On Apr 24, 2005, at 6:30 PM, DJ Soundwave wrote:

> responding to violence with more
> severe violence is not going to work. it's bad for the scene, it's bad
> for your soul, it's bad for the world. use your strength to neutralize
> violence, to see it coming and to defuse it. stooping to their level
> only degrades your parties. if you're stronger than they are and
> smarter than they are, use your intelligence to see their next move
> before they make it, and use your strength to protect them from their
> own stupidity. they are the weak and the foolish, and they are more
> dangerous to themselves than they are to you.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bottom Line: if it says "Narcotics Checkpoint," it isn't one.

"Ahead of the roadblocks, officers put up signs reading "Narcotics
Checkpoint One Mile Ahead" and "Narcotics Canine Ahead." There was
no checkpoint. Officers would then look for people attempting to
turn around illegally or throwing items out of windows, pull them
over for the criminal violation, and use that as a basis for a
search."

Adding to that:

It isn't cause for suspicion, ruled the US Supreme Court, if you
*legally* turn around and drive out of the area to avoid a drunken
driving checkpoint, a legal type of checkpoint where you can be
stopped and questioned.

Again adding:

Having been stopped for a minor equipment violation at Garberville,
CA, a famous "let's stop them for any reason imaginable and see if
they're stoned and carrying pounds of pot out of the Emerald
Triangle" hotspot, I discovered that having used Visine previously
is very wise. I'm not saying I was stoned or carrying pot; I'm
saying that having not having red eyes (due to allergies or any
other reason) is a good idea. It gives plausible deniability,
important if you have red eyes from simple hay fever or any other
reason.

Next month, Infinity will convert a poorly performing station in San Franci=
sco
 to a format that will play only ``podcasts,'' or amateur recordings
 distributed via the Internet to listeners' iPods and other digital music
 players.

Infinity, which is part of the Viacom media conglomerate that also owns CBS
 and MTV, announced Wednesday that it would convert its KYCY-AM (1550) stat=
ion
 in San Francisco to the new format May 16.

> > responding to violence with more

> > for your soul, it's bad for the world. use your strength to neutralize

> > only degrades your parties. if you're stronger than they are and
> > smarter than they are, use your intelligence to see their next move
> > before they make it, and use your strength to protect them from their
> > own stupidity. they are the weak and the foolish, and they are more
> > dangerous to themselves than they are to you.

Subject: [sfraves] your weekend party reviews???

ok folks, i know you went out this weekend.  let's hear your reviews!

friday, i was at mighty for Thrust with Lee Coombs.  saw lots of
friends so the company was fantastic.  my set kinda blew chunks and to
make up for that, i enthusiastically began drinking any cup or bottle
that was handed to me.  had to leave a tad early because i was
fuckered.  but good times!  saw lots of folks i haven't seen in
awhile.

saturday, made the trek down to socal.  me and aaron did a tag set at
a rave and tore the bejesus out of it.  one of the best sets i've ever
played with aaron.  had a blast!  this was uber-rave.  like rave-on
raver!

you can see for yourself here:
http://www.tiggerlovesyou.com/somemore/somemore169.html

--=20

Subject: [sfraves] Eklektic Hektic Review... Oooh Shit man

OK... so Saturday was fun!!!  I had a nice walk 2 the bus stop in Hercules
& had alota think out loud moments.. although this time I didn't pretend I
was the Validvictorian of my High School class & gave the speech during
graduation...

So I got 2 the City & hung out w/ Phil (
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/profiles/sfr.php?cmd=show_profile&userid=53)
who had a pre EK Pizza party @ his pad in like SOMA/ China Basin pad... oh
yeah!!!  YUMMY Pizza!

OK.. now EK was fuckin' sick!!  Like I got there early.. MikeyJ was on the
decks in the back... Rizzo (I thnink) fka J Rock was in the front... like
the front was like all mash up w/ all the DJs they had pretty much or it
seemed like i dunno... I can honestly that well.. when Lexxus was up
there, he was fuckin' Rockin' it like crazy w/ his Breaks set.. actually..
I think until he popped up.. the breaks room was kinda mellow 4 the most
part until he hopped on.. well.. IMHO... then after him... LIke Donna
Matrix, Ms Throwdown, oh gosh... Felix (well.. I think I saw him spin or
just early on in the night), but yeah.. ooh wow.. it was Awesome in the
Front room & I did find myself in there dancing alot!!!  But oooh...
Yeah.. Lexxus was Dope!  I kinda left like 15 mintues b4 the club closed
down & Lexxus did get back on the decks & spun the theme song 2 A-Team
over a nice fat yummy beat!!!  Wow!!!

In the Jungle room.. oooh my gosh... OK... yeah... MikeyJ really got
things off on the right beat & well.. honestly ( & please don't tell the
other DJs) but my fave sets that night were Soundboy & Ivry!!  Heeeeello
2day.. those were the 2 sets I did happen 2 like well.. dance most of
thier like entire sets!!  Ooooooooh...

I mean.. there was a period of time when i walked around the corner from
Cat Club 2 like get some air & I endedup @ another bar.. I was ther 4 like
an hour or a lil' longer.. but yeah man.. I got bought like a few drinks @
that bar by random dudes... then like when i left.. I realized that i was
in a gay biker bar.. then realized i made out w/ 5 guys 1 get 10 free
drinks!  Yeah...  I was kinda toasted when I got 2 the biker bar & well..
slightly sloshed when I left.. but man.. they were soooooooo nice!  Come 2
think of it.. I'm lucky there was no roofie slipping in 1 of those drinks
when i was @ the gay biker bar, ya know?

But yeah.. it was an amazing fuckin' time.. Heeeeeeello 2Day.. I'm still
HIGH from that night still.. fuckin' A man.. Ya know.. it was just a
Groovy fuckin' night!!  Awesome fuckin' Vibe, hung out w/ the Jungle fam..
Groovy Fuckin'  Music aaaaaaaaaaall night loooooong!!!  I Loved It!!!

I dunno man.. all i could say is that if U never been, then well... I
don't wanna seem 2 exclusive about it, but ya know.. it's bonkers fuckin'
wild mad Love the whole night!!!  SEriously man.. oh... it's like just 1
of those fuckin' parties that charged me up man... WOW!!!

How was the SFR/ SF Dance thingie @ Club 6???  Man.. I meant 2 stop by &
hang out w/ Jacob 4 a while.. miss that guy!




-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - andrea parker @ club 6 tomorrow!

Wednesday, MAY 4th, 2005

DimSum and XLR8R present:
THE ANDREA PARKER TOUR 
 
DJ and Live Sets From:

Andrea Parker (!K7, MoWax, Beggers Banquet, Touchin Bass)
Mochipet (DimSum, Tigerbeat6, Bpitchcontrol)
Forest Green (DimSum, SisterSF)
Sindri (DimSum, Imputor?)
Samira (SisterSF)

With Chillout Room by:
-The Ambient Mafia-
64k
drop
Harken
redstickman
4Matt (the drow)

Visuals by Konstrukt

Club Six
60 6th St. (between Market/Mission), SF 
9pm, $10

Andrea Parker, known for her electro mixes and sublime
productions on !K7, MoWax, and Beggers Banquet is
headed stateside to support her own imprint Touchin
Bass!

Parker has contributed to several experimental
electronic releases through out her career including
remixes for Depeche Mode, Ryuichi Sakamoto, and
Tipper.

Miss Parkers DJ style is uncompromising and crosses
all boundaries. Shes supported Radiohead on the US
part of their Kid A tour, experimented live on stage
with avant-garde supremos : Bang On A Can (Philip
Glass and Steve Reich) and provided more than a little
entertainment at parties for director Roman Polanski
and fashion house; Gucci.

Her popularity as a DJ was confirmed by the high sales
of her mix for !K7s DJ Kicks series which showcased
the variety of her musical tastes; shes not afraid to
fuse hip hop pioneers like Man Parish with electronic
pushers Gescom. 

More info :
http://www.xlr8r.com/article.php?uid=3251CA24BE8730E1A8F17C32E7AA7142

From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 03 May 2005 18:02:17.0351 (UTC) FILETIME=[3E356970:01C5500A]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] I had a crazy dream last night that I went to a rave

It was in a pretty small dark room with black lights and neon on the
walls. The DJ sucked and didn't even seem to care about mixing or what
feeling the song created.

There were only about thirty ravers there and we all ate pizza at the
start of the party.

Some dude hooked me up with some pills, which I took and were lousy.
Everyone at the party was happy, tripping hard and I was the only one
feeling depressed.

Me and my friend left the party early because the music just wasn't good
and we didn't feel like dancing. But after we left we found out that a
good DJ showed up and things went crazy.

Geeze what a nightmare.

Two things this dream made me realize:

1. I have hidden fears about feeling like I miss out on stuff
2. Hidden fears that I am unable to be happy, unless the situation is
perfect.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Cubik & Origami LIVE @ SCOUT in SF this Wednesday! (tomorrow night!)

Hey all, my friend Matt (Cubik) and I will be playing a crazy
guitar-bass-decks-electonics-fx downtempo set this Wednesday (and every
Wednesday for a while) at our home label Wide Hive's new weekly, SCOUT.


We will play live from 9-10, and Variable Unit (all-star
hip-hop/jazz/funk live band) will play from 10-12, backing up some of
the best local MCs that have signed up for a chance at the mic!

The shows will all be recorded on audiophile equipment and the best
will be culled and released on CD later this year as "The Best Of
SCOUT".

Come to the Red Devil Lounge - 1695 Polk Street, San Francisco,
tomorrow night for some serious soul funk and downtempo bump.

Check out http://widehive.com/scout.html for the details!

Cheers,
-george c | origami

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  DOW RELEASES "ACCEPTABLE RISK" PROGRAM AT BANKING
  CONFERENCE

--=====================_10257980==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

May 3, 2005
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

DOW RELEASES "ACCEPTABLE RISK" PROGRAM AT BANKING CONFERENCE
"Risk Calculator" helps ensure sound business practice

When government is made to take the back seat in regulatory matters,
corporations must rely on their own judgment to determine what is, and
what isn't, acceptable where human lives are at risk.

Doing this has until now been more of an art than a science. With
Acceptable Risk, business finally has a risk standard of its own,
reflecting its values and allowing us to reliably factor human and
environmental casualties into business decisions in accordance with
the soundest of economic principles.

Last Thursday in London, Dow representative Erastus Hamm unveiled
Acceptable Risk, the Acceptable Risk Calculator, and the Acceptable
Risk mascot--a life-sized golden skeleton named Gilda--to an audience
of about 70 banking professionals, including some from Dow's largest
investors. Many of the bankers in attendance excitedly signed up for
licenses for the Calculator, which helps businesses scientifically
determine the point where casualties start to cut into profit, while
suggesting the best regions on earth to locate dangerous ventures.

Hamm told the bankers how Acceptable Risk would have applied to some
famous "skeletons in the closet" of big business: IBM's WWII sale of
technology to the Nazis for use in identifying Jews; Dow's production
of napalm and Agent Orange for use in Vietnam; and the plight of
Dursban, a Dow pesticide whose main ingredient came out of Nazi nerve
agent research, was tested on student volunteers as recently as 1998,
and was finally banned two years later.

Each of these cases entailed heavy casualties, Hamm noted, and yet
each was immensely profitable and therefore consistent with sound
business practice. Hamm said the case of the Bhopal gas disaster of
1984 was slightly more complicated--but so long as so-called "socially
responsible" investor groups do not get away with forcing Dow to spend
too much time on the matter at the May 12 AGM and elsewhere, that case
could end up being a "golden skeleton" too.

Please visit http://www.dowethics.com/risk/ to try out the Acceptable
Risk Calculator for yourself, and for text, photos and video of the
London announcement.

Contacts: Erastus Hamm <mailto:ehamm@dowethics.com>
           Vikram Banarjee <mailto:vbanarjee@dowethics.com>





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] "THE FUTURE OF CREATIVITY IN THE DIGITAL AGE"  TUESDAY, 5.3

--=====================_10890469==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

A bit of a late notice, I know, but I listened to the interview with Paul 
Miller this morning on NPR and found out about the program.



POPANDPOLITICS.COM PRESENTS:
"THE FUTURE OF CREATIVITY IN THE DIGITAL AGE"  TUESDAY, 5.3

PopandPolitics.com is proud to present its first MASH-UP, an innovative 
series pairing newsmakers from the worlds of culture and public policy. 
This inaugural benefit event will feature a conversation on THE FUTURE OF 
CREATIVITY IN THE DIGITAL AGE with Stanford law professor LAWRENCE LESSIG 
and musician/artist/filmmaker PAUL MILLER AKA DJ SPOOKY. It will be 
moderated by multimedia journalist FARAI CHIDEYA.  Admission to the event 
includes an after-party at which DJ Spooky will spin a guest set. His new 
album "Drums of Death," featuring Chuck D and Dave Lombardo of Slayer, was 
just released on Thirsty Ear.

7 - 8:30 p.m., Conversation
8:30 - 11 p.m., After-Party
Swedish American Hall, 2174 Market Street, San Francisco
$23
For more information or tickets visit
<http://67.114.169.99:8888/MailList/redirect.cfm?ID=26696&MID=317 
&LID=3>http://www.popandpolitics.com/mashup/mashup_release/mashupPR.htm

POPANDPOLITICS.COM (www.popandpolitics.com), a nonpartisan 501(c)3 
nonprofit, is an online magazine and education program affiliated with San 
Francisco State University's Center for Integration and Improvement of 
Journalism. Its mission is to cover the space where pop culture and 
politics intersect, and to train the next generation of journalists to lend 
their voice to the most important debates of our times.

This event launches PopandPolitics.com's capital campaign for a site 
upgrade and redesign. PopandPolitics.com, a pioneering site in grassroots 
political/cultural journalism and blogging, was founded ten years ago. The 
redesigned site will include increased audio / video capabilities and 
interactivity.

Participants:

LAWRENCE LESSIG (<http://www.lessig.org>www.lessig.org) is a professor of 
law at Stanford University and is well-known as a champion of the public 
domain. He represented web site operator Eric Eldred in the ground-breaking 
case Eldred v. Ashcroft, a challenge to the 1998 Sonny Bono Copyright Term 
Extension Act. Lessig was named one of Scientific American's Top 50 
Visionaries, for arguing "against interpretations of copyright that could 
stifle innovation and discourse online." He chairs the Creative Commons 
(www.creativecommons.org) project and is a boardmember of the Electronic 
Frontier Foundation (www.eff.org). Lessig is the author of "The Future of 
Ideas" and "Code and Other Laws of Cyberspace." He also helped build the 
case against Microsoft in Department of Justice v. Microsoft.

DJ SPOOKY aka Paul D. Miller (<http://www.djspooky.com>www.djspooky.com) is 
a conceptual artist, writer, and musician. His written work has appeared in 
The Village Voice, The Source, Artforum, Raygun, Rap Pages, Paper Magazine, 
and a host of other periodicals. He is a co-Publisher of the magazine "A 
Gathering of the Tribes." His work has appeared at the Whitney Biennial, 
The Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and many other museums and galleries. 
Miller is most well known as "DJ Spooky that Subliminal Kid." He has 
recorded a huge volume of music and has collaborated with musicians and 
composers including Iannis Xenakis, Ryuichi Sakamoto, Butch Morris, Kool 
Keith a.k.a. Doctor Octagon, Killa Priest from Wu-Tang Clan, Yoko Ono and 
Thurston Moore from Sonic Youth.

FARAI CHIDEYA is a multi-media journalist whose experience includes 
anchoring ABC's late-night broadcast, "World News Now," hosting Oxygen 
Media's signature program, "Pure Oxygen," and hosting KALW current 
events/call in show "Your Call." She is currently the host/correspondent 
with NPR's "News & Notes with Ed Gordon." Chideya has consistently brought 
new ideas and audiences into mainstream media, focusing on serving young 
news-consumers and diverse audiences. She is the author of three 
non-fiction books, most recently "Trust: Reaching the 100 Million Missing 
Voters," (www.trustthebook.com) and is the founder of PopandPolitics.com.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

Subject: Re: [sfraves] raving in southern cal / candie kids alive and kicking

Southern cali is alive and thriving. I was at Xara Dulzura the weekend before 
last. I had fun laptop DJing at the Xaruba Cafe where I setup a small 
soundsystem. A highlight for me was segueing from me DJing with live drummers, 
to the drummers taking over, and me beat matching to them (or attempting to). It 
erupted into a cool live looping of afro-house drum-beats in a jam session with 
a bunch of drummers, mandolin, and sax player. People got some serious dancing 
going on. Met cool people. Even got some very inspiring positive feedback online 
and on tribe.

Heard and met great DJ's including LA's Wolfie and San Diego's Jack-Tripper.
Mutaytor (see mutaytor.com) put on an a massive live show. I was well blown away.

All in all, I actually find what little I've seen of the so-cal scene to be more 
"plurry" without being pretentious about being so. Then again, I am way way sick 
of the bay area and most of the people there (NOT YOU OF COURSE!!) so this may
have something to do with it. :-/ It's nice to see a fresh place, look upon
things with fresh eyes, and see beautiful valleys, mountains, people, art and
music. There was even a passover seder, where at the end, two crazily 
face-painted, beautiful stiltwalkers came up on the circle and said "we're 
passing over!" then gave a big cheer to the woman leading the seder, Athena. The 
whole experience  was amazing. Best passover seder I've been to. Nice communal 
food sharing all weekend.

http://www.podcollective.com/fora/viewtopic.php?p=4571#4571

As you can see from the pix above, there were no candy kids whatsoever (I'm in 
the collection above twice, and I'm far too old to be candy).
Candy is for the unimaginative. This event just had lots of people in
costumes.  There's a difference. Candy kids are kids. Fortunately, I didn't
feel particularly geriatric at Xara.

It felt kinda  like a weekend campout party at Camp & Sons, but with more 
people, more stages, more audience participation, and more live music.

-- Niels.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

troy --

thanks for the info on 'a scanner, darkly'.  i'd definitely call that a
synchronicity!  i was just finishing up prometheus rising last night and there
was a part in there where they were all laughing about a book that talks about
this lodge called "toot and come in" and they realized that also could be
pronounced "tutenkhamen".  well his wife in the next room just happened to be
watching a show on the mummy.  coincedence?  for me and my friends, they happen
to often to be merely such.

--

Synchronicity reveals the meaningful connections between the subjective and
objective world.

- Carl G. Jung

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> May 3, 2005
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> 
> DOW RELEASES "ACCEPTABLE RISK" PROGRAM AT BANKING CONFERENCE
> "Risk Calculator" helps ensure sound business practice
> 
> When government is made to take the back seat in regulatory matters,
> corporations must rely on their own judgment to determine what is,
> and
> what isn't, acceptable where human lives are at risk.
> 
> Doing this has until now been more of an art than a science. With
> Acceptable Risk, business finally has a risk standard of its own,
> reflecting its values and allowing us to reliably factor human and
> environmental casualties into business decisions in accordance with
> the soundest of economic principles.

Jessi:
 
I've had really good luck with a Cannon ELF series. For about $300, it's small, has kickass resolution, and with a 512 MB video card you can get some pretty long video clips w. sound. Pretty sure they have even bigger ones now. I'm sure other peeps on here might have some better recomendations, but there's mine.

peace
 
Chuck

Subject: [sfraves] DJ AM - deejay to the stars???

DJ hired to play SFMOMA party says it's about tunes, not his L.A. glitz
- Aidin Vaziri, Chronicle Pop Music Critic
Tuesday, May 3, 2005

Click to View

Yes, we know Adam Michael Goldstein is the soon-to-be-husband of
Nicole Richie. And, sure, he used to play with Crazy Town and Papa
Roach, two of the more dubious bands not just in recent memory but of
the whole past century. But it's his record collection that reassures
us that the 32-year-old Philadelphia native who goes by the
professional name DJ AM is the right guy to rock the Post-Modern Party
after the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's Modern Ball on
Wednesday.

Surveying the stacks of vinyl crowding the walls and floors of his Los
Angeles home, he estimates over the phone that there must be something
like 7, 000 discs in there, ranging from Wu-Tang Clan's "Enter the
Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)" to Elton John's "Goodbye Yellow Brick Road." Of
course, he could make room for a few more but then where would he put
the 600 designer sneakers he owns?

Between his four regular weekly gigs -- two in Hollywood, two at the
Hard Rock Hotel in Las Vegas -- and the wedding planning, it's lucky
Goldstein made time at all for the San Francisco event. Having served
as Hollywood's unofficial celebrity DJ since 1993, when he held a
residency at the popular star lair Dragonfly, he contends that now the
perfect night doesn't entail playing Killers records for the likes of
Brad Pitt and Lindsay Lohan but loading up on rented videos and
microwave popcorn.

"Home with my fiancee, relaxing and watching movies in bed," Goldstein
says. "That's my favorite thing."

He says he hasn't been starstruck since Ben Stiller approached him on
the decks nearly five years ago. "At first I was sure he was going to
complain about the music, from the look on his face," Goldstein says.
"But he said, 'Are you busy in the next few weeks? You're amazing and
I would love for you to come play at my wedding in Hawaii.' That
happened at Kate Hudson's birthday party."

Since then he's worked at the bar mitzvah of Steven Spielberg's son,
Nicki Hilton's runway show and the birthday parties of everyone from
Tom Cruise to Melissa Etheridge. In March alone, he packed in a dinner
party for Jessica Alba, "The Ring Two" movie premiere and a Hugo Boss
fashion show at the Beverly Hills Hotel, to name a few.

"I'm just really lucky that I happen to live in Hollywood," Goldstein
says. "I've been hired for a lot of jobs just because of my location."

He also deserves credit for his complete disregard of genres. On any
given night, he's likely to mix up records by the Jackson Five, Oasis,
Ciara, George Michael, System of a Down, anything goes. "I'm all over
the map," he says. He recently replaced his traditional DJ setup with
a computer program called Serrata that allows him to travel with his
entire record collection on just two pieces of vinyl and a laptop
computer, which really cracks things open.

Starbucks has approached Goldstein about marketing a DJ AM mix CD that
would be available exclusively at the coffee shops. He's also looking
to move into production in the future. And the whole tabloid thing?

"It is what it is," Goldstein says. "It has nothing to do with me as a pers=
on."
Post-Modern Party: 9 p.m. to midnight Wednesday. With DJ AM, DJ Spooky
and DJ Angola spinning at San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, 151
Third St., San Francisco. Tickets $125. (415) 618-3263 or
sfmoma.org/modernball. The Modern Ball and the Modern Ball gala dinner
are sold out.
--=20

yep, yep, i got it, i'm on it....

Is this life imitating art or vicey-versa?

it was a bitch to find though, google notwithstanding, since i wanted the=
=20
book vers., since it's a lot clearer than the movie:

"If a new car built by my company leaves Chicago traveling west at 60 miles=
=20
per hour, and the rear differential locks up, and the car crashes and burns=
=20
with everyone trapped inside, does my company initiate a recall?

You take the population of vehicles in the field (*A*) and multiply it by=
=20
the probable rate of failure (*B*), then multiply the result by the average=
=20
cost of an out-of-court settlement (*C*).

*A* times *B* times *C* equals *X.* . . .=20

If *X* is greater than the cost of a recall, we recall the cars and no one=
=20
gets hurt.

If *X* is less than the cost of a recall, then we don't do a recall."

Fight Club, page 30, 1996

Why people picked up on 'the first rule of Fight Club is that...,' instead=
=20
of this passage is beyond me, since it's the heart of the story.

whatthefuckever.

On a personal note, the most money I ever made in my life, for no work to=
=20
speak of, was holding a seat for a lobbyist on Capitol Hill for an asbestos=
=20
hearing.=20

wonder which side of the issue they were on?

kinda why i don't do that
'werk<http://www.al.com/living/birminghamnews/index.ssf?/base/living/111398=
8973270320.xml>'
anymore

Also...

My Mom's first job in the USA was repping Nazi Holocaust Death Camp=20
Survivors.

She got them lifetime pensions from the West German government and she=20
worked in the field from 1963 to 1979, which is about the time that all=20
people who lived through that experience were accounted for.

It wasn't until the 1990's that pressure was put on the Swiss banking syste=
m=20
to release the assets that were stolen from the Jews.

In other words, they just ran the clock out on the Survivors.

Nice, huh?

And my Libertarian friends wonder why I take a dim view of their trust in=
=20
business/corporations to:

'Do The Right Thing.'

right, right.

nwa

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: JJ Islas on An Epiphany Of Sound

Yes folks.  In case you didn't notice, last week marked my return to
the airwaves after an extended trip to India.  (And I marked it without
any sort of announcement. ;) )  But this week I'm not slacking so much.
Because I'm letting you know that I'll be having JJ Islas back on the
show so that he can being you a mix of house and progressive beats.  Do
tune in and welcome me back to the land of S.F.!

90.1 FM on the radio dial and online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu
Show runs from 9a-noon Wed (aka tomorrow.)

Namaste!


http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

mers,

to). It

n with
> a bunch of drummers, mandolin, and sax player. People got some serious da=
ncing

s may

DJ Soundwave wrote:
> you were at Xara Dulzura?!!?!

Yep! I got the pictures to prove it, and I didn't even bring a camera.

> holy shit dude. I've seen those pictures already. that is EXTREMELY
> cool. apart from anything else I've been trying to figure out whether
> that happened here or in Europe.

Dulzura, CA. Inland from San Diego, near the Mexican border. Gorgeous 
landscapes. It looks almost like it could be a foreign country.

> 
> the green transparent kick drum, I fucking creamed my panties when I
> saw that shit.
> 
> anyhoo. even tho the candy thing wasn't happening in those pics you
> must admit there's a ton of fuzzy clothing and all that.
> 
> are you the guy on the laptop in the pictures?

Yes. That's me. I was happy to find four or five pictures of me snapped by three 
different photographers. Of course, I had the "honey" of having a bunch of 
beautiful women bellydancing in front of me, so I tended to be in a lot of 
background shots: http://nielsmayer.com/npm_xara_2005_3.jpg (Shayde is so amazing!).

I need to glue the midi crossfader I built ontop of my audio interface box so it 
actually looks like i'm DJing and not just twiddling invisible knobs and 
clicking keys on my computer. Being a geek is so uncool!

Did I ever tell you guys about the time I setup my "rig" in the wrong tent at 
burning man... so like I'm being a total dork wiring my shit together and kind 
of realizing the vibe was a little strange for music. For one, there was no 
soundsystem. For two, there were people having sex. I eventually figured out
I was in the wrong dome, tore all my shit down. Turned out the system I was 
scheduled to play on kept playing at full volume outdoors all night ... so
i setup outside, and rocked out, trying not to think about the guy doing the 
bucking bronco ride (hand in the air and all) on some hot chick right in front 
of me just moments before...

-- Niels.

on my shirt somemore @ school...

seat @ the bar... MS. HEIDI & MR ERIC walk in & Hello 2day.... me & Heidi
have this totally mondo super fuckin' Awesome Groovy Hug of 2 married
people who like just won the fuckin' Lotto happy hug dealie!!  YAY!!  Love
U Girl!!   LoL.. It was also Dope hangin' out w/ Eric & we gave each other
a mondo hug!

Mooger... so like Eric, Heidi & I were like mondo talking, then this guy
from across the bar kinda like came up 2 me & started scopin' my rings..
hmmm.. ok.. so that part wasn't weird.. but then he said 2 me, "Wow, I
never met a thick asain like you b4, you're so HOT, your earings & rings
are so HOT, oh mygosh, your hair is so HOT, Wow, you're beauty mark on
your face it so HOT" & well.. he did that thing where like well... let's
just say no random person ever ever EVER in my whole life @ a bar like
started rubbing body parts on my knee like this dude, his name was Venice
like Italy, LA Venice, did... LOLOLOLOLMAO Hello 2day man.. he hella threw

Sweetie, U can back me up 'cause U were there 4 the whole thing!!

So Weird...

bge rude, so I like switched hangin' out w/ Andy & Orange then headed back
2 Venice, Heidi, & Eric.... LOLOLOLMAO  I mean... like 4 the most part...
Venice was a Groovy lil' flamey queenie boy & I was totally flattered @
some1 actually throwing themself @ me. but it was just weird how that was
like happening.. esp after hearing that a girl I know wants 2 screw me &
has been thinking about it 4 over a year now or something like that... 
HELLO 2DAY.. I tell U SFRavers... this is all fact.. no fiction in this
story!!!!

totally played this set that I dunno... parts of it sounded like booty-ish
kinda house, but not really, he did throw in some bad ass Electro @ 1
point, & there was this Groovy Oriental chordy sounding song that i was
diggin' alot!!

with... all we kept sayin' in the bar was how HOT everything was!!  AndyW
is HOT is his tie!!  The bartenders boobs I took a picture of was HOT!!!

Andy.. he spun a really Awesome, techno-ie diversified set 'cause I think
it was him who told me once he wants 2 keep every1 guessin' when he's on
the decks!!  But yeah.. I'm sure his set was HOT!

Hugger Mugger: So Hot!!!

Oh yeah.. I was looking 4 Tim.. where U there Homeboy???  I feel sorry
that i scared every1 I asked there if they were U who I didn't know yet!!!

From sfraves-return-121102-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed May 04 21:55:10 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121102-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4023 invoked from network); 4 May 2005 21:55:07 -0000
Message-Id: <6.2.1.2.2.20050504145352.02a09150@localhost>
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.2.1.2
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 14:55:10 -0700
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_12595411==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  KENT STATE 35 YEARS AGO

--=====================_12595411==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

35 years ago National Guard troops killed four Vietnam War protestors on 
the <http://www.may4.org/>Kent State campus in Ohio.

This post is not about the Vietnam War, nor is it about the brave men and 
women who fight in wars. It is about the brave men and women who never step 
on the "battlefield" yet play an important role in ending wars.

During war time, we see at least two types of Patriotism arise. We have the 
patriots who go off to fight the war. And, we have the patriots who oppose 
the war. Both types of patriots exhibit courage and love of country. But, 
there are rarely parades and medals for the latter.

In the Vietnam era, there is no question that the protests helped bring a 
close to the conflict. Today is a day to remember those who died doing just 
that and a day to remember the lessons of those events.

Since we are in wartime again, its possible we'll see additional protests 
if Iraq drags out or other unforeseen events occur. When we see those 
protests, we'll need to keep in mind that most involved will be law abiding 
patriots demonstrating their love of country and their support for the 
troops in order to get them out of a dangerous situation. We'll also need 
to remember the right to voice that type of patriotism.

During this war, we've had our share of squelching of dissent. We don't 
need to detail that here. But, luckily, we haven't had anyone killed for 
dissent. In order to keep the worst from happening we need to look back and 
remember those patriots who died that May 5 in Ohio for simply showing love 
of country and for helping to bring our troops home from a dangerous situation.

I have to admit I didn't realize this anniversary until I heard this Crosby 
Stills Nash and Young song on the radio today:

Tin soldiers and Nixon's comin'.
We're finally on our own.
This summer I hear the drummin'.
Four dead in Ohio.

Gotta get down to it.
Soldiers are cutting us down.
Should have been done long ago.
What if you knew her and
Found her dead on the ground?
How can you run when you know?

Na, na, na, na, na, na, na, na.
Na, na, na, na, na, na, na, na.
Na, na, na, na, na, na, na, na.
Na, na, na, na, na, na, na, na.

Gotta get down to it.
Soldiers are cutting us down.
Should have been done long ago.
What if you knew her and
Found her dead on the ground?
How can you run when you know?

Tin soldiers and Nixon's comin'.
We're finally on our own.
This summer I hear the drummin'.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio.
Four dead in Ohio

..................

Legend has it that as soon as Neil Young heard the news from Ohio he 
grabbed his guitar and started to write the song. Young played the song for 
David Crosby and said they should consider recording it at a later time. 
Crosby insisted they record it right away. So, they called Stephen Stills 
and Graham Nash and told them to book studio time and they were on their 
way to LA to record this new song.

The band released it right away, even though their label was already 
pushing their recently released single "Teach the Children." The song meant 
so much to the band that they didn't care that it would take away from the 
marketing of the current hit. To CSNY, the hits never mattered as much as 
the message. Like much of the music of the day, it spoke directly to an 
important issue and took it head on. Its a great song. But, I hope we 
remember the lessons from those who died and hope another song like this 
never has to be written again.

Here are the names of those who died at Kent State, so that they may not be 
forgotten:

ALISON KRAUSE

JEFFREY MILLER

SANDRA SCHEUER

WILLIAM SCHROEDER





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_12595411==.ALT--

Wednesday, May 4th, 2005

Special Guest DJ:


ICON - REVERB, DJICON.COM
ICON has a number of radio show residencies. She does a monthly Breaks
show for "Thump Funk" on XM Satellite 80, plays regularly for "House
Nation", Friday nights on Wild 94.9, and still periodically appears on
"Solid State", a weekly Saturday night electronic music show on K-ROCK
in New York City. She has also appeared on Bay Area Breakbeat shows,
"Future Breaks FM" and "Bassline FM".

ICON will be celebrating=20

everb's first international release this Saturday night at Sno Drift.
The event will showcase 14+ DJs: Special guest Derb from Germany,
Mystere, St.John, Taj, Gianni, Lexxx, Drc, Smoove, Bam, Hope and Wink
residents Denise, Felipe Avelar and Aaron Jae! Please visit this link
to purchase your tickets and get complete event details: Reverb - This
Saturday Night @ Sno Drift

Network + Support
Zen City Records has become one of San Francisco's leading electronica
vendors. The store has six listening stations and boasts a "Zen-like
atmosphere," including Buddha statues and sofas. Before you reach
enlightenment, sample any record and chat with the friendly staff. New
and used records. 105 Valencia, S.F. (415) 437-1578

UNLEASH YOUR INNER KRAKEN

When they've had enough rum, the old-timers tell 
the tale of the last voyage of the Jiggletech, 
a noble submarine. Weighing anchor, she drifted from

undersea grotto of kinky pyramids and giant pearls.

  http://www.context.fm/sutekh.html

  http://www.iamthedj.com/music.html

  http://www.orangeage.com

Fearing the pleasures this might unleash, a squadron
of black helicopters intercepted the vessel on the
horizon's edge. The good ship dove for the ocean floor
as depth charges rained down from the sky! Relentless 
sonic pressures pounded her hull with each detonation,
discharging waves of unending acoustical force. 
Her hatches battened, her bulkheads sealed, 
the Jiggletech drifted deeper.

  Azeem  *live hip hop 
  (Future Primitive / Wide Hive / Oaklyn Records) 
  http://www.widehive.com/azeem.html

  http://www.djmozaic.net

Beyond the reach of sunlight, the Jiggletech
found herself embraced by the coiling tentacles
of a radiant squid. Gently, this leviathan
deposited its catch on the sandy sea bottom. 

  Origami vs. Cubik (newstylesound.com / Moksha Tribe)
  http://newstylesound.com

Having jaws but no gills, the submarine's divers
ventured curiously out through the hatch, snorkles 
in hand, masks and tanks at the ready. What they 
found was no inky abyss; all around them were
Nereids, Neptunes and shape-shifting sea-nymphs -- 
a deep water garden of coral and bubbles, 
beautifully lit by the phosphorescence of the 
benevolent squid.

  BRAIN-BENDING SUPER-COLOSSAL LIGHTING 
  by Coil & Radiant Atmospheres

  by Know:Audio & Gateway Systems

Scuttling her butt in this clamshell of love,
the Jiggletech never returned.

From sfraves-return-121112-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu May 05 18:56:37 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121112-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 10853 invoked from network); 5 May 2005 18:56:35 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Message-Id: <p06210201bea01c9be037@[192.168.0.100]>
Date: Thu, 5 May 2005 11:56:30 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  he Connection Between Hip Hop, New Wave and Punk

Something to Ponder Over:
The Connection Between Hip Hop, New Wave and Punk
by Davey D

This past Monday, Spinderella of Salt-N-Pepa, Mike Shinoda of Linkin
Park and myself among others, participated in a panel discussion at
UCLA that focused on the business workings and current state of Hip
Hop.  Before we launched into Q&A from the audience all of were asked
'What CD we were listening to in our ride?'  The audience seemed a bit
surprised when I mentioned that in my CD deck was the 1981 album
'JuJu' by new wave/punk act Siouxsie & the Banshees.  Songs like
'Spellbound, 'Monitor' and 'Into the Light' brought back fond
memories.  More importantly the whole early new wave/punk scene was a
very much apart of my early Hip Hop experience.

For those who wish to walk down memory lane, how could we forget when
New Wave/Punk acts like Thomas Dolby, Tom Tom Club, The Clash,
Blondie, The Thompson Twins, The Police, Depeche Mode, Human League,
Tears for Fears and David Bowie to name a few were regularly heard
within Hip Hop circles especially in many of our 'hoods'.  No offense
to Run DMC, who are often sighted as the first Hip Hop group to merge
Rock and Rap, when we really go back and look at what was happening in
the late 70s early 80s, we'll find that there was an often under
reported important conversation and cultural exchange that was taking
place with hardcore b-boys from the South Bronx and the
disenfranchised rebellious New Wave Punk kids in downtown Manhattan on
the Lower Eastside and in the Village.

It really began when acts like Afrika Bambaataa and Grandmaster Flash
who were just starting to record records were starting to be invited
to perform at some key downtown spots like the Mudclub or the Roxy
which was frequented by punk/new wave kids.  The parallels between the
hardcore Hip Hoppers from the Bronx and the Rebellious Punk Kids soon
became obvious.  Both groups had reacted organically to a stale,
formulaic music industry that was serving the public watered down
disco and arena rock.  The Blacks and Puerto Ricans in the Bronx
embraced the classic James Brown Soul and Funk music of Sly and the
Family Stone and developed Hip Hop, while their Lower Eastside white
counterparts got into the British import punk and new wave.

People like Bambaataa, Fab 5 Freddy, Debby Harry of Blondie and
British new Wave icon Malcolm McClaren would wind up being key figures
in Hip Hop's first cross cultural exchange.  The B-Boys from the Bronx
would get nice gigs at the Punk/New Wave spots while the punk crowd
would literally be granted safe passage to Bronx River or the PAL up
in the Bronx.  It's important to note that this was not a natural
occurrence which has often been erroneously stated, especially with
the white kids coming up to the Bronx.  It was a deliberate attempt on
the parts of folks who had mutual respect and vision to build with one
another.

When you look back into time you'll find that both the early Hip Hop
and Punk/New Wave groups equally influenced each other.  This
admiration was reflected in Blondie's pivotal song 'Rapture' where
lead singer Debby Harry after being escorted up to a B-Boy party at
the PAL club where Grandmaster Flash was playing gave props to Fab 5
Freddy as well as Flash who blew her away.

Soon after you had people like Malcolm McClaren teaming up with 5%
cats like the World Famous Supreme Team who did radio to do songs like
Buffalo Gals (which was named after a London clothing store-not the
size of woman's butts), 'Hey DJ' and 'Hobo Scratch'.  History will
show that others like the punk rock group known as the Beastie Boys
would start to embrace rap and put out songs like Cookiepuss and go on
to become Hip Hop's first meaningful white act.  Pioneering groups
like the Cold Crush Brothers would release songs like 'Punk Rock Rap'
while Flash and his crew did songs like new wave influenced songs like
'Scorpio'.  Bambaataa himself would go onto to form a group called
Time Zone and would record a huge song called 'World Destruction' with
punk icon Johnny Rotten.


The whole time this was happening between the years 1979-1984, you saw
the musical walls of segregation come down as artists from both genres
would become familiar to both audiences.  In other words during the
early 80s you would hear Thomas Dolby's 'Blinded Me With Science',
David Bowie's 'Let's Dance', Devo's 'Let It Whip' or Tom Tom Club's
'Genius of Love' not only being played on urban radio, but also at
popular Hip Hop night spots where playing them would help set off the
party.

It was amazing to hear the types of early reactions to last year's
Mobb Deep hit song 'Got It Twisted'.  First, many younger folks had no
idea that they had sampled the main riff that gave the song its entire
flavor from Dolby's 'Blinded Me with Science'.  When it was revealed,
the reaction ranged from 'Who in the heck is Thomas Dolby'?  to 'Wow,
Mobb Deep is so adventurous, groundbreaking and experimental for going
there and sampling a rock act.  For some the Thomas Dolby connection
was strange for others who fondly remember those early days, what Mobb
Deep did was a natural fit.  More importantly we need to remember that
it was Thomas Dolby who actually stepped up and produced Whodini's
first record 'Magic Wand'.

In fact we need to also shout out folks like Trevor Horn and Rick
Rubin who stepped over from the world of New Wave and Punk and got
down on the production tip within Hip Hop.

We also need to keep in mind that these few examples I mentioned are
just around the early Hip Hop scene in New York.  If you go back and
look at what was happening 300 miles away in California you will find
similar exchanges between the early emerging Hip Hop community and the
new wave punk sects.  In places like Los Angeles where racial
segregation is more pronounced and ethnic groups are really removed
from one another, to see the early Ska and punk scenes make their way
to early Hip Hop clubs and eventually see it reflected in the music
with folks coming from places like South central is significant.  If
anyone remembers back in the days when KDAY was jumping off in LA,
then you know it was not usual to hear a Thompson Twins song or a
Clash song being mixed and cut up by the famed Mixmasters at that
time.  It was not out of place to go to an Uncle Jamm's Army set at
the old Coliseum and here some of those aforementioned new wave
groups.  And of course Hip Hop was not out of place in those New Wave
Punk clubs.

Today in the age of music industry consolidation and corporate radio
owning multiple stations in a market has resulted in what is best
described as music segregation.  Industry proponents would argue and
say its niche marketing, but really it isn't.  You have a group of
'experts' who sit around a table and devise elaborate marketing plans
which run along the lines of station X owned by company A will go
after Latino women 18-34 and will play a particular style of music
with very little room for deviation.  Station Y, also owned by that
same company will go after older white men 25-54 and will also embrace
a particular music genre.

This process goes all the way down the line until there are no more
stations for the company to play with.  The end results are a series
of unintended consequences, some of which I touched upon in a previous
column where I asked 'When is Old School Too Old to Play' as well as
what I would call increased music segregation.  Sure we can look at
recent examples like Fred Durst and Limp Bizkit doing songs with
Method Man or the upcoming Coachella Music Festival or a Warp Tour
where there will be a healthy dose of rock and rap acts.  However, the
cultural exchange seems to be very one sided at best and contrived and
forced at worse.

It's one sided in the sense that you have rock oriented outlets with a
predominantly white audience embracing Hip Hop.  Yes, you can tune
into a radio station like KROQ and hear rap alongside the usual rock
offerings and lastly we have all the mash up projects, with the most
noticeable being Collision Course with Linkin Park and Jay-Z.
However, you will not see similar attempts in many urban outlets that
target African American audiences.  Yes believe it or not groups like
Linkin Park as popular as they are are still relatively unknown in
many Black circles where BET and commercial radio are the main
conduits to things outside the community.  I'm not sure what needs to
be done to change that or if it even needs to be changed.

I guess I just yearn for the days when the Hip Hop and Punk and New
Wave communities were known to each other and me, a Black kid from the
Boogie Down Bronx, mentioning I like Siouxsie & the Banshees or the
Split Endz is not met with shock and surprise because I defy a
stereotype but with approvals or moans because everyone in the room
has strong opinions about my choice of groups.

Something to Ponder Over...
by Davey D
mrdaveyd@aol.com

-- 


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all 
the money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody 
else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into 
experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to 
the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are 
alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> the reaction ranged from 'Who in the heck is Thomas Dolby'? 
> to 'Wow,
> Mobb Deep is so adventurous, groundbreaking and experimental
> for going
> there and sampling a rock act.  For some the Thomas Dolby
> connection
> was strange for others who fondly remember those early days,
> what Mobb
> Deep did was a natural fit.  More importantly we need to
> remember that
> it was Thomas Dolby who actually stepped up and produced
> Whodini's
> first record 'Magic Wand'.
> 
> In fact we need to also shout out folks like Trevor Horn and
> Rick
> Rubin who stepped over from the world of New Wave and Punk
> and got
> down on the production tip within Hip Hop.
> 
> We also need to keep in mind that these few examples I
> mentioned are
> just around the early Hip Hop scene in New York.  If you go
> back and
> look at what was happening 300 miles away in California you
> will find
> similar exchanges between the early emerging Hip Hop
> community and the
> new wave punk sects.  In places like Los Angeles where racial
> segregation is more pronounced and ethnic groups are really
> removed
> from one another, to see the early Ska and punk scenes make
> their way
> to early Hip Hop clubs and eventually see it reflected in the
> music
> with folks coming from places like South central is
> significant.  If
> anyone remembers back in the days when KDAY was jumping off
> in LA,
> then you know it was not usual to hear a Thompson Twins song
> or a
> Clash song being mixed and cut up by the famed Mixmasters at
> that
> time.  It was not out of place to go to an Uncle Jamm's Army
> set at
> the old Coliseum and here some of those aforementioned new
> wave
> groups.  And of course Hip Hop was not out of place in those
> New Wave
> Punk clubs.
> 
> Today in the age of music industry consolidation and
> corporate radio
> owning multiple stations in a market has resulted in what is
> best
> described as music segregation.  Industry proponents would
> argue and
> say its niche marketing, but really it isn't.  You have a
> group of
> 'experts' who sit around a table and devise elaborate
> marketing plans
> which run along the lines of station X owned by company A
> will go
> after Latino women 18-34 and will play a particular style of
> music
> with very little room for deviation.  Station Y, also owned
> by that
> same company will go after older white men 25-54 and will
> also embrace
> a particular music genre.
> 
> This process goes all the way down the line until there are
> no more
> stations for the company to play with.  The end results are a
> series
> of unintended consequences, some of which I touched upon in a
> previous
> column where I asked 'When is Old School Too Old to Play' as
> well as
> what I would call increased music segregation.  Sure we can
> look at
> recent examples like Fred Durst and Limp Bizkit doing songs
> with
> Method Man or the upcoming Coachella Music Festival or a Warp
> Tour
> where there will be a healthy dose of rock and rap acts. 
> However, the
> cultural exchange seems to be very one sided at best and
> contrived and
> forced at worse.
> 
> It's one sided in the sense that you have rock oriented
> outlets with a
> predominantly white audience embracing Hip Hop.  Yes, you can
> tune
> into a radio station like KROQ and hear rap alongside the
> usual rock
> offerings and lastly we have all the mash up projects, with
> the most
> noticeable being Collision Course with Linkin Park and Jay-Z.
> However, you will not see similar attempts in many urban
> outlets that
> target African American audiences.  Yes believe it or not
> groups like
> Linkin Park as popular as they are are still relatively
> unknown in
> many Black circles where BET and commercial radio are the
> main
> conduits to things outside the community.  I'm not sure what
> needs to
> be done to change that or if it even needs to be changed.
> 
> I guess I just yearn for the days when the Hip Hop and Punk
> and New
> Wave communities were known to each other and me, a Black kid
> from the
> Boogie Down Bronx, mentioning I like Siouxsie & the Banshees
> or the
> Split Endz is not met with shock and surprise because I defy
> a
> stereotype but with approvals or moans because everyone in
> the room
> has strong opinions about my choice of groups.
> 
> Something to Ponder Over...
> by Davey D
> mrdaveyd@aol.com
> 
> -- 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>                  
> House Music 101: 
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen
> with all 
> the money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing
> anybody 
> else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
> 
> "Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into 
> experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation"
> belongs to 
> the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while
> you are 
> alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
> -Kabir
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are
> ahead of 
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> 
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> 
> 
> 
>
---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] Turn down the bass, I can't land this fucker

http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=29&art_id=qw1115096583506B216&set_id=1

British police have moved to swiftly shut down a pirate radio station
after pilots complained that thumping dance music was drowning out
instructions from air traffic controllers as they landed at a nearby
airport, a report said on Tuesday.

Pilots landing passenger jets at Birmingham airport in central England
reported hearing loud bursts of "garage", a cutting-edged form of
dance music characterised by frantic beats and prominent, repetitive
baselines.

Subject: [sfraves] Xara Dulzura (was Re: [sfraves] raving in southern cal / candie kids
 alive and kicking)

By the way, in addition to the Xara pictures URL I posted below, I also
found some other excellent sites (with pix's of me in them!)

These are really nice:
http://www.pixievisionproductions.com/gallery/xara2005

More crazyness to come this friday... cirqueberzerk.com

Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> Southern cali is alive and thriving. I was at Xara Dulzura the weekend 
> before last. I had fun laptop DJing at the Xaruba Cafe where I setup a 
> small soundsystem. A highlight for me was segueing from me DJing with 
> live drummers, to the drummers taking over, and me beat matching to them 
> (or attempting to). It erupted into a cool live looping of afro-house 
> drum-beats in a jam session with a bunch of drummers, mandolin, and sax 
> player. People got some serious dancing going on. Met cool people. Even 
> got some very inspiring positive feedback online and on tribe.
> 
> Heard and met great DJ's including LA's Wolfie and San Diego's 
> Jack-Tripper.
> Mutaytor (see mutaytor.com) put on an a massive live show. I was well 
> blown away.
> 
> All in all, I actually find what little I've seen of the so-cal scene to 
> be more "plurry" without being pretentious about being so. Then again, I 
> am way way sick of the bay area and most of the people there (NOT YOU OF 
> COURSE!!) so this may
> have something to do with it. :-/ It's nice to see a fresh place, look upon
> things with fresh eyes, and see beautiful valleys, mountains, people, 
> art and
> music. There was even a passover seder, where at the end, two crazily 
> face-painted, beautiful stiltwalkers came up on the circle and said 
> "we're passing over!" then gave a big cheer to the woman leading the 
> seder, Athena. The whole experience  was amazing. Best passover seder 
> I've been to. Nice communal food sharing all weekend.
> 
> http://www.podcollective.com/fora/viewtopic.php?p=4571#4571
> 
> As you can see from the pix above, there were no candy kids whatsoever 
> (I'm in the collection above twice, and I'm far too old to be candy).
> Candy is for the unimaginative. This event just had lots of people in
> costumes.  There's a difference. Candy kids are kids. Fortunately, I didn't
> feel particularly geriatric at Xara.
> 
> It felt kinda  like a weekend campout party at Camp & Sons, but with 
> more people, more stages, more audience participation, and more live music.
> 
> -- Niels.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Come down to Folded tonight!!

live-instrument-ladled house action at Folded tonight.  Not only do we
have Matt Craske, recent SF transplant and head of Offset Music, (one
very fine house label!) the inimitable Andrew Phelan and I:van on the
decks, we've got DJF playing live sax and, er, origami on the
bass-o-mo-phone as always.

Come get crazy, drink some vodka drinks on the cheap (show up early),
get loose, and free your funky caboose (all night long)!

---

Folded @ Anu (43 Sixth St. @ Market, SF)

Friday, May 6th, 10PM - 2AM

*No Cover* as always

----

Featuring:

Matt Craske (Offset Music)

DJ F on live saxamaphone (breakshopstudios)

With Residents:

Origami & Andrew Phelan (newstylesound, so sound, turnaround-sound,
olive)

i-van (monterey bay)

Premium vodka promotion with discount vouchers from 10-12.

The housemates are comprised of a married couple, a gentleman, a dog, as well as 3 children on occasion. We've had 2 males in the bedroom before, so we're seeking a female to balance out the energy in the house. Two of us are house music dj's/producers so count on music and a party on occasion. This is a very creative and spiritual household. We vibe off each other, we sing, we dance, we create music and art and enjoy life to the fullest while raising our children to be better than ourselves.
 
The house has beautiful hardwood floors and nice backyard. We have wireless dsl. Laundry facilities are at your disposal, our kitchen is your kitchen, and the family entertainment room is well stocked with a 65" TV for movies/video games (no cable!), surround sound, and ps2. Decently appointed kitchen features 100 gallon fish tank. You would also have storage places in the garage. We are centrally located between 101 and 280 close to caltrain.

No cigarette smoking in the house but we do have a designated smoking lounge/laundry room (the garage). 

$500/month plus 1/4 of utilities (pg&e,water,phone/dsl). 


Available now. 
Located in Sunnyvale, Ca near Lawrence and El Camino
Sorry, no more pets and must be over 21.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  School board bans band from performing 'Louie Louie'

--=====================_2235013==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



School board bans band from performing 'Louie Louie'

May 5, 2005, 7:21 AM

BENTON HARBOR, Mich. (AP) -- A pop culture controversy that has simmered 
for decades came to a head when a middle school marching band was told not 
to perform "Louie Louie."

Benton Harbor Superintendent Paula Dawning cited the song's allegedly 
raunchy lyrics in ordering the McCord Middle School band not to perform it 
in Saturday's Grand Floral Parade, held as part of the Blossomtime Festival.

In a letter sent home with McCord students, Dawning said "Louie Louie" was 
not appropriate for Benton Harbor students to play while representing the 
district -- even though the marching band wasn't going to sing it.

Band members and parents complained to the Board of Education at its 
Tuesday meeting that it was too late to learn another song, The 
Herald-Palladium of St. Joseph reported.

"It's very stressful for us to try to come up with new songs for the band," 
eighth-grader Laurice Martin told the board. "We're trying to learn the 
songs from last year, but some of us weren't in the band last year."

Dawning said that if a majority of parents supports their children playing 
the song, she will reconsider her decision.

"It was not that I knew at the beginning and said nothing," Dawning said. 
"I normally count on the staff to make reliable decisions. I found out 
because a parent called, concerned about the song being played."

"Louie Louie," written by Richard Berry in 1956, is one of the most 
recorded songs in history. The best-known, most notorious version was a hit 
in 1963 for the Kingsmen; the FBI spent two years investigating the lyrics 
before declaring they not only were not obscene but also were 
"unintelligible at any speed."

------

The Louie Louie Pages: http://www.xs4all.nl/ 7/8tdg/louie1.html

Louie Louie.net: http://www.louielouie.net/

Subject: [sfraves] Antipiracy Rule for Broadcasts Is Struck Down

--=====================_753443==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Antipiracy Rule for Broadcasts Is Struck Down
By STEPHEN LABATON

WASHINGTON, May 6 - A federal appeals court handed a major setback to
Hollywood and the television networks on Friday when it struck down an
antipiracy regulation requiring computer and television makers to use
new technology that would make it difficult for consumers to copy and
distribute digital programs.

The unanimous ruling by the three-judge panel, in an important case at
the intersection of intellectual property and technology, was a
stinging rebuke for the Federal Communications Commission. The court
said the commission exceeded its authority when it approved the rules
in 2003.

It was a significant victory for libraries, consumer groups and civil
liberties organizations. They had maintained that the regulation, known
as the broadcast flag rule, would stifle innovation in technology and
make it more difficult for consumers and users of library services to
circulate material legitimately.

Although an appeal is possible, lawyers involved in the case said the
fight would shift in the near term to Congress, which is already
weighing legislation. Hollywood executives and their lobbyists warned
that if the rule was not resurrected by Congress, studios and
broadcasters would sharply limit the digital programming available over
the airwaves, focusing instead on channels limited to cable and
satellite services, where they have other means to control what can be
copied.

The Supreme Court is expected to issue a ruling soon in another closely
watched case involving digital rights and intellectual property,
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios v. Grokster Ltd. In that case, the court is
considering whether the online services that enable copyright songs and
movies to be shared freely over the Internet can be held liable
themselves for copyright infringement.

The rule at issue in Friday's decision would have required
manufacturers to install special technology in new computers and
televisions that would enable them to recognize a "broadcast flag" -
specially embedded computer bits in the programs created by the studios
and the networks. The new equipment would then restrict redistribution
and reuse of the programs.

For years, the movie studios and television networks urged the
commission to adopt the rule, citing the recording industry's
experience with companies like Napster and saying restrictions on
copying and distributing programs by consumers were essential to the
transition from analog to digital television. They maintained that
without the imposition of the broadcast flag, shows would be copied and
then transmitted limitlessly through the Internet, much the way music
is.

But the critics said that the studios and networks were unduly alarmist
and that the new rule, which was to have taken effect July 1, would
prevent consumers from copying and using programs for legitimate
reasons.

Research librarians submitted affidavits in the case contending that
the broadcast flag rule would make it impossible to distribute
broadcast clips and other research material over the Internet to
researchers and students.

Critics also maintained that the commission had overreached and had
moved to regulate the Internet more tightly, ridiculing the agency in
the aftermath of the rulemaking as the "federal computer commission."

The rule was challenged from the moment it was issued in November 2003.
The case was filed last year in the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia, the usual venue for challenging commission
rules.

The outcome of the case was signaled during oral arguments in February,
when the judges aggressively questioned F.C.C. lawyers about whether
the agency had exceeded its authority by setting technical standards
having nothing directly to do with broadcasting transmissions.

"You've gone too far," said Judge Harry T. Edwards during the oral
arguments, as he pressed a government lawyer to justify how the agency
could possibly set standards governing computers and the Internet. "Are
washing machines next?"

But the breadth of Judge Edwards's opinion was more than many lawyers
had expected.

"In this case, all relevant materials concerning the F.C.C.'s
jurisdiction - including the words of the Communications Act of 1934,
its legislative history, subsequent legislation, relevant case law, and
commission practice - confirm that the F.C.C. has no authority to
regulate consumer electronic devices that can be used for receipt of
wire or radio communication when those devices are not engaged in the
process of radio or wire transmission," Judge Edwards wrote.

"And the agency's strained and implausible interpretations of the
definitional provisions of the Communications Act of 1934 do not lend
credence to its position. As the Supreme Court has reminded us,
Congress 'does not ... hide elephants in mouse holes.' "His opinion, in
American Library Association v. Federal Communications Commission, was
joined by Judges David B. Sentelle and Judith W. Rogers.

David Fiske, the commission's top spokesman, said that the agency did
not have a comment about the decision and that the government had not
decided whether it would seek an appeal either to the full Court of
Appeals or to the Supreme Court. Some lawyers said it was unlikely that
the Supreme Court would consider the matter as the case did not satisfy
the criteria for such review.

The broadcast flag rule was adopted at the urging of Michael K. Powell
when he was commission chairman. It was supported by Kevin J. Martin, a
commissioner at the time who became chairman this year.

In recent weeks each side in the lawsuit has been talking to lawmakers
in anticipation of the ruling.

"Without a broadcast flag, consumers may lose access to the very best
programming offered on local television," said Edward O. Fritts,
chairman and chief executive of the National Association of
Broadcasters. "This remedy is designed to protect against unauthorized
indiscriminate redistribution of programming over the Internet."

Dan Glickman, president of the Motion Picture Association of America,
offered similar warnings. "If the broadcast flag cannot be used,
program providers will have to weigh whether the risk of theft is too
great over free, off-air broadcasting and could limit such high-quality
programming to only cable, satellite and other more secure delivery
systems," he said. "It is important to remember that this decision is
only about the F.C.C.'s jurisdiction, not the merits of the broadcast
flag itself."

But Gigi B. Sohn, president of Public Knowledge, a digital rights
advocacy group that led the fight against the broadcast flag rule,
warned that intervention by Congress could create a new set of problems
for consumers and innovators.

"If Congress starts to go down the road of giving the F.C.C. broad
power over new applications and technologies, who knows what comes
next?" Ms. Sohn said. "This case is about the future of technology."

Government officials and industry executives report that digital
television has slowly been gaining in popularity. Nearly 1,500
stations, or about 90 percent of the total, now broadcast some digital
programs. Industry executives project sales this year of about 15
million television sets able to receive digital programs, about half of
all sets sold. Indeed, some sets already being sold are equipped for a
broadcast flag.

Cable televisions now have the ability to sell digital programs to as
many as 90 million homes, and about 300 hours of digital programming is
available each day in many markets.

http://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/07/technology/07tele.html

Subject: RE: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

i think that's his house.  i'd totally understand if that was
the case, because i wouldn't want flyering to be done at my
house for one of my parties.  you'd find flyers all over the
place for months afterward.

i used to promote as well, but i never understood why
club/parties would let me in for free.  i suppose it was "club
courtesy", as the club or party i was promoting for would let
them in for free to promote their event.  but it seemed funny -
let someone in to litter up their venue, for free.

by the way, $15 is pretty pricey for a UG, IMHO.  i'd have just
done the cars outside.

m

Subject: RE: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

it's an underground venue and I wouldn't want them to get in trouble for 
flyers on cars or outside.  I didn't know it was his house and I think it's 
a bit crazy to charge fifteen bucks at 2am for all local talent when there 
are only two hours left in the party.  We actually weren't there to party in 
the first place; we came from the city to drop off some flyers, shake some 
hands, and promote a couple of up coming events.  If he didn't want flyers 
in, he could have at least been polite about it.  He came from a rather 
harsh angle and basically told us to piss off.  I believe the reason most 
people let you into their parties to promote is to keep the cycle of parties 
and promotion active.  If you let promoters in and they spread the word 
about up coming events, it's more likely that events are going to do well 
and it perpetuates a more active scene.  Maybe I was bit harsh in my first 
post saying he was a dick, but I can't think of a better way to describe his 
attitude.  On another note, we've never had a problem coming into the venue 
before to promote, so it seemed a little odd and out of place that we were 
turned away at the door.  In any case, water under the bridge as far as I'm 
concerned.
Eat Fresh,
Joey Frisco

Subject: [sfraves] Tiesto offering truly tedious

--=====================_45867574==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Tiesto offering truly tedious

By YURI WUENSCH, SPECIAL TO THE EDMONTON SUN

Last year, I missed my window of opportunity to critically lambaste 
Tiesto's In Concert DVD (out now on Blackhole Recordings), a deplorable 
display of unchecked ego and poor filmmaking. However, thanks to In Concert 
2, a virtual copycat of the first, my vitriol for the world's No. 1 DJ has 
an outlet.

The world of electronic dance is, inexplicably and to the best of my 
knowledge, the only genre of music to boast annual polls to determine which 
DJ is No. 1. For the last few years, Tiesto has been tops, the reigning 
king of trance and, in turn, the dance world. It's hard to dismiss trance's 
popularity - the 70,000 people that turned up for Tiesto's shows in Arnhem, 
Holland, and Hasselt, Belgium, last fall testify to it.

Tiesto also has the distinction of being the first and only DJ to have ever 
played the opening ceremonies of the Olympics.

You know this after watching In Concert 2 because, not unlike the first 
DVD, the house announcer tells the audience so, along with facts about 
Tiesto's mind-boggling record sales and other bits of egomania.

The In Concert 2 show sees Tiesto employing an elevated UFO-like stage, the 
same one used in the first concert DVD. As a visual element, it's an 
admittedly inspiring piece of hardware complemented by pyrotechnics and 
intricate light displays.

But as high up as Tiesto is on that pedestal, he's that much further 
removed from his audience. In his defence, it's probably something of an 
occupational hazard. To accommodate such a large crowd, certain performance 
concessions likely had to be made.

Still, it's hard not to see what's lost as a result. Good DJs will read and 
respond to the crowd, the interplay between the two being integral to 
dance's dynamics. But In Concert 2 is just Tiesto as deified spectacle 
rather than audience co-conspirator.

At larger rave-styled events, the crowd often becomes the show, anyway. The 
best parties boast costumed characters and a colour parade that is all but 
ignored on In Concert 2.

The camera never strays far from Tiesto, only briefly interspersing shots 
of the crowd or the occasional buxom European lass as an afterthought. No 
matter how many camera angles you employ, a grinning Dutchman behind the 
decks will get old real fast.

The direction of the concert is equally tedious, a hodgepodge of jump cuts, 
bad edits and flash over substance. There's never a correlation between 
what's happening musically and how the video plays out.

The lack of continuity is compounded by the preponderance of stock shots - 
I think I saw the same hands pointing skyward a dozen times. If the imagery 
had been synced to the beats, it might have been more tolerable. As it 
wasn't, I found myself simply listening to In Concert 2 because watching it 
gave me a headache.

I was more impressed with Tiesto's skills as a DJ on this particular 
outing, but only marginally so. Produced in Dolby 5.1, the music is crisp 
and clean and you can actually hear him working the mix, or at least 
attempting to. I don't mind hearing a DJ struggle with a mix if only 
because it at least shows they're trying. However, when you bring the mix 
full-stop, as Tiesto does on a couple of occasions, it's either because of 
a complete lack of technical ability, showboating or both.

Even with the mix's inconsistencies, there are still some killer pumping 
trance tracks. In particular, the three Tiesto tunes remixed by DJ Montana 
are monsters, especially Breda 8pm.

When trance doesn't fall prey to a patterned structure of big peaks and 
teetering breakdowns, instead keeping things punchy and rolling, the appeal 
is undeniable. However, Tiesto unerringly gives the beats breathers and 
those lulls stymie the mix's flow.

There are also some live vocal performances mixed in as part of the show, 
featuring Matt Hales from Aqualung and a large choir-like ensemble of girls 
known as the Children of Orpheus. They're decent enough, though the way 
they're presented had me thinking less trance and more Lord of the Dance.

While I obviously have no love for either the first or second concert DVDs, 
I do honestly hold hope for a third. Or maybe you just had to be there. 
Still, I do think the potential is there for DVDs like this to be done better.

http://www.canoe.ca/NewsStand/EdmontonSun/Entertainment/2005/05/07/pf-1029787.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_45867574==.ALT--
