	 <BAY101-F2740666DE9B8CCA7EEA819B41D0@phx.gbl>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

#1 - I live in that warehouse.  Flyers were never a problem at our
first few events there.  However, the last 2 parties it has gotten a
lot worse.  The flyering issue has come up on this mailing list before
and has/is talked about by many promoters.  It's just not cool to have
to cleanup peoples' flyers, period.

#2 - Modified has only printed one flyer.  That flyer was put out
almost two years ago.

#3 - I very rarely get into parties for free unless I am doing sound,
helping to setup/cleanup, or DJing.  I make it a point to pay other
events I go to.  Perhaps if promoters set a standard by paying to get
into all the events they show up to in order to "drop off some flyers,
shake some hands, and promote a couple of up coming events" it would
help the scene "to keep the cycle of parties and promotion active."

#4 - Modified events on average, pull about 100-150 people right now @
my place.  New Years was the only party we would have walked away with
more then a couple hundred bucks in our pockets.  What happened at New
Years?  We gave out full refunds at the door as the PD kicked everyone
out.  How often does that happen?  How big of a dick does that make
me?
=09Myself and a couple of others have been barely breaking even or
sometimes taking losses since Modified started.  It was our hope we
could build a name and earn peoples trust in order to do something
other then renegades.
=09How much do you think rent is on a warehouse?  Lets do some quick
math.  We had roughly 120 paying people Friday night.  That's $1800 @
the door.  By the time you minus rent, decor (we watered down and
repainted over half of the space), new lighting, patrolled parking and
all those last minute stupid things you never think about (zip ties,
string, broken/stolen needles, etc.) maybe you can understand the $15
cost.  Perhaps we should lower ticket price and pack 500 people in
there?
=09Those first few $3-$5 parties we did set a standard.  A standard that
just isn't financially viable outside of what we were doing before.=20
Let's face reality - it takes money to throw parties.  If people want
a place to party where they aren't going to be hassled like they are
at other spaces, aren't going to be packed like cattle into the venue,
and can generally expect a good time, then they have to be willing to
pay a cover that will at least pay for the party.

#5  We don't search (maybe we should start) - people get flyers in
sometimes.  When they do, they are asked to put them away.

Joey -  I apologize if I came off as an asshole.  I did not intend to.
 Parties are a bit stressful for promoters last time a checked.  if it
really was such a big deal to you, I invite you and the other two
other people I am assuming also wanted to get in  - free of charge -
to come to my next show and flyer for your event.  All I ask is that
you stay after to clean up.

element
modified productions

On Sun, 8 May 2005 mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com wrote:
-&e->Thanks to everyone who came down on Friday, it was our best night in quite
-&e->a while, lots of dancing and smiles and familiar faces.  :)
-&e->
-&e->I found out after the fact that there was a problem with the drink
-&e->promotion (they gave out crappy mixed drink shots instead of vouchers and
-&e->left early on top of that), sorry to anyone that came down for cheap vodka
-&e->and got stuck with the regular price, hit me up next month and I'll buy
-&e->you a drink.

a. no hard feelings.  i got a smirnoff uber deluxe illuminated coke 
mirror.  not that i touch the stuff (coke*, I do touch smirnoff).  but 
it's the most fabulously 70s thing i have ever seen.  and the fizzy cheap 
little shot things were fine.  small, and fizzy.  i actually ran into one 
of the major SFLoveParade planners who was there with her parents, and she 
talked her non-drinking mom into having one (the fizzy little shot, not 
the coke mirror)... so there's an upside.

b. that bartender wants to kill me.  he can sense when I've decided to buy 
my last drink, and insists on buying me one a few minutes later.  funny 
guy.  what was that, a red headed slut?

c. while i'm not a huge fan of sax + keys + house (spending time in san 
jose, you get 6000% your USRDA of that stuff at the hands of one Harry Who 
:P) but that was some cool shit to see go down live.

d. george was having so much fun he didn't get to pee.  which is all good 
except that means i didn't get to play bass (as NewStyleSound LLC's second 
string bassist).

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

Well, honestly... if you would have ever come to one of our (DTS) events, 
and wanted to promote an upcoming party, we would have shaken your hand and 
invited you (and usually one other promoter per party) into the space to do 
your thing (we had three people for two parties).  It's just the edicate and 
respect we show for other crews and promoters that are trying to throw 
parties and do positive things for the scene.  A lot of other crews that I 
am indirectly involved with have the same two promoter or promoter +1 
policy.  It actually seems to be the standard, especially with the crews 
that post on bayraves, evolic, dts, hcftp, etc...  I understand that you are 
trying to do something different without posting on some of these resources, 
but I don't understand that you don't show the same respect and courtesy to 
others that they would show to you or any other crew trying to come up and 
do right.  Especially after we talked to you at the door and explained that 
you were welcome to promote at our parties and informed you that we only 
wanted to walk through.  It seemed like you were basically telling us that 
you didn't give a fuck about anyone other than your crew and how you did 
that night.  It came across like this, "I don't want to clean up your 
flyers; I don't pass flyers out at your party; why should I help you promote 
your party or perpetuate the scene if I don't print flyers and hand them out 
at your parties; you're here and there are two hours left in the party, so, 
I'm gonna charge you as much as I can even though I know that you're only 
gonna be here for a few minutes; actually, in the end guys, go fuck 
yourselves because I don't care about anyone other than modified 
productions."  It just sucks when people monkey wrench instead of oil the 
metaphorical rave machine.  It really doesn't benefit anyone to be a an 
asshole, if you were that stressed about money for your party, you should 
have said so instead of coming across like the nazi supervisor of the food 
line at a concentration camp.  In anycase, no hard feelings really, I just 
think that it was a shitty decision on your part and that you were a dick 
for whatever reason (evidently you don't think that you should help other 
crews out).  Like I said in my last post, it's all water under the bridge to 
me.  Best of luck in future endeavors.
Cordially,
-Joey Frisco

PS-
>"come to my next show and flyer for your event.  All I ask is that
>you stay after to clean up."
considered and noted for future reference.
-JF




>From: element <modifiedproductions@gmail.com>
>Reply-To: element@modifiedproductions.com
>To: Joey Frisco <josephwhunt@hotmail.com>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!
>Date: Sun, 8 May 2005 16:31:05 -0700
>
>#1 - I live in that warehouse.  Flyers were never a problem at our
>first few events there.  However, the last 2 parties it has gotten a
>lot worse.  The flyering issue has come up on this mailing list before
>and has/is talked about by many promoters.  It's just not cool to have
>to cleanup peoples' flyers, period.
>
>#2 - Modified has only printed one flyer.  That flyer was put out
>almost two years ago.
>
>#3 - I very rarely get into parties for free unless I am doing sound,
>helping to setup/cleanup, or DJing.  I make it a point to pay other
>events I go to.  Perhaps if promoters set a standard by paying to get
>into all the events they show up to in order to "drop off some flyers,
>shake some hands, and promote a couple of up coming events" it would
>help the scene "to keep the cycle of parties and promotion active."
>
>#4 - Modified events on average, pull about 100-150 people right now @
>my place.  New Years was the only party we would have walked away with
>more then a couple hundred bucks in our pockets.  What happened at New
>Years?  We gave out full refunds at the door as the PD kicked everyone
>out.  How often does that happen?  How big of a dick does that make
>me?
>	Myself and a couple of others have been barely breaking even or
>sometimes taking losses since Modified started.  It was our hope we
>could build a name and earn peoples trust in order to do something
>other then renegades.
>	How much do you think rent is on a warehouse?  Lets do some quick
>math.  We had roughly 120 paying people Friday night.  That's $1800 @
>the door.  By the time you minus rent, decor (we watered down and
>repainted over half of the space), new lighting, patrolled parking and
>all those last minute stupid things you never think about (zip ties,
>string, broken/stolen needles, etc.) maybe you can understand the $15
>cost.  Perhaps we should lower ticket price and pack 500 people in
>there?
>	Those first few $3-$5 parties we did set a standard.  A standard that
>just isn't financially viable outside of what we were doing before.
>Let's face reality - it takes money to throw parties.  If people want
>a place to party where they aren't going to be hassled like they are
>at other spaces, aren't going to be packed like cattle into the venue,
>and can generally expect a good time, then they have to be willing to
>pay a cover that will at least pay for the party.
>
>#5  We don't search (maybe we should start) - people get flyers in
>sometimes.  When they do, they are asked to put them away.
>
>Joey -  I apologize if I came off as an asshole.  I did not intend to.
>  Parties are a bit stressful for promoters last time a checked.  if it
>really was such a big deal to you, I invite you and the other two
>other people I am assuming also wanted to get in  - free of charge -
>to come to my next show and flyer for your event.  All I ask is that
>you stay after to clean up.
>
>element
>modified productions
>

Subject: [sfraves] Saturday Night Adventure!!

The night started out pretty mellow... I wasn't really planning on doing
more than mellow really (well.. mellow IMO.. Hello 2day)

I mean.. ok.. so like it was a small lil' thingie @ GregJ's pad & ooh.. so
fun!!  Then... well.. I was suppose 2 go 2 Reverb @ Sno Drift 'cause i was
like GL & stuff & I wanted 2 C some Homies I ain't seenin a while... but
ummm.. lol.. didn't make it there unfortunately... Sorry B.. reallly
wanted 2 hang w/ U Homie! =\

Instead.. a crew of us wented to the ummm Taurus (sp) party in SOMA 'cause
there was this GL thing that we were on or soemthing... unfortunately..
that didn't pan out either 'cause by the time we got there.. it was max
capcity.... Oh Well... la la la la la la la...

Fortunately... Anu was right down the alley way from the Taurus shindig &
well.. although I been hella wanting 2 say HI 2 all the people who were @
the Art Gallery like Ripple, Wish, or like Odeed who i ain't seen or talk
2 in a while... my home 4 the night was Anu.. WOW... YAY.. Hello 2day...
saw like sooo many of my Jungle Fam there & I was soooo fuckin' Happy &
felt soo much Love there, honestly... it was So Dope!  LoL.. 1st person I
ran in2 was long lost just moved back 2 Cali from Hicksville 1 of my Fave
Jungle DJs & my DNB Big Bro Kryptyk =)  YAY!!  Awesome.. we caught up,
talked.. then some1 started like 2 pretend strangle my neck from behind..
YAY!!!  It was MC Child!!  So Dope!

Ummmmmm.. Method ONe was on the decks & was spinning "the History of DNB"
& I guess when i got there.. he was around the 97-98 era of Jungle...
LoL.. yeah.. I'm so bullshitting my ass off right now like i know what i'm
talkin' about.. but yeah man.. that set was fuckin' SICK!!!  I Loved it!! 
MC DUH was n the Mic switching off w/ Child.. LoL.. it was Dope!!  I
mean.. the crowd was Sick & feelin' it & yeah... I guess U can say the set
was totally anthematic (if that's a word).. o h Gosh man... it was So
Dope!  Then.. @ the end of his set.. he busted out fuckin' New Order..
LOL.. in honor of Coachella...

OK.. but that wasn't it.. I mean.. I was on a quest 2 eventually get a
ride hime... that didn't pan out... so a bunch of us from Anu decided 2
check out this Rave in Potrero Hills & well.. it was kinda eeeh.... like
it felt like a bunch of clubbers 2gehter in a basement & I dunno.. i
didn't really get a Ravey kinda vibe.. but none the less.. it was a Sick
lil Undergounrd!!  I had so much fun!!!  Wow!!  LoL.. I even had a 8 foot
long snake wrapped around me @ 1 point during the party.. LOLOLMAO..

Hope y'all had a Groovy Weekend! =)


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] DJ Spooky Raps About Remixing 

--=====================_15509751==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


DJ Spooky Raps About Remixing

By Katie Dean

Story location: http://www.wired.com/news/digiwood/0,1412,67261,00.html

02:00 AM May. 09, 2005 PT

DJ Spooky relies heavily on sampling in his work as a DJ and musician. So 
it shouldn't be a surprise that his new book and CD sample audio recordings 
of some of literature's great remixers: writers whose work "sampled" other 
people's material.

DJ Spooky, whose real name is Paul D. Miller, is an artist, musician and 
writer at the forefront of using technology to remix art and culture.

Now, he's sharing his ideas about art, music, sampling and remixing in his 
first book, Rhythm Science. The book comes with a CD of tracks that mixes 
music with literary works by the likes of James Joyce and Gertrude Stein.

Creative Commons guru Lawrence Lessig calls the book "the story of how 
freedom would build better science and art."

In addition to his writing, Miller has a new album out this spring with 
rapper Chuck D and Slayer drummer Dave Lombardo.

He's also been an advocate for peer-to-peer software, filing an amicus 
brief in the landmark MGM Studios v. Grokster case, because he believes 
peer-to-peer can be used to foster collaboration between artists. It also 
leads to greater creativity by exposing listeners to a diverse mix of music.

Miller stopped by the Wired News office for a chat about his book, his new 
album and his thoughts on sampling culture and copyright.

Wired News: Why did you decide to write a book? What message do you want to 
convey?

Paul D. Miller: I think so many issues right now around sampling and 
digital media in general are kind of at a crossroads.... I was fascinated 
with these issues, but at the same time I felt that there hadn't been a 
book by a DJ about the whole DJ process. It's not just playing records ... 
it's about record players, crowds (and) social environments. So the book 
was a snapshot of that -- a screensaver so to speak -- of how you can have 
this kind of technologically conditioned social culture. And as a 
practicing artist I realized there hadn't been that many books, in fact 
none, written by other DJs. It's always a critic or something.

WN: Do you ever run into problems with copyright when sampling music?

Miller: I sample all sorts of stuff. The strategy, of course, is to make it 
unrecognizable. That means sampling has to be a kind of shredder -- the 
equivalent of when you throw away your credit card bill and put it through. 
I throw away certain recorded sounds and shred them so they are 
unrecognizable in the same way you would trace someone's credit identity. 
They do come after you for both cases.

WN: There was a recent case of NWA using a snippet of George Clinton's 
music, and a court ruled that even though the sample was unrecognizable, 
NWA still had to secure rights to use it.

Miller: That means they didn't change it enough. Basic rule of thumb: ... 
you don't want to get sued.

It's a nightmare. There (are) lawyers. There are websites who filter 
through all records -- everything. People are paid to just listen to music 
at this point and listen for samples....

In the same way a lot of people involved with internet hacking culture will 
hack your site and then call you up and say "By the way, we have security 
services we'd like to offer you," you might get a little phone call saying, 
"There is a sample on your record that we heard, and we'd be more than 
happy to clear it for you." Of course implying that if you don't, the next 
phone call will be to the people you sampled.

It's a paradoxical world. On one hand, sampling is a homage to your 
favorite records and favorite sounds, but you have to pay through the nose 
if you feel like doing that.

So for my current book, Rhythm Science, what I did was find audio companion 
material that was based on writers whose works I really enjoyed: Gertrude 
Stein, James Joyce, Kurt Schwitters, even people like Patti Smith, and then 
remix that in a way that everything was cleared and crisp. It was no problem.

WN: You cleared it legally.

Miller: Yeah.

WN: Why did you choose those readings in particular?

Miller: They were authors whose work I felt reflected a lot of the issues 
with sampling.

Take for example James Joyce. He would take motifs from posters in the city 
streets when he was walking and have a notepad and write them down, and 
they would appear in his book. He would sample stuff from advertising, from 
other authors, from magazine articles.

Or Gertrude Stein, because she had this repetitive style of speaking and 
her writing reflected that; Antonin Artaud, because he was involved with a 
lot of theater scripting.

To me, with hip-hop and electronic music, you are looking at sound as a 
kind of theater, where samples are almost like voices that you can take 
from a script.... Pretty much everybody on (the record) was involved in 
some way, shape or form with creating a critique of literature and how 
stories were told.

WN: Do you think there should be some kind of sampling license?

Miller: Yeah, I think we need to find a good middle ground. I think it's 
slowly evolving. I'm a huge fan of the Creative Commons scene because they 
are giving people some of the tools necessary to get some sanity into the 
system.

WN: There's an argument that sampling isn't really music; music is playing 
an instrument and composing. How do you respond to that?

Miller: (Sampling) is an inheritor of folk culture where a lot of people 
would know the same songs, but each person would make their own version. 
That's what happened with blues, that's what happened with jazz, but those 
were much more refined patterns of folk culture.

But if you look at gypsy music, for example, or Rai music out of the 
northeast part of the Middle East, or India, there are so many different 
traditions that have somehow managed to become part of (the) recording 
process. If you look at Indian classical music, so many records are 
parallel to one another, but that's because they're a folk culture.

And also they didn't have the same kind of copyright laws, so people would 
record different versions of the same thing, no problem, that was part of 
the culture.

But with sampling, it implies a personalization of that. You're not only 
participating in a culture with all your peers and friends -- again 
peer-to-peer networks, that's the pun -- but you're able to make your own 
versions, send that to friends in that part of literally the entire network 
culture that we live in right now.

WN: In addition to the book, you've completed a new album with Chuck D and 
Dave Lombardo from Slayer. Tell us about it.

Miller: The record is called Drums of Death. It's a sense of humor about, 
kind of, heavy metal meets hip-hop.... Right now it seems much more like 
everything has become so compartmentalized. It's sort of the playlist 
mentality where you have this genre like hip-hop, rock.... Everything is 
put in its little genre and that's it.

I want to make a genre that's a blur -- where your iPod is malfunctioning, 
and next thing you know your hip-hop is in the rock section of your 
playlist, and your rock has gone over to your dub section, and your reggae 
section is mixed into your jazz and your classical music is sprinkled over 
everything.

So thinking about that was a kind of a fun way of jumping back in ... like 
getting Chuck D to rhyme more like his old-school style. And the guys from 
Slayer, the drummer Dave Lombardo is amazing, it was really fun working 
with him. That's the only person that was live. I had to fly out to L.A. 
and we recorded him in his garage outside of L.A.

WN: And Chuck D?

Miller: He sent me (the music) files.

WN: What happened with Flava Flav?

Miller: It didn't fit. It wasn't the right project.... He is better for 
reality TV at this point. But again, that's nothing negative, it's just ... 
I felt like I wanted to evoke a certain kind of Public Enemy....

(We used) a classic sort of '70s big synthesizer (vocorder) that you run 
voices through. We ended up making a synthetic voice to replace Flav that 
kind of evoked the same kind of call and response. So Chuck D does his 
thing and instead of going back and forth (with Flava Flav), it goes to the 
computer.

WN: You also downloaded a Muslim prayer to use in "The B-Side Wins Again," 
right? What else have you found online?

Miller: Oh yeah, the call to prayer. That's a scratching on "B-Side Wins 
Again." I just have a hair of it. You can get everything (online) from U.S. 
soldiers rapping -- have you heard about the Baghdad raps?

If you just do a quick Google search, there are people uploading video 
clips of themselves rhyming about being in Baghdad, and there are bombs 
going off. But there are also people making audio recordings of the war and 
putting them online.

At this point in the game you can find all sorts of stuff online. One of my 
favorite websites for experimental music and sound peeps is called UbuWeb, 
and they have MP3s that are also shareware of historical recordings by 
artists too. I try as much as possible to support a lot of different things.

David Cohn contributed to this report.





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
practiced in past centuries ..."
- David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] srr: sound advice - used peavey equipment

No no no no no no no no no no no no

Look at:
EAW
Community
Mackie even
Meyer (haha!)
EV
McCauley
etc

For home monitors, look for some of those Mackie SRMs.. they sound
fine.

I don't much care for JBLs of any stripe, and the EONs everybody's got
even less....  But they're cheap used and I've heard them sound
half-decent before.

But no Peavey.  Peavey actually translates in audioese to: "CRAP!". 
It's sort of a swear word, actually.

"Jesus christ, I just dropped that amp rack on my foot!  PEAVEY!!!"

;)
-GC

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Can anyone help me ID this game?

I know this is totally random, but i was just sitting here at work and this 
image of this game i used to play way back in the day popped into my head 
and i can't for the life of me remember what the name of it was.

I think it was a Sierra game, but i could be wrong it did have similar 
graphics as....say...police quest III which is why i think it might be a 
Sierra game.

Anyway, it was like a life simulation game, where you picked your dude and 
you had some money, and you had to get an apartment, and get a job, and go 
to school and earn a degree and shit like that.  It was like a top down 
kinda view, of a map of the "city" where it had differant places like a 
McDonalds looking place, and a school and you could get a job at mcdonalds 
until you got enough of a education to get a better job.  When you'd go from 
location to location, you'd see a little marble like thing rolling around to 
the next location.

I know this is a weird random memory, but the name of this game is bugging 
the hell out of me.  I've spent nearly an entire day here at work just 
trying to find the name of it, but so far no luck, so i figured i try the 
next best thing.  YOU GUYS!!!

So please someone out there...you have to know what i'm talking about, and 
if so please let me know so i can put my mind at ease.

Buck Murdock
"I've got a fever, and the only prescription is more cowbell!"

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Reid Speed - Saturday, May 21st

DIRTY
Saturday, May 21st
@ the Shadow Lounge
9th and Folsom, SF
FREE b4 10:30 & only $5 after that
9pm-4am
21+

featuring:
Reid Speed (Breakbeat Science) L.A.
- special breaks and electro set

Drum'n'bass and two-step DJ Reid Speed started DJing her senior year
in high school, two years after she entered New York City's dance
music community. Formally known as Reid Margolis, Speed started
playing out just short of a year after she began spinning. Her local
career swiftly took off, as she was soon playing at a large handful of
local parties and received her first rotating residency, all within
two years. Her affiliation with Stuck on Earth promotions began when
founder, Chris Kausch, caught her at a local event. In April of 1998,
her knowledge and experience landed her a job at DJ Dara's record
store, Breakbeat Science. Working in the well-known store exposed
Speed to many promoters and artists and gave her an avenue to further
her DJing. The job also lead to her residency at DJ Seoul's Direct
Drive nights. She has worked on productions with FS (of Ming & FS) and
her first mix CD, Reeespect, was released through Stuck on Earth in
early 2001.
~ Diana Potts, All Music Guide

With:
Donna Matrix (Newsbreakz)
Aaron Jae vs M.O.D. (Evil Breaks/SFBreaks.org)
with Audio Angel (Groundscore/Sister SF)
Ripple (Subscience)
Bam vs Influence (Evil Breaks/Invibe)
Sheztek vs Jauncy (Moksha Tribe)

--=20
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

May 11th:  Wink @ Butter
May 14th:  Telic Benefit Day Party
May 14th:  Downlow
May 21st:  DIRTY w/ Reid Speed @ Shadow Lounge
May 26th:  Goldie @ Ruby Skye
June 11th:  Battery Acid Buddhas
June 11th:  Ataraxia Nervosa
June 17th:  Mighty Breaks
June 24th:  Subscience 2 Year
July 16th:  Clandestine @ Blue Cube

Subject: [sfraves] Party Rant

PLEASE READ WITH CAUTION THIS IS A NOTE WITH LOTS OF ME BITCHING, (I AM 
USING MY ONCE A YEAR FREE PARKING PASS FOR NO OTHER REASON THAN TO VENT) IF 
YOU PROCEED, YOU DO SO AT YOUR OWN RISK, IF THIS CAUSES A FLAME WAR FOR ANY 
REASON, PLEASE SEND ALL EMAILS TO 
LALALALALALALALALALALALALALALA@CANTHEARYOU.COM
IF YOU SERIOUSLY NEED TO GET IN TOUCH WITH ME FOR DISCUSSION ON FORGIVENESS, 
LOVE AND RANDOM ACTS OF ME SHOWING MY BUTT TO NICE PEOPLE, PLEASE EMAIL ME 
AT LALALALA@STILLCANTHEARYOU.COM
I WILL CONSIDER THIS TO BE SOMEWHAT EDUCATIONAL SIMULATION TO WHAT IT WOULD 
BE LIKE IF YOU WERE ANNA NICHOL SMITH'S DINNER.  IF YOU FEEL THAT YOU DID 
NOT GET ANYTHING GOOD FROM THIS EMAIL, PLEASE READ THIS NEXT SENTENCE OVER 
AND OVER:
"DESPITE PREVIOUS THOUGHT, RICHARD SIMMONS DOES, IN FACT, LOVE YOU VERY, 
VERY MUCH!"
.
(ENTER)  <--CLICK ON THIS
I bet you a hundred bux  nuthin happenned  huh?
pretty cool eh...okay, here we go...hold on...
to simply put it, I was very dissapointed with this party I went to last 
night
I hereby call this "review of the asshole party from hell, owned/ran and 
secured by assholes and put on by people who treated me like an asshole  
because I tried to help out my fellow friends and joyful, warm UGSF 
community from getting ripped off, apparently, I had bad timing?  
Humanitarians are bad mmmmkaay.  Still processing that one.   "DO unto 
others as others would have done unto you"  So I wanted to bring it to your 
attention that Christ was lying to all of us, it is just propaganda...found 
out last ngith and am pretty bummed, we have all been fooled.
     okay...so some of you may be thinking what "what the hell is up with 
this guy?"  "who gives him the right ?" "Is he on crack?"  "lots of run -on 
sentences that don't make too much sense right now" "where do you think he 
got that really cool re-entry stamp that doesn't work?"  "Is he single?"  
(if you asked if I was single, give yourself one point.  Points will be 
tallied at end of rant for the "Re-Entry Stamp Contest"
here is where we began....I used to be Kathy Lee Gifford's best friend-naw, 
just kidding, now seriously..
I started partying summer of '96 and consistently went to parties every 
weekend for several years. (ouch) I have been a promoter of parties up in 
Humboldt County (humboldt Rave Collective) as well as dj and drinker of fine 
wine and fernet..  I am friend to many and usually end up being one of the 
rare persons who walks around at parties to make sure "people are okay." you 
may have recognized me at a party, just keep an eye out for a guy who says 
"hey!, how are you doing, are you okay?"  And the ones who aren't, Whack 'em 
  ever so slightly on the back of their heads with a book on "forgiveness.") 
    You can find one of these books under your grandmothers's collection of 
National Geographic mags in the bathroom.  trust me . Usually, they are 
fine,(suspected Rick Jame's types)   which you will find out very quickly... 
anyhoo, I digress like Martha Stewart's ankle bracelet....
   Last night, my friends and I went to the Taurus party on purpose, a 
location that resembled an old gallery similar to "True Love" party from 
back in the day, that means "a long time ago"
okay...this may start a big thing on the list, whatever, I am a size queen 
and proud...I am very pissed off and extremely dissapointed with how the 
Taurus party went last night.  The door guy stopped us as there was a long 
line at the entrance to the party, we waited patiently for 15 minutes or so 
before entry, not a problem at all.line behind us grew more and more.  The 
music was great, wonderful I started to see many familiar faces from both 
Santa Cruz and SF from what I could see while waiting and watching 30 or so 
peeps zip right on in with their "reentry stamps."
   These were real, authentic ink stamps in which the door guy, or dude/girl 
stamps the inside of your right wrist for the soul purpose of you being able 
to  "RE-ENTER"
RULE NUMBER .5: IF YOU ARE THROWING A PARTY AND YOU HAVE RE-ENTRY STAMPS, I 
WOULD PUSH THE WONDERFUL IDEA OF ACTUALLY LETTING YOUR GUESTS 
"RE-ENTER"---trust me, I know, this seems simple...but as I learned last 
night, it really is not.  I will explain later.
   We were finally let in at 11:30pm with our "re-entry stamps"  I was 
stoked.  The space was nice, not decorated at all.  Seemed very last 
minute-ish  White walls, lots of room inside for all the people outside 
waiting inline to come on in.  Nope.  The rave hula hooopers were going 
crazy taking up all the space...grrrr.  I wanted to *crop dust them. We 
settled outside to have a smoke, chilled a bit.  I got up to go take a wee 
wee in the potty and alittle on my right shoe (of course, like duh)  as I 
walked to the bathrooms (which were located at the entrance way next to one 
of the few, very creative decorations that said "Free re-entry stamps that 
don't work, unless you pay 10-20$$ more at the door")   I did not think 
anything of it, I was just happy to have my re-entry stamp...ya know, in 
case I had to find someone, or maybe take someone safely to their car so 
they can avoid being killed by a meanie muni driver who has never had the 
priveledge to ever get a real re-entry stamp that did not work. I heard they 
were no longer letting people inside the party this was around 12:15am
Interesting.  I thought, "good god if they had been to any of the old school 
harmony parties/Lepidoptera parties, they would have had a cornary or 
35...when the locations were sooo slammed full that walking anywhere, you 
could not help to avoid stepping on hands, faces, lotion, candy bracelets, 
or your boyfriend.  I did not understand, maybe there were regulations with 
space owner that I could not figure out.
  Friend and I were waiting on a couple of others to get inside, was not 
sure if it was going to happen.  I was concerned, we had no cells to 
communicate.

I go back to the front to see if I could see my buddies in line, not there, 
then I hear that people who were being let in were being charged 
20-30$$$$$$$ a piece instead OF  THE ADVERTISED 10$
that was stated on the flyer and in local calenders.
HUH? WHAT THE FUCK IS THAT?  I figured people were being charged extra as an 
"I am waiting inline inconvenience fee" (if they had the nerve to charge 
extra, I really was not putting it past them)  I was pretty upset, as were 
many others who had just been waiiting up to a half hour for a party with no 
decorations, one bathroom, and one sound area.  If the music had not been 
great, I thing I would have staged an "anti-plur riot" which involves lots 
of farting and quickly moving thru the crowd, waiting for a small and secret 
uproar.

After finding out the shit that was being done by the staff at the front, I 
went to find the promoter (yay, proactivity)  I ran into Little John and 
asked if he new who I could speak with and he pointed to a gentleman.  "go 
talk to him"
  Alrighty....anyone who has ever known me, knows that my intent is about 
99% good always unless I am dealing with an ex boyfriend.  I aproached the 
tall, sweaty guy, who was previously djing, I introduced myself and told him 
what I was hearring and seeing from the door.  I let him know that the last 
bunch of peeps were charged over the advertised price by the guy at the 
door.  He totally snapped at me.  what the fuck do you expect me to do?!?!" 
the spaceowner is a bitch,I really dont have time for this shit"

                                                        ummmm, whoa
                                                               dude, 
breathe...
   I mean, really...
                                  Downward dog...
stretch, breathe,
  I tried to find a new way to approach him, more diplomaticaly than before, 
He was just really pissed off.  Apparently his evenning was not going the 
way he wanted.  Due to the owner being a *hagatha biotch.  I wish he would 
have pointed me in her direction so  my lil elfen friends could attack her 
and take her make up off with keebler crackers and stuff. .  Grrrrrr.  Where 
was my big rubber "PLUR" stamp when I needed it, it would have fit perfectly 
right in the center of his forehead.

RULE NUMBER 1 WHEN PROMOTOTING/THROWING PARTIES:  IF YOU ARE GOING TO THROW 
A PARTY, YOU MUST TAKE THE RESPONSIBILITY TO DO SO OR DONT FUCKING DO IT!!!
pretty please

RULE NUMBER 1.5 DONT BE MEAN TO PEOPLE WHO TRY TO HELP YOU
(i THINK THAT MAY EVEN BE IN THE BIBLE, OR A COOKBOOK i SAW ONCE)

RULE NUMBER 2: PEOPLE WHO BRING HULAS TO INDOOR 150MAX CAPACITY PARTIES 
BETTER BE  AS SPECTACULAR AS MOTHER THERESA IN A THONG BEKINI PLUS CHARGE 
FOR 3 EXTRA TICKETS, EVEN THOUGH THE HULAS TAKE UP ROOM FOR TEN.

   You will only jeopardize yourself and the people who may be dumb enough 
to actually attend. I found my friend who was djing and talked to her about 
what was going on...apparently she knows the promoter very well.
"you are kidding!", she pulls the guy away from his relaxed converstaion 
with his friend after he had just yelled at me for "not having time"   I 
wanted to give him a hula hoop if he was going to stand there But then 
again, who really wants to talk to someone like me if they are making 4 
months worth in rent for the evenning by ripping other's off.*
  Thank god for miss "M" ladies out there, I love ya, really I do.
Smoke/processing time-I go outside to chill, hearing more people talking 
about that $$ at the door factor, still, other friends were not there yet 
who we were supposed to meet.  It was now around 1:30 or so...
On top of everything, there was a very nice boy, flirting with me, then 
telling me how I should live my life in regards to smoking and drinking.  I 
was certain it was my mom fucking with me.
nope.  It wasn't my mom, I asked him what her middle name was and he told me 
  it was "george"  He continued to say that people who drink whiskey are 
drunks....sorry dude, my AA sponsor says otherwise (bad joke)

RULE NUMBER ONE IN DATING/FLIRTING:  DONT TELL PEOPLE THEY SUCK BEFORE YOU 
EVEN FUCK!!!
---it really wont help you get laid, I swear! (but did you notice how nice 
and manipulative he was from the get go? very similar to someone wanting you 
to eat their fingertip chilli special..or something
RULE NUMBER 2: IF YOU CAN RECOGNIZE AN OLD FREAKY KARMIC RELATIONSHIP WITHIN 
THE FIRST 5 MINUTES WHILE YOU ARE ALREADY KINDA STRESSED/WORRIED, WALK AWAY, 
COME BACK AND REINTRODUCE YOURSELVES IN THE NEXT LIFE WHEN THINGS ARE 
HOPEFULLY MORE CALM, AND YOU NO LONGER SMOKE CIGGIES.

I started ponderring the idea that maybe I was the one causing all this 
trouble...In a situation where there is all sorts of BS, oh, fuck 
it...BULLSHIT.  So you can kind of say I was being sensitive, but it really 
hurt my feelings...partying up here for sooo long, then they (not knowing 
who "they" actually are) charge that much while keeping the crowd soo 
thinned, I think they planted the hula hoopers like cage dancers in a sleeze 
club.  And there was still a huge crowd out in front from what I could see, 
apparently Osby was even spotted by the Crocodile Hunter knawing on a rubber 
tire.  So there were tuns of peeps that did not get in, Aaron Jae was having 
a bitch of a time too...it was just over all kinda sucky that there was all 
this going on.  It really ruined it.  I let it get to me because I am very 
opinionated with the politcal aspects of parties.  I love parties.  I love 
people who go to them.  Whatmad eme mad most of all is knowing that I REALLY 
do try everyday to go out of my way to help others have a good time.  A good 
time in a good honest fashion with good love and food, and stuffs.  Since 
when do we fuck humanitarian type folks? Are they good lays or wonderful 
scapegoats for the Gargamels of life?
I will be praying for forgiveness, hitting myself in the back of the head 
with that forgiveness book from grandma's for years to come as it is as 
diddapointing as if I were shaped like an oscar meyer weiner or something 
that is weirder looking...just for being a humanitarian typa guy who got a 
real "re-entry stamp.

RULE NUMBER 4ISH: IF YOU ARE PROMOTING A PARTY/ORGANIZER OF A PARTY, TALK 
WITH THE MANAGER/HAGATHA BIOTCH OF THE LOCATION AND GET EVERYTHING IN 
WRITING AHEAD OF TIME SO YOU DONT GET FUCKED, SO THEY DONT GET FUCKED, AND 
SO WE DONT GET FUCKED.  AT LEAST MAKE SURE THERE IS LUBE IF YOU CANT WORK 
SHIT OUT...CUZ IN THE END THERE JUST MIGHT BE SHIT, OH WAIT, ENEMA, WRONG 
NOUN, LUBE IS IF YOU ARE LIKE ALL DRY AND STUFF....DUH
WHERE DID MY BEER GO?
IS THIS STILL RECORDING?


Unfair. To me, others who paid that money, unfair to the people who charged 
it, especially if they thought that was an okay thing to do.  Be forewarned, 
you may meet a person in the next life who tries hitting on you then tells 
you that you are fucked up...see the irony?

I THINK RULE NUMBER 3: KARMA IS A BITCH AND i WANT TO SLAP HER

Okay, nearring the climax here folks...love that word, I digress.  and 
squeeze my nipple . After all this, I went outside to get my buddy to head 
out I told him to meet me out front.  He was a little bit out of it.  I get 
to the front, passing people still waiting in line for the hula hooper space 
taker-uppers to stop so they can come in and play as well..I went out the 
front door and the security guy states "NO RE-ENTRY, ONCE YER OUT YER OUT!"  
I showed him my stamp, he really could give a rats ass, actually, now that I 
think of it, I probably would have had an easier time getting back in if I 
did give him a rat's ass (like attracts like)  I told him that my friend was 
supposed to come out side and I was looking for him because he was a little 
"drunk"
   Security guy says this "WELL YOUR FRIEND SHOULDN"T HAVE COME TO THIS 
PARTY IF HE WAS DRUNK!"
-----okay, here when it gets good......
My thoughts:  1. did he just tell me my friend should not have come to the 
party  drunk?  Partying sober is fine, I dont have a problem with the other 
side of it either.  But if you go to a party, watch yourself, dont go 
overboard...there are people who keeps their eyes open for that usually  =)
                    2. This guy apparently did not realize they were selling 
booze inside, I guess it is pretty easy to look the other way when you are 
working security at an unpermitted space for a minimal wage
                   3.They have had people in and out all night
                    4 and most importantly my friend was not inside, not in 
front and really, all I wanted to do was find him, make sure he was alive 
and go to bed.  It is okay to make sure people are okay in certain places 
right?  Good, I dont hear any disagreements there...

   I was soooo pissed off, I told the guy I was going back in to look one 
more time and he was not wanting to let me...
you wanna hear what happens when you piss off the nice guy?  I went up to 
him, pretty close too  (I am so proud of myself for standing up for my 
friend and I by the way:P )  "If you really want to go there Sir, that is 
your name?  You just got out of college, okay understood.  Let me point out 
you the fact that you are a security guy WORKING A FUCKING RAVE in 
SF...usually that means there  unfortunatley will be a few peeps durring the 
evenning that need assistence, you should know this.  I have a fucking stamp 
on my wrist, I need to find my buddy, this aint bullshit. I am concerned and 
I am actually surprised that you aren't considerring your working conditions 
"
  so I looked in the yellow pages for a "re-entry stamp repair shop, cause 
mine obviously was not working, or was that the idea from the beginning so 
they can make more bling?  I have no idea.

    A big part of me writing this is not to bash anyone really, I want 
people to know that there are certain arenas within throwing parties that do 
need to be checked, marked, and really well-planned out.  Dont hire your old 
college friends who have no concept of what responsibilities are when 
working parties, unpermitted or not...
   Promoters: kind of like running a business aint it?  you want to make 
people feel safe, cared for, respected while at the same time, having the 
time of their lives.  Really, put effort into this, it is worth it.  The 
downside of poor planning can turn up a lot of shit, fines, injuries, and 
others...if you have people in the front doing security.  I would love it if 
I were to never have to deal with these certain lame-o security guys again.  
I have no idea what company they were with or if that was even the case.  
Maybe someone could be proactive and teach them a little compassion and 
possibly care for the work they do.  But dammit, if someone is sick, (which 
was not really the case) I want to know that there are others than friends 
who will at least, lemme reiderrate that AT LEAST let you back 
inside/outside so you can find them, so they can be cared for.
   I am also kicking myself in the butt because I threw that receipt away 
for my "re-entry stamp"  I was wanting to return it and get my $$ back.  I 
hope all others had a great and safe evenning.  I will not be back at that 
location ever agian, happily

>real re-entry stamps that don't work, are in fact really cool and effective 
>if used at proper locations.
>Anna Nichol's dinner must, in fact, be very very tasty..."Trim Spa 
>Babeeeeeeee"
*an old waiter trick of farting as you rush on by.  With hula hoopers its 
different, they seem to not notice because they have the hula protective 
barrier which becomes stronger as their drugs kick in...then they really 
can't smell it.  So what you do is ask to borrow the hula hoop to "try," 
then fart really quick and hand it back to them, then run away.  Make sure 
you are wearring a mask to hide your identity.
*word was the owner was the reason for raver ticket inflation
*HAGATHA BIOTCH:mean space owner lady chick thing, similar to Cruella 
Deville minus all the dogs

Danny

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: EGR Records/Catharsis (hard techno/powernoise/electrotech)

Greets,

This upcoming week and a half contains 3 separate events in San Francisco 
featuring EGR Records artists Catharsis & Nadon... A summary is at the top 
followed by more in depth information on each event:

-----------

Tuesday evening 5/10  --  Catharsis vs Nadon @ HuggerMugger; hard 
techno/powernoise; midnight to 2am

Saturday 5/14 -- Catharsis @ Spin This!; various edgy goodness; rotation 
between DJs all evening.

Thursday 5/19 -- Catharsis @ Future; electotech/electroclash  11:45pm to 1am

-----------

If you had to choose only one I'd recommend the Future event as it is the 
opening night for this club and I'll be doing a different style than my 
usual for this event.. Definitely more approachable than hard 
techno/powernoise, but still aggressively mixed from vinyl!

-----------
5/10

Catharsis vs Nadon @ HuggerMugger

When: Tuesday evening May 10th  9:30pm to 2am; we are dropping hard techno 
/ powernoise between midnight and 2am; possibly a little earlier.

Cost: Free!!

Lineup
9:30 - 11 Juan Segovia (tech-om)
11 - 12 Aaron Jae (EvilBreaks / SFBreaks)
12 - 2 Catharsis Vs. Nadon (EGR Records)

Location: 101 6th St @ Mission in San Francisco

Website: 
<http://www.tech-on.com/huggermugger.php>http://www.tech-on.com/huggermugger.php

-----------
5/14

Spin This!

When: Saturday May 14th  9:00pm to 2am

Cost: Free before 9pm; $1 9 to 11pm; $3 after

Lineup:
DJ rotation between Catharsis, Fanboy, Jawa, Phreaki Boi, & RMS

Location: 682 Commercial St. Off of Kearny between Sacramento and Clay

Website: http://www.dark-tekno.com/spinthis/

-----------
5/19

Opening night of Future featuring the latest in electrotech/clash, 
futurepop, synthpop, and indie remixes.

When: Thursday May 19th  9:00pm to 2am

Cost: Free before 10pm; $5 afterwards

Lineup
9:30 - 10:30 Modo (Future)
10:30 - 11:45 DJ Owl (Muf1)
11:45 - 1:00 Catharsis (EGR Records)
1:00 - close Modo (Future)

Location: 424 Haight st. in San Francisco  @ UndergroundSF

Website: http://www.futuresf.com/




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Paris hilton, being dumb...

http://www.cnn.com/2005/SHOWBIZ/Movies/05/05/film.paris.hilton.ap/index.htm=
l

Here's a few snippets that I personally enjoyed:

Q: Do you read blogs?

HILTON: What's that?

Q: Um, they're these things on the Internet where people write about
news and stuff.

HILTON: No, I don't really read anything on the Internet except my AOL
mail. I don't like people who sit on computers all day long and write
about people they don't know anything about.

Q: Paris, you just described my job.

(Her publicist, Rob Shuter, laughs.)

Q: What did you want to be when you were a little girl?

HILTON: A veterinarian, but then I realized I could just buy a bunch of ani=
mals.




Q: So what could you possibly do on "Simple Life 4"?

HILTON: Go to Maui.

Q: Why?

HILTON: They want to sex it up, have us more in swimsuits and stuff.

Q: But what would you do?

HILTON: I don't know. We could work as lifeguards or work in a hotel
or something.

Q: "Baywatch" tried that and it didn't work.

HILTON: Tried what?

Q: They went from the United States to Hawaii, which I guess is
technically the United States. Anyway, it didn't work. [Editor's note:
Hawaii, of course, is one of the United States.)

HILTON: (Silence.)


--=20
Live Life at 140bpm

> WITH THE MANAGER/HAGATHA BIOTCH OF THE LOCATION AND GET EVERYTHING IN
> WRITING AHEAD OF TIME SO YOU DONT GET FUCKED, SO THEY DONT GET FUCKED, AND
> SO WE DONT GET FUCKED.  AT LEAST MAKE SURE THERE IS LUBE IF YOU CANT WORK
> SHIT OUT...CUZ IN THE END THERE JUST MIGHT BE SHIT, OH WAIT, ENEMA, WRONG
> NOUN, LUBE IS IF YOU ARE LIKE ALL DRY AND STUFF....DUH
> WHERE DID MY BEER GO?
> IS THIS STILL RECORDING?
>
>
> Unfair. To me, others who paid that money, unfair to the people who
> charged
> it, especially if they thought that was an okay thing to do.  Be
> forewarned,
> you may meet a person in the next life who tries hitting on you then tells
> you that you are fucked up...see the irony?
>
> I THINK RULE NUMBER 3: KARMA IS A BITCH AND i WANT TO SLAP HER
>
> Okay, nearring the climax here folks...love that word, I digress.  and
> squeeze my nipple . After all this, I went outside to get my buddy to head
> out I told him to meet me out front.  He was a little bit out of it.  I
> get
> to the front, passing people still waiting in line for the hula hooper
> space
> taker-uppers to stop so they can come in and play as well..I went out the
> front door and the security guy states "NO RE-ENTRY, ONCE YER OUT YER
> OUT!"
> I showed him my stamp, he really could give a rats ass, actually, now that
> I
> think of it, I probably would have had an easier time getting back in if I
> did give him a rat's ass (like attracts like)  I told him that my friend
> was
> supposed to come out side and I was looking for him because he was a
> little
> "drunk"
>    Security guy says this "WELL YOUR FRIEND SHOULDN"T HAVE COME TO THIS
> PARTY IF HE WAS DRUNK!"

> party  drunk?  Partying sober is fine, I dont have a problem with the
> other

> overboard...there are people who keeps their eyes open for that usually

> selling
> booze inside, I guess it is pretty easy to look the other way when you are

>                     4 and most importantly my friend was not inside, not
> in
> front and really, all I wanted to do was find him, make sure he was alive
> and go to bed.  It is okay to make sure people are okay in certain places
> right?  Good, I dont hear any disagreements there...
>
>    I was soooo pissed off, I told the guy I was going back in to look one
> more time and he was not wanting to let me...
> you wanna hear what happens when you piss off the nice guy?  I went up to
> him, pretty close too  (I am so proud of myself for standing up for my
> friend and I by the way:P )  "If you really want to go there Sir, that is
> your name?  You just got out of college, okay understood.  Let me point
> out
> you the fact that you are a security guy WORKING A FUCKING RAVE in
> SF...usually that means there  unfortunatley will be a few peeps durring
> the
> evenning that need assistence, you should know this.  I have a fucking
> stamp
> on my wrist, I need to find my buddy, this aint bullshit. I am concerned
> and
> I am actually surprised that you aren't considerring your working
> conditions
> "
>   so I looked in the yellow pages for a "re-entry stamp repair shop, cause
> mine obviously was not working, or was that the idea from the beginning so
> they can make more bling?  I have no idea.
>
>     A big part of me writing this is not to bash anyone really, I want
> people to know that there are certain arenas within throwing parties that
> do
> need to be checked, marked, and really well-planned out.  Dont hire your
> old
> college friends who have no concept of what responsibilities are when
> working parties, unpermitted or not...
>    Promoters: kind of like running a business aint it?  you want to make
> people feel safe, cared for, respected while at the same time, having the
> time of their lives.  Really, put effort into this, it is worth it.  The
> downside of poor planning can turn up a lot of shit, fines, injuries, and
> others...if you have people in the front doing security.  I would love it
> if
> I were to never have to deal with these certain lame-o security guys

Subject: [sfraves] my first rave experience--tell me yours?

hi. i live in s.f. and on my 24th birthday (april 9th) friends took me
to my first rave ("stark raving mad") and i wrote about my experience
when i got home. that's what i've pasted below. i'm posting here
because i don't know anyone in the rave community, but i'm hoping to
meet some of you, maybe at an upcoming party? that's odd for me to
say, 'cause i'm anti-social--no, i used to be--but since that party
and another one, i'm feeling a newfound connectedness. at first i
ascribed it to the pill--and yeah, the pill deserves some credit--but
long after it wore off, the craving for community lingered.

- Bobby

----------------------------------------------------------

4.10.2005

i'm sitting here with a soggy towel stuffed into the back of my mouth.
not a proper mouthpiece, but better than the plastic bottle cap i spat
out after my molars mashed it down to a gnarled disc. my chew toy
before that was the mangled mess of what used to be a pen cap, and for
a while i even grinded down on a wad of bubble wrap.

jaw tension: a side effect of the pill jason set in my palm around van
ness and sutter, after we stepped off the 38 bus. a couple blocks
later, at the side of an office building, a nondescript guy guarding a
nondescript door whispered "shhhhh" and glanced down the sidewalk
before letting us in the basement. i sidestepped through sweaty
strangers and sat against a wall in a room painted with daycare-bright
gorillas and parrots. next to me two girls bit each other's lips,
their teeth glowing green under the black lights. another girl by the
turntables swung a fluorescent mesh of light trails all around her
body.

i raked my fingernails over my arm, but nothing.

in my usual role of detached observant i stuck to the wall and watched
djs flick lighters to see knobs on their equipment. i tend to walk
through real life as disembodied eyes and ears, forgetting i'm in the
office, the car, the restaurant. until someone addresses me. then i
twitch and say, "i was--i'm sorry--i was somewhere else." as a kid i
wouldn't even go into my mother's office unless she promised not to
introduce me to anyone. now, still, as i walk the stairs to my own
job, i incant, "remember to say good morning, remember to say good
morning." and i'm just as aloof at home, grinning when i walk into a
silent apartment, roommates gone or locked away. sometimes,
though--and this is sometimes--i counter my artful avoidance with a
calculated trip to the kitchen for apple juice. to flash my face, say
hi, ask some questions.

but i like my roommates, i like my coworkers. that's the hardest part
to explain. i like the bustle and clamor of a packed subway car--until
i recognize someone and walk toward the other end. this is why i have
a closet full of hooded sweatshirts.

tell me how to tactfully rephrase this sentiment: "i like you, all of
you, i really do, and i appreciate the invitation--that's actually my
favorite restaurant in the city--but if i go, if i go and the
conversation turns to me and you ask me how maryland's climate
compares to california's, i will--and this does not reflect on any of
you--i will shove a gun in my mouth midsentence. not to die, not to be
away from you, but to be alone."

maryland actually gets really hot, a lot hotter than here in the
summer, but the winters--click, bang.

so there's the backstory of my intractable reclusiveness, meaning that
i descended into this underground party as a silent spy, like one of
the little robots sent down to collect tea cup fragments from
titanic's hull. i kept my back to the jungle mural and sifted details:
fire-orange vinyl purses, knee-high striped socks, "this is my rave
shirt."

for what felt like an hour i turned over a water bottle until a warm
glow from my feet crept up my ankles and spread through my calves,
while a soft vapor gauze clung to my arms, wrapping in moist layers.
simple sensations, like a sudden awareness of friction between the air
and my forearms, triggered my hands to carve slices through the
humidity, automatic as a reflex, controllable but not chosen, not any
more than i decided to dilate my pupils or sweat through my shirt.

someone handed me a flyer i already had. i handed it back. "no," she
forced, "fan your face with it."

the heat: another detail. all night you can watch pink bodies press
against the grills of industrial fans without considering your own
meltdown. thirst, i must have traded that sensation for a
hyper-sensitivity to bass reverberations. on the girl's tip i pushed
forward to the water counter alongside other red-faced kids who had
overheated in unventilated rooms. i chugged another bottle, popped the
fresh cap in my mouth and dropped a dollar in the tip jar for all the
human effort that crafted this sub-world, all the hands that wired
speakers, ran projectors, built massage tables and taped up prints of
optical illusions.

the free exchange of air: another detail. the beauty of breathing.
that we swap our atmosphere indiscriminately, that no null space
exists between us and, and, and, that's it: the connectedness of all
things. imagine how faces would blur into a common form if you thumbed
through a stack of polaroid headshots. i had a vision of my own image
fusing between and permeating throughout those layers, into that shaky
composite of eyebrows and nostrils. i headed for a dark corner to
crouch in and scribble a sloppy essay on my brilliant theories of
oneness--particles, man, particles--but on the way i remembered that i
was brainstorming with the same genius that inspired a lot of these
people to wear orange socks.

someone passed out another flyer. the words blurred, focused, blurred.
"we're not here to preach about how good it was 'back in the day,'"
the photocopied handwriting said. "we're not trying to bring back the
'old' vibe. it's time to appreciate all that we have right here in our
scene, make ourselves better and move forward."

i sat on the floor, my back to a girl in a white plastic chair.
kneading my neck, she asked, "is your jaw sore? you must have a good
pill."

another girl's hands upturned mine to the neon-netted ceiling. "relax
them. no, relax them."

another detail: the ineffable sense of togetherness in this gauntlet
of loving limbs. she bent each finger, snapping the joints apart with
a deftness i envied.

i yelled in some guy's ear, "this is my first time."

"first time?" he said, pulling a bright beaded bracelet off his wrist.
he slipped it over mine. "here."

(this is also at http://bobbyburgess.net/journal/?date=3D20050410 )

---------------------------------------------------------------------

RV's, No Lowriders!

Tickets: $20 Pre-Sale / $25 @ the Door

INFO LINES: 916.484.3717      775.321.9887
WEBSITES: www.stilldream.org   www.techno-truth.com    www.mixlife.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

I have to agree with chris on this issue. As being a past promoter/DJ/Party 
bank roller etc..

It is more a "Privilege" to get into a party for free. alot of times guys 
like to "Front" and say look at me getting into all these parties for free 
im a "Somebody" etc.. I had the courtesey of calling promoters in advanced 
and asking to get on a list. If they said they could not because of budget 
etc.. I would gladly pay, cause anyone that has been on the receiving end of 
doing an event knows how pricey it can be when you have your balls on the 
line. And yes partys are very stressful most promoters know this. I for one 
sure do.

So moral to my rant. Call promoter in advance so you don't get your feelings 
hurt at the door. Be willing to pay if the promoter needs the $$

But I have say it does suck having to pay 10-15 bucks per party if you have 
10 you need to hit up that night. So advice follow rule number 1. 
hehehehe...

just my thoughts,

Macadio

>it's an underground venue and I wouldn't want them to get in trouble for 
>flyers on cars or outside.  I didn't know it was his house and I think it's 
>a bit crazy to charge fifteen bucks at 2am for all local talent when there 
>are only two hours left in the party.  We actually weren't there to party 
>in the first place; we came from the city to drop off some flyers, shake 
>some hands, and promote a couple of up coming events.  If he didn't want 
>flyers in, he could have at least been polite about it.  He came from a 
>rather harsh angle and basically told us to piss off.  I believe the reason 
>most people let you into their parties to promote is to keep the cycle of 
>parties and promotion active.  If you let promoters in and they spread the 
>word about up coming events, it's more likely that events are going to do 
>well and it perpetuates a more active scene.  Maybe I was bit harsh in my 
>first post saying he was a dick, but I can't think of a better way to 
>describe his attitude.  On another note, we've never had a problem coming 
>into the venue before to promote, so it seemed a little odd and out of 
>place that we were turned away at the door.  In any case, water under the 
>bridge as far as I'm concerned.
>Eat Fresh,
>Joey Frisco

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

I don't usually post on here...but i can't even believe that someone woudl 
complain about not getting into an event for free to flyer when the venue 
allowed no flyers.  And personally, i would give attitude if someone asked 
more than once.  But thats just me.

In my opinion, promoters in general need to calm down and get off their high 
horses.  Throwing a party does not automatically allow you to be admitted 
into every event for free.

That being said...the party was amazing, the bathroom situation was a breath 
of fresh air (metaphorically) cause there was never a wait.  The sound and 
talent amazing, the crowd....well lets say the rave trash was filtered out. 
<3 modified.

~Molly

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!

Being one of the people that happened to be there, I have to say I
couldn't possibly agree with you any more Joey. I think what people
fail to realize is that we are upset about the lack of respect that
Element showed us. And I'm not saying respect because we were
promoting, but respect as people. For me at least I show every
promoter that I'm on good terms with such a level of respect the cant
help but show it in return. When that respect is not returned I feel
sort of slapped in the face. But beyond that Element came off as quite
the jerk. I have worked with him on two separate shows in the past.
Both times I treated him with the utmost respect, so I hope in the
future it gets returned.

Like Joe said it's water under the bridge, no hard feelings. We are
all adults here so there is no need to beat a dead horse.


--=20
Nick Sideshow
---------------------------
http://www.hcftp.com
http://www.dtscollective.org
HCFTP/DisturbingTheScene

On 5/9/05, Joey Frisco <josephwhunt@hotmail.com> wrote:
> Well, honestly... if you would have ever come to one of our (DTS) events,
> and wanted to promote an upcoming party, we would have shaken your hand a=
nd
> invited you (and usually one other promoter per party) into the space to =
do
> your thing (we had three people for two parties).  It's just the edicate =
and
> respect we show for other crews and promoters that are trying to throw
> parties and do positive things for the scene.  A lot of other crews that =
I
> am indirectly involved with have the same two promoter or promoter +1
> policy.  It actually seems to be the standard, especially with the crews
> that post on bayraves, evolic, dts, hcftp, etc...  I understand that you =
are
> trying to do something different without posting on some of these resourc=
es,
> but I don't understand that you don't show the same respect and courtesy =
to
> others that they would show to you or any other crew trying to come up an=
d
> do right.  Especially after we talked to you at the door and explained th=
at
> you were welcome to promote at our parties and informed you that we only
> wanted to walk through.  It seemed like you were basically telling us tha=
t
> you didn't give a fuck about anyone other than your crew and how you did
> that night.  It came across like this, "I don't want to clean up your
> flyers; I don't pass flyers out at your party; why should I help you prom=
ote
> your party or perpetuate the scene if I don't print flyers and hand them =
out
> at your parties; you're here and there are two hours left in the party, s=
o,
> I'm gonna charge you as much as I can even though I know that you're only
> gonna be here for a few minutes; actually, in the end guys, go fuck
> yourselves because I don't care about anyone other than modified
> productions."  It just sucks when people monkey wrench instead of oil the
> metaphorical rave machine.  It really doesn't benefit anyone to be a an
> asshole, if you were that stressed about money for your party, you should
> have said so instead of coming across like the nazi supervisor of the foo=
d
> line at a concentration camp.  In anycase, no hard feelings really, I jus=
t
> think that it was a shitty decision on your part and that you were a dick
> for whatever reason (evidently you don't think that you should help other
> crews out).  Like I said in my last post, it's all water under the bridge=
 to
> me.  Best of luck in future endeavors.
> Cordially,
> -Joey Frisco

> >From: element <modifiedproductions@gmail.com>
> >Reply-To: element@modifiedproductions.com
> >To: Joey Frisco <josephwhunt@hotmail.com>
> >CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: 5/6 doublethinnk - thanx Modified!
> >Date: Sun, 8 May 2005 16:31:05 -0700
> >
> >#1 - I live in that warehouse.  Flyers were never a problem at our
> >first few events there.  However, the last 2 parties it has gotten a
> >lot worse.  The flyering issue has come up on this mailing list before
> >and has/is talked about by many promoters.  It's just not cool to have
> >to cleanup peoples' flyers, period.
> >
> >#2 - Modified has only printed one flyer.  That flyer was put out
> >almost two years ago.
> >
> >#3 - I very rarely get into parties for free unless I am doing sound,
> >helping to setup/cleanup, or DJing.  I make it a point to pay other
> >events I go to.  Perhaps if promoters set a standard by paying to get
> >into all the events they show up to in order to "drop off some flyers,
> >shake some hands, and promote a couple of up coming events" it would
> >help the scene "to keep the cycle of parties and promotion active."
> >
> >#4 - Modified events on average, pull about 100-150 people right now @
> >my place.  New Years was the only party we would have walked away with
> >more then a couple hundred bucks in our pockets.  What happened at New
> >Years?  We gave out full refunds at the door as the PD kicked everyone
> >out.  How often does that happen?  How big of a dick does that make
> >me?
> >       Myself and a couple of others have been barely breaking even or
> >sometimes taking losses since Modified started.  It was our hope we
> >could build a name and earn peoples trust in order to do something
> >other then renegades.
> >       How much do you think rent is on a warehouse?  Lets do some quick
> >math.  We had roughly 120 paying people Friday night.  That's $1800 @
> >the door.  By the time you minus rent, decor (we watered down and
> >repainted over half of the space), new lighting, patrolled parking and
> >all those last minute stupid things you never think about (zip ties,
> >string, broken/stolen needles, etc.) maybe you can understand the $15
> >cost.  Perhaps we should lower ticket price and pack 500 people in
> >there?
> >       Those first few $3-$5 parties we did set a standard.  A standard =
that
> >just isn't financially viable outside of what we were doing before.
> >Let's face reality - it takes money to throw parties.  If people want
> >a place to party where they aren't going to be hassled like they are
> >at other spaces, aren't going to be packed like cattle into the venue,
> >and can generally expect a good time, then they have to be willing to
> >pay a cover that will at least pay for the party.
> >
> >#5  We don't search (maybe we should start) - people get flyers in
> >sometimes.  When they do, they are asked to put them away.
> >
> >Joey -  I apologize if I came off as an asshole.  I did not intend to.
> >  Parties are a bit stressful for promoters last time a checked.  if it
> >really was such a big deal to you, I invite you and the other two
> >other people I am assuming also wanted to get in  - free of charge -
> >to come to my next show and flyer for your event.  All I ask is that
> >you stay after to clean up.
> >
> >element
> >modified productions
> >

From sfraves-return-121210-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue May 10 07:03:37 2005

Subject: Re: [sfraves] my first rave experience--tell me yours?

Well, Bobby, this is one of the most engaging posts I've seen here in 
ages.  Well written.

Love,

Apollo


At 08:39 PM 5/9/2005, Bobby Burgess wrote:
>hi. i live in s.f. and on my 24th birthday (april 9th) friends took me
>to my first rave ("stark raving mad") and i wrote about my experience
>when i got home. that's what i've pasted below. i'm posting here
>because i don't know anyone in the rave community, but i'm hoping to
>meet some of you, maybe at an upcoming party? that's odd for me to
>say, 'cause i'm anti-social--no, i used to be--but since that party
>and another one, i'm feeling a newfound connectedness. at first i
>ascribed it to the pill--and yeah, the pill deserves some credit--but
>long after it wore off, the craving for community lingered.
>
>- Bobby
>
>----------------------------------------------------------
>
>4.10.2005
>
>i'm sitting here with a soggy towel stuffed into the back of my mouth.
>not a proper mouthpiece, but better than the plastic bottle cap i spat
>out after my molars mashed it down to a gnarled disc. my chew toy
>before that was the mangled mess of what used to be a pen cap, and for
>a while i even grinded down on a wad of bubble wrap.
>
>jaw tension: a side effect of the pill jason set in my palm around van
>ness and sutter, after we stepped off the 38 bus. a couple blocks
>later, at the side of an office building, a nondescript guy guarding a
>nondescript door whispered "shhhhh" and glanced down the sidewalk
>before letting us in the basement. i sidestepped through sweaty
>strangers and sat against a wall in a room painted with daycare-bright
>gorillas and parrots. next to me two girls bit each other's lips,
>their teeth glowing green under the black lights. another girl by the
>turntables swung a fluorescent mesh of light trails all around her
>body.
>
>i raked my fingernails over my arm, but nothing.
>
>in my usual role of detached observant i stuck to the wall and watched
>djs flick lighters to see knobs on their equipment. i tend to walk
>through real life as disembodied eyes and ears, forgetting i'm in the
>office, the car, the restaurant. until someone addresses me. then i
>twitch and say, "i was--i'm sorry--i was somewhere else." as a kid i
>wouldn't even go into my mother's office unless she promised not to
>introduce me to anyone. now, still, as i walk the stairs to my own
>job, i incant, "remember to say good morning, remember to say good
>morning." and i'm just as aloof at home, grinning when i walk into a
>silent apartment, roommates gone or locked away. sometimes,
>though--and this is sometimes--i counter my artful avoidance with a
>calculated trip to the kitchen for apple juice. to flash my face, say
>hi, ask some questions.
>
>but i like my roommates, i like my coworkers. that's the hardest part
>to explain. i like the bustle and clamor of a packed subway car--until
>i recognize someone and walk toward the other end. this is why i have
>a closet full of hooded sweatshirts.
>
>tell me how to tactfully rephrase this sentiment: "i like you, all of
>you, i really do, and i appreciate the invitation--that's actually my
>favorite restaurant in the city--but if i go, if i go and the
>conversation turns to me and you ask me how maryland's climate
>compares to california's, i will--and this does not reflect on any of
>you--i will shove a gun in my mouth midsentence. not to die, not to be
>away from you, but to be alone."
>
>maryland actually gets really hot, a lot hotter than here in the
>summer, but the winters--click, bang.
>
>so there's the backstory of my intractable reclusiveness, meaning that
>i descended into this underground party as a silent spy, like one of
>the little robots sent down to collect tea cup fragments from
>titanic's hull. i kept my back to the jungle mural and sifted details:
>fire-orange vinyl purses, knee-high striped socks, "this is my rave
>shirt."
>
>for what felt like an hour i turned over a water bottle until a warm
>glow from my feet crept up my ankles and spread through my calves,
>while a soft vapor gauze clung to my arms, wrapping in moist layers.
>simple sensations, like a sudden awareness of friction between the air
>and my forearms, triggered my hands to carve slices through the
>humidity, automatic as a reflex, controllable but not chosen, not any
>more than i decided to dilate my pupils or sweat through my shirt.
>
>someone handed me a flyer i already had. i handed it back. "no," she
>forced, "fan your face with it."
>
>the heat: another detail. all night you can watch pink bodies press
>against the grills of industrial fans without considering your own
>meltdown. thirst, i must have traded that sensation for a
>hyper-sensitivity to bass reverberations. on the girl's tip i pushed
>forward to the water counter alongside other red-faced kids who had
>overheated in unventilated rooms. i chugged another bottle, popped the
>fresh cap in my mouth and dropped a dollar in the tip jar for all the
>human effort that crafted this sub-world, all the hands that wired
>speakers, ran projectors, built massage tables and taped up prints of
>optical illusions.
>
>the free exchange of air: another detail. the beauty of breathing.
>that we swap our atmosphere indiscriminately, that no null space
>exists between us and, and, and, that's it: the connectedness of all
>things. imagine how faces would blur into a common form if you thumbed
>through a stack of polaroid headshots. i had a vision of my own image
>fusing between and permeating throughout those layers, into that shaky
>composite of eyebrows and nostrils. i headed for a dark corner to
>crouch in and scribble a sloppy essay on my brilliant theories of
>oneness--particles, man, particles--but on the way i remembered that i
>was brainstorming with the same genius that inspired a lot of these
>people to wear orange socks.
>
>someone passed out another flyer. the words blurred, focused, blurred.
>"we're not here to preach about how good it was 'back in the day,'"
>the photocopied handwriting said. "we're not trying to bring back the
>'old' vibe. it's time to appreciate all that we have right here in our
>scene, make ourselves better and move forward."
>
>i sat on the floor, my back to a girl in a white plastic chair.
>kneading my neck, she asked, "is your jaw sore? you must have a good
>pill."
>
>another girl's hands upturned mine to the neon-netted ceiling. "relax
>them. no, relax them."
>
>another detail: the ineffable sense of togetherness in this gauntlet
>of loving limbs. she bent each finger, snapping the joints apart with
>a deftness i envied.
>
>i yelled in some guy's ear, "this is my first time."
>
>"first time?" he said, pulling a bright beaded bracelet off his wrist.
>he slipped it over mine. "here."
>
>(this is also at http://bobbyburgess.net/journal/?date=20050410 )
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
practiced in past centuries ..."
- David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
