--- Bobby Burgess <bobbyburgess@gmail.com> wrote:

> hi. i live in s.f. and on my 24th birthday (april
> 9th) friends took me
> to my first rave ("stark raving mad") and i wrote
> about my experience
> when i got home. that's what i've pasted below. i'm
> posting here
> because i don't know anyone in the rave community,
> but i'm hoping to
> meet some of you, maybe at an upcoming party? that's
> odd for me to
> say, 'cause i'm anti-social--no, i used to be--but
> since that party
> and another one, i'm feeling a newfound
> connectedness. at first i
> ascribed it to the pill--and yeah, the pill deserves
> some credit--but
> long after it wore off, the craving for community
> lingered.
> 
> - Bobby
> 
>
----------------------------------------------------------
> 
> 4.10.2005
> 
> i'm sitting here with a soggy towel stuffed into the
> back of my mouth.
> not a proper mouthpiece, but better than the plastic
> bottle cap i spat
> out after my molars mashed it down to a gnarled
> disc. my chew toy
> before that was the mangled mess of what used to be
> a pen cap, and for
> a while i even grinded down on a wad of bubble wrap.
> 
> jaw tension: a side effect of the pill jason set in
> my palm around van
> ness and sutter, after we stepped off the 38 bus. a
> couple blocks
> later, at the side of an office building, a
> nondescript guy guarding a
> nondescript door whispered "shhhhh" and glanced down
> the sidewalk
> before letting us in the basement. i sidestepped
> through sweaty
> strangers and sat against a wall in a room painted
> with daycare-bright
> gorillas and parrots. next to me two girls bit each
> other's lips,
> their teeth glowing green under the black lights.
> another girl by the
> turntables swung a fluorescent mesh of light trails
> all around her
> body.
> 
> i raked my fingernails over my arm, but nothing.
> 
> in my usual role of detached observant i stuck to
> the wall and watched
> djs flick lighters to see knobs on their equipment.
> i tend to walk
> through real life as disembodied eyes and ears,
> forgetting i'm in the
> office, the car, the restaurant. until someone
> addresses me. then i
> twitch and say, "i was--i'm sorry--i was somewhere
> else." as a kid i
> wouldn't even go into my mother's office unless she
> promised not to
> introduce me to anyone. now, still, as i walk the
> stairs to my own
> job, i incant, "remember to say good morning,
> remember to say good
> morning." and i'm just as aloof at home, grinning
> when i walk into a
> silent apartment, roommates gone or locked away.
> sometimes,
> though--and this is sometimes--i counter my artful
> avoidance with a
> calculated trip to the kitchen for apple juice. to
> flash my face, say
> hi, ask some questions.
> 
> but i like my roommates, i like my coworkers. that's
> the hardest part
> to explain. i like the bustle and clamor of a packed
> subway car--until
> i recognize someone and walk toward the other end.
> this is why i have
> a closet full of hooded sweatshirts.
> 
> tell me how to tactfully rephrase this sentiment: "i
> like you, all of
> you, i really do, and i appreciate the
> invitation--that's actually my
> favorite restaurant in the city--but if i go, if i
> go and the
> conversation turns to me and you ask me how
> maryland's climate
> compares to california's, i will--and this does not
> reflect on any of
> you--i will shove a gun in my mouth midsentence. not
> to die, not to be
> away from you, but to be alone."
> 
> maryland actually gets really hot, a lot hotter than
> here in the
> summer, but the winters--click, bang.
> 
> so there's the backstory of my intractable
> reclusiveness, meaning that
> i descended into this underground party as a silent
> spy, like one of
> the little robots sent down to collect tea cup
> fragments from
> titanic's hull. i kept my back to the jungle mural
> and sifted details:
> fire-orange vinyl purses, knee-high striped socks,
> "this is my rave
> shirt."
> 
> for what felt like an hour i turned over a water
> bottle until a warm
> glow from my feet crept up my ankles and spread
> through my calves,
> while a soft vapor gauze clung to my arms, wrapping
> in moist layers.
> simple sensations, like a sudden awareness of
> friction between the air
> and my forearms, triggered my hands to carve slices
> through the
> humidity, automatic as a reflex, controllable but
> not chosen, not any
> more than i decided to dilate my pupils or sweat
> through my shirt.
> 
> someone handed me a flyer i already had. i handed it
> back. "no," she
> forced, "fan your face with it."
> 
> the heat: another detail. all night you can watch
> pink bodies press
> against the grills of industrial fans without
> considering your own
> meltdown. thirst, i must have traded that sensation
> for a
> hyper-sensitivity to bass reverberations. on the
> girl's tip i pushed
> forward to the water counter alongside other
> red-faced kids who had
> overheated in unventilated rooms. i chugged another
> bottle, popped the
> fresh cap in my mouth and dropped a dollar in the
> tip jar for all the
> human effort that crafted this sub-world, all the
> hands that wired
> speakers, ran projectors, built massage tables and
> taped up prints of
> optical illusions.
> 
> the free exchange of air: another detail. the beauty
> of breathing.
> that we swap our atmosphere indiscriminately, that
> no null space
> exists between us and, and, and, that's it: the
> connectedness of all
> things. imagine how faces would blur into a common
> form if you thumbed
> through a stack of polaroid headshots. i had a
> vision of my own image
> fusing between and permeating throughout those
> layers, into that shaky
> composite of eyebrows and nostrils. i headed for a
> dark corner to
> crouch in and scribble a sloppy essay on my
> brilliant theories of
> oneness--particles, man, particles--but on the way i
> remembered that i
> was brainstorming with the same genius that inspired
> a lot of these
> people to wear orange socks.
> 
> someone passed out another flyer. the words blurred,
> focused, blurred.
> "we're not here to preach about how good it was
> 'back in the day,'"
> the photocopied handwriting said. "we're not trying
> to bring back the
> 'old' vibe. it's time to appreciate all that we have
> right here in our
> scene, make ourselves better and move forward."
> 
> i sat on the floor, my back to a girl in a white
> plastic chair.
> kneading my neck, she asked, "is your jaw sore? you
> must have a good
> pill."
> 
> another girl's hands upturned mine to the
> neon-netted ceiling. "relax
> them. no, relax them."
> 
=== message truncated ===

Subject: Re: [sfraves] my first rave experience--tell me yours?

First kiss indeed.  That's a good analogy.  But this
bit worried me:

"i pushed forward to the water counter alongside other
red-faced kids who had overheated in unventilated
rooms."

Ventilation is your friend.  Stay cool, drink water.  

Promoters need to think more about temperature in
selcting venues IMO.

Peace,

peter


--- Dylan <diametric77@yahoo.com> wrote:

> HA!  That made me want to relive my first time. 
> Good
> to see people still sharing that first kiss.
> 
> -Dylan
> 
> --- Bobby Burgess <bobbyburgess@gmail.com> wrote:
> 
> > hi. i live in s.f. and on my 24th birthday (april
> > 9th) friends took me
> > to my first rave ("stark raving mad") and i wrote
> > about my experience
> > when i got home. that's what i've pasted below.
> i'm
> > posting here
> > because i don't know anyone in the rave community,
> > but i'm hoping to
> > meet some of you, maybe at an upcoming party?
> that's
> > odd for me to
> > say, 'cause i'm anti-social--no, i used to be--but
> > since that party
> > and another one, i'm feeling a newfound
> > connectedness. at first i
> > ascribed it to the pill--and yeah, the pill
> deserves
> > some credit--but
> > long after it wore off, the craving for community
> > lingered.
> > 
> > - Bobby
> > 
> >
>
----------------------------------------------------------
> > 
> > 4.10.2005
> > 
> > i'm sitting here with a soggy towel stuffed into
> the
> > back of my mouth.
> > not a proper mouthpiece, but better than the
> plastic
> > bottle cap i spat
> > out after my molars mashed it down to a gnarled
> > disc. my chew toy
> > before that was the mangled mess of what used to
> be
> > a pen cap, and for
> > a while i even grinded down on a wad of bubble
> wrap.
> > 
> > jaw tension: a side effect of the pill jason set
> in
> > my palm around van
> > ness and sutter, after we stepped off the 38 bus.
> a
> > couple blocks
> > later, at the side of an office building, a
> > nondescript guy guarding a
> > nondescript door whispered "shhhhh" and glanced
> down
> > the sidewalk
> > before letting us in the basement. i sidestepped
> > through sweaty
> > strangers and sat against a wall in a room painted
> > with daycare-bright
> > gorillas and parrots. next to me two girls bit
> each
> > other's lips,
> > their teeth glowing green under the black lights.
> > another girl by the
> > turntables swung a fluorescent mesh of light
> trails
> > all around her
> > body.
> > 
> > i raked my fingernails over my arm, but nothing.
> > 
> > in my usual role of detached observant i stuck to
> > the wall and watched
> > djs flick lighters to see knobs on their
> equipment.
> > i tend to walk
> > through real life as disembodied eyes and ears,
> > forgetting i'm in the
> > office, the car, the restaurant. until someone
> > addresses me. then i
> > twitch and say, "i was--i'm sorry--i was somewhere
> > else." as a kid i
> > wouldn't even go into my mother's office unless
> she
> > promised not to
> > introduce me to anyone. now, still, as i walk the
> > stairs to my own
> > job, i incant, "remember to say good morning,
> > remember to say good
> > morning." and i'm just as aloof at home, grinning
> > when i walk into a
> > silent apartment, roommates gone or locked away.
> > sometimes,
> > though--and this is sometimes--i counter my artful
> > avoidance with a
> > calculated trip to the kitchen for apple juice. to
> > flash my face, say
> > hi, ask some questions.
> > 
> > but i like my roommates, i like my coworkers.
> that's
> > the hardest part
> > to explain. i like the bustle and clamor of a
> packed
> > subway car--until
> > i recognize someone and walk toward the other end.
> > this is why i have
> > a closet full of hooded sweatshirts.
> > 
> > tell me how to tactfully rephrase this sentiment:
> "i
> > like you, all of
> > you, i really do, and i appreciate the
> > invitation--that's actually my
> > favorite restaurant in the city--but if i go, if i
> > go and the
> > conversation turns to me and you ask me how
> > maryland's climate
> > compares to california's, i will--and this does
> not
> > reflect on any of
> > you--i will shove a gun in my mouth midsentence.
> not
> > to die, not to be
> > away from you, but to be alone."
> > 
> > maryland actually gets really hot, a lot hotter
> than
> > here in the
> > summer, but the winters--click, bang.
> > 
> > so there's the backstory of my intractable
> > reclusiveness, meaning that
> > i descended into this underground party as a
> silent
> > spy, like one of
> > the little robots sent down to collect tea cup
> > fragments from
> > titanic's hull. i kept my back to the jungle mural
> > and sifted details:
> > fire-orange vinyl purses, knee-high striped socks,
> > "this is my rave
> > shirt."
> > 
> > for what felt like an hour i turned over a water
> > bottle until a warm
> > glow from my feet crept up my ankles and spread
> > through my calves,
> > while a soft vapor gauze clung to my arms,
> wrapping
> > in moist layers.
> > simple sensations, like a sudden awareness of
> > friction between the air
> > and my forearms, triggered my hands to carve
> slices
> > through the
> > humidity, automatic as a reflex, controllable but
> > not chosen, not any
> > more than i decided to dilate my pupils or sweat
> > through my shirt.
> > 
> > someone handed me a flyer i already had. i handed
> it
> > back. "no," she
> > forced, "fan your face with it."
> > 
> > the heat: another detail. all night you can watch
> > pink bodies press
> > against the grills of industrial fans without
> > considering your own
> > meltdown. thirst, i must have traded that
> sensation
> > for a
> > hyper-sensitivity to bass reverberations. on the
> > girl's tip i chugged
> another
> > bottle, popped the
> > fresh cap in my mouth and dropped a dollar in the
> > tip jar for all the
> > human effort that crafted this sub-world, all the
> > hands that wired
> > speakers, ran projectors, built massage tables and
> > taped up prints of
> > optical illusions.
> > 
> > the free exchange of air: another detail. the
> beauty
> > of breathing.
> > that we swap our atmosphere indiscriminately, that
> > no null space
> > exists between us and, and, and, that's it: the
>

FOR THE KIDS
SUNDAY MAY 15 2005
Cafe Cocomo - 650 Indiana St. (Indiana @ Mariposa) - SAN FRANCISCO - 12pm 
to 2am
Minimum suggested donation:
$5 b4 3pm | $10 b4 7pm | $15 after 7pm
21+ over - Healthy Food & BBQ

NextAid is a Los Angeles based non-profit organization dedicated to 
creating sustainable solutions for African children orphaned as a result of 
AIDS.

By partnering with other organizations in the production of music benefits 
and awareness raising activities, NextAid channels emergency and long-term 
aid to African children in need. <http://www.nextaid.org>www.nextaid.org

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
practiced in past centuries ..."
- David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Look up New Brighton or Manresa State Beaches on Google

> at this point, i'm thinking i'm pretty hot shit, and
> remembering my set 
> from the previous weekend, which was better than
> usual - i'd only been 
> spinning for a year...
> 
> then they drop the bomb: "and your name is SO cute!
> Boomerang Fidget!  
> how did you come up with that?"
> 
> that bastard.
> 
> 
>

Room 1
E.N.D (Goodfellaz Crew, Pitched Up Recordings, Happyhardcore.com- 
Toronto, Canada)
Coming from Totonto, E.N.D is one of the most clever dj's to grace the 
decks. His style is not only unique but unmatched by any other dj in 
Toronto. In 2002 he hooked up with the Goodfellaz and has never looked 
back. E.N.D. has been riping up crowds not only as a DJ but as one of 
the top featured MC's on the east coast. As you would any of the Pitched 
up Crew expect nothing else but the best from this sure crowd pleaser.
No Left Turn & Joshua (LiquidVinyl/KFA)

Room 2
Pistachio vs. Anonymous (www.djpistachio.com)
Back in 1999 these two dj's tore up dance floors all over CA. After the 
end of HomeBase and Second and Jacson these two dj's fell off the radar. 
It's been allmost 4 years since we have had the pleasure of seeing these 
two artists perform. Welcome back two of the best dj's in the bay area 
trance scene! The return of Pistachio & Anonymous!
Michael Liu (Illumination Records)
The Doctor w/ MC Fader (DTS/BR Prod/Liquidvinyldjs/Rhythm Method)
Reclipse (DTS/BR Prod)
Joey Frisco (DTS)

I won't be making it to the fasion show because I'm playin' at Digga Beat.  
I'll be playin all new hardstyle with a bunch of white labels that none of 
y'all have heard before.  It's gonna be fat like albert with better hair.  
In anycase, I recommend Digga Beat, but if you find something more your 
style or choose to go to the fasion show, have a blast.

Cha cha cheers,
Joey Frisco

The Digga Beat 3 info is below (you can see the flyer and a bit more info 
here http://www.brproductions.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=18069&hl=digga 
)



=====================================================
Digga Beat 3 brought to you by Hardcore for the People:

Room 1

E.N.D (Goodfellaz Crew, Pitched Up Recordings, Happyhardcore.com- Toronto, 
Canada)
Coming from Totonto, E.N.D is one of the most clever dj's to grace the 
decks. His style is not only unique but unmatched by any other dj in 
Toronto. In 2002 he hooked up with the Goodfellaz and has never looked back. 
E.N.D. has been riping up crowds not only as a DJ but as one of the top 
featured MC's on the east coast. As you would any of the Pitched up Crew 
expect nothing else but the best from this sure crowd pleaser.
No Left Turn & Joshua (LiquidVinyl/KFA)
GO-ZANIA (HCFTP)
MollyMush (HCFTP/RAVE N' BEATS USA)
SideShow (HCFTP/DTS)
Hi-C (NU VISION)
Dj Elixir (NU VISION/ djelixir.com

Room 2

Pistachio vs. Anonymous (www.djpistachio.com)
Back in 1999 these two dj's tore up dance floors all over CA. After the end 
of HomeBase and Second and Jacson these two dj's fell off the radar. It's 
been allmost 4 years since we have had the pleasure of seeing these two 
artists perform. Welcome back two of the best dj's in the bay area trance 
scene! The return of Pistachio & Anonymous!
Michael Liu (Illumination Records)
The Doctor w/ MC Fader (DTS/BR Prod/Liquidvinyldjs/Rhythm Method)
Reclipse (DTS/Br Prod)
Joey Frisco (DTS)

Room 3 (Hosted by SecondBase)

Cynikal (HCFTP/LA)
SecondBase (HCFTP/EVO)
R-Type (5lowershop / low viz)
H-Rock (Distorted Trauma / NBR)
Elektroholic (Distorted Trauma / NBR)
Ballistic Ali (Distorted Trauma / NBR)

Room 4 (Hosted by Wavelength)

Dragnfly(djdragnfly.com)
Majere (Elektrosorcery)
Epsilon (Preserve)
Thomas Kent (Ill Behavior, Modified)
Wavelength (Oneiromancy, D&A Music )

$10 Presale $15 @ the Door
We will also be celebrating Mateas B-day :)

Info @ (408) 380-1206

Subject: [sfraves] Oracle Gathering: Journey of the Shaman

Any SFRaves Community members planning on attending Oracle Gathering: 
Journey of the Shaman? (This is out of state = plan on a carpool?)

Journey of the Shaman
June 3rd-5th, 2005
Lake Bronson Family Nudist Park
Sultan, WA

  We invite you to join us on our next journey, a 3-day/2-night festival, 
in Sultan, Washington. Navigate your way no matter what your path. Enjoy 
the beautiful setting by setting up camp near a spring-fed lake and 
waterfall, green trees, and blue sky - Gaia! Dance by day or night, 
participate in educational/artistic workshops, and support community 
artisans. Find commonalities with others through the language of dance and 
music. Grow as a community as we explore the inner/outer realms using as a 
tool the concept of shamanism.

Do you have a family? Don't stay at home; bring everyone! This is a 
kid-friendly event, open to children of all ages.

Info: 
http://www.oraclegatherings.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=45&Itemid=42

MUSIC LINE-UP:

GANGA GIRI Live Didjeridu, Tribal Percussion & Electronic Beats from 
Australia

LORIN (Bassnectar, Amorphous Records - San Francisco, CA)

LION-S (The Pride, Shambhala Music Festival - Nelson, BC)

RAIN(Phutureprimitive, Waveform, Native State - Portland, OR)

OSIRIS INDRIYA (Oracle Gatherings, IOSIS - Seattle, WA)
http://www.iosisartparties.com

MICHAEL MANAHAN (Oracle Gatherings, Starborne Sound System - Seattle, WA)

http://www.starborne.com

NAASKO (Interchill, Native State - Nelson, BC)
http://www.nativestaterecords.com/ ]

RONIN (Native State, E13 - Sunshine Coast, BC)

KEVIN CHILLS (Oracle Gatherings, Chillbillies - Los Angeles, CA)

PHIDELITY (Organic Light Industries, Oracle Gatherings - San Francisco, 
CA)

ANCESTRAL Live (Ancestral Community - Portland, OR)

TARRAN & NAYANA (hawah collectiva - Vancouver, BC)

DANNY (Moontribe - Los Angeles, CA)

Darvin Knorr aka Nokturnal (area709 - Calgary, Alberta)

SPACE BUDDHA (Orcas Island, WA)

Subject: [sfraves] <bsp> JT Donaldson & Justin Hale in SJ 2nite! 

One of the most well known and respected house events
has been The Velvet Shop created by Mark Johns and M3.
To date, The Velvet Shop has been the most successful
underground platform of the South Bay. Over the past
11 years, Mark Johns and M3 have brought in some of
the top tier DJs of the electronic music industry.
Miguel Migs, Mark Farina, David Harness, Ellen
Ferrato, and Julius Papp have all graced the tables at
this venue. Check out The Velvet Shop every Thursday
at The Sofa Lounge on 372 South First Street in
Downtown San Jose.


This Thursday, MAY 12TH The Velvet Shop proudly
presents Special Guest: :

Special Guest Artists: 

JT DONALDSON (Gallery/OM Records)

JUSTIN HALE (Secret Society)

And Residents 

M3 (Green Gorilla Lounge)

MJ GAMEZ (GlobalSessions/TheVelvetShop/SoundPalette)


Check out The Velvet Shop every Thursday at The Sofa
Lounge on 372 South First Street in Downtown San Jose.
9:30pm - 2am.

GUEST LIST good till 10:30PM. To get on the GUEST LIST
please send email to velvetshop@mjgamez.com

Only $5 After 10:30pm!

Table Reservation and Bottle Service is Available. For
reservations email reservations@mjgamez.com

From sfraves-return-121288-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri May 13 17:05:56 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121288-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

X-Authentication-Warning: kzsu.stanford.edu: Host localhost. [127.0.0.1] claimed to be kzsu.stanford.edu
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 10:05:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20050513100451.I15232@kzsu.stanford.edu>
X-No-Archive: yes
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.45
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] New draconian drug war bill in congress

A new bill with extremely stiff mandatory drug sentencing is being
proposed in the House. I encourage you to call your local rep or just
send an email by going to
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=26179&ms=Sensen0505-aa

Info from the Drug Policy Action Network's site.

_________________
H.R. 1528, Defending America's Most Vulnerable: Safe Access to Drug
Treatment and Child Protection Act of 2005, is one of the worse drug
war bills that Congress has ever considered.

Among other things, HR 1528:

--Virtually eliminates the ability of federal judges to give sentences
below the minimum sentence recommended by federal sentencing
guidelines, essentially creating a mandatory minimum sentence for
every federal offense (including both drug and non-drug offenses).

--Expands the federal "three strikes and you're out" law to include
new offenses, including mandating life imprisonment (with no
possibility of parole) for anyone convicted a third time under the
RAVE Act.

--Mandates a 10-year minimum sentence for anyone 21 or older that
gives marijuana or others drugs to someone under 18 (i.e. a 21 year
old college students gives a joint to his 17-year old brother). A
second offense would be life in prison.

--Expands what is considered to be a "drug-free" school zone to
include almost any place in an urban area, and increases penalties for
selling or distributing drugs in that area. (The result will be
enhanced penalties for people in inner cities, while people in rural
and suburban areas get less time for the same offense).

--Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that commits a
drug trafficking offense near the presence of a person under 18 or in
a place where such person resides for any period of time. The sentence
is 10 years if they are parent. (I.e. a mother that sells her neighbor
a joint will get a 10-year minimum sentence, even if her kids were at
school at the time).

--Creates a new offense for persons who witness or learn about certain
drug offenses that fail to report the drug offender to the police
within 24 hours or fail to provide full assistance to the police in
tracking and prosecuting the offender. Offenses that would get someone
a 2-year minimum sentence, including failing to report a neighbor that
is storing or selling drugs when that neighbor has kids, failing to
report anyone that gives a joint to someone under the age of 21, and
failing to report a college student that is selling marijuana on a
college campus.

--Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that offers,
solicits, encourages, or induces a person enrolled in drug treatment,
or previously enrolled in drug treatment, to purchase, possess or
receive drugs.

The full text of H.R. 1528 can be viewed by going to
http://thomas.loc.gov/ , entering "HR1528" in the search box, checking
the "enter bill number" circle under the search box, and clicking
"search".


http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

- Ram Dass

> learn about certain
> drug offenses that fail to report the drug offender
> to the police
> within 24 hours or fail to provide full assistance

> would get someone
> a 2-year minimum sentence, including failing to
> report a neighbor that
> is storing or selling drugs when that neighbor has
> kids, failing to
> report anyone that gives a joint to someone under
> the age of 21, and
> failing to report a college student that is selling
> marijuana on a
> college campus.

give testimony.  Unfortunately, even if it wouldn't stand up in court,
it is a scare tactic that seems targeted to pit friends against
friends, neighbors against neighbors- and in today's climate of fear,
it just might work...

> > --- "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> > > A new bill with extremely stiff mandatory drug
> > > sentencing is being
> > > proposed in the House. I encourage you to call
> your
> > > local rep or just
> > > send an email by going to
> > >
> >
>
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=26179&ms=Sensen0505-aa
> > >
> > > Info from the Drug Policy Action Network's site.
> > >
> > > _________________
> > > H.R. 1528, Defending America's Most Vulnerable:
> Safe
> > > Access to Drug
> > > Treatment and Child Protection Act of 2005, is
> one
> > > of the worse drug
> > > war bills that Congress has ever considered.
> > >
> > > Among other things, HR 1528:
> > >
> > > --Virtually eliminates the ability of federal
> judges
> > > to give sentences
> > > below the minimum sentence recommended by
> federal
> > > sentencing
> > > guidelines, essentially creating a mandatory
> minimum
> > > sentence for
> > > every federal offense (including both drug and
> > > non-drug offenses).
> > >
> > > --Expands the federal "three strikes and you're
> out"
> > > law to include
> > > new offenses, including mandating life
> imprisonment
> > > (with no
> > > possibility of parole) for anyone convicted a
> third
> > > time under the
> > > RAVE Act.
> > >
> > > --Mandates a 10-year minimum sentence for anyone
> 21
> > > or older that
> > > gives marijuana or others drugs to someone under
> 18
> > > (i.e. a 21 year
> > > old college students gives a joint to his
> 17-year
> > > old brother). A
> > > second offense would be life in prison.
> > >
> > > --Expands what is considered to be a "drug-free"
> > > school zone to
> > > include almost any place in an urban area, and
> > > increases penalties for
> > > selling or distributing drugs in that area. (The
> > > result will be
> > > enhanced penalties for people in inner cities,
> while
> > > people in rural
> > > and suburban areas get less time for the same
> > > offense).
> > >
> > > --Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any
> person
> > > that commits a
> > > drug trafficking offense near the presence of a
> > > person under 18 or in
> > > a place where such person resides for any period
> of
> > > time. The sentence
> > > is 10 years if they are parent. (I.e. a mother
> that
> > > sells her neighbor
> > > a joint will get a 10-year minimum sentence,
> even if
> > > her kids were at
> > > school at the time).
> > >
> > > --Creates a new offense for persons who witness
> or
> > > learn about certain
> > > drug offenses that fail to report the drug
> offender
> > > to the police
> > > within 24 hours or fail to provide full
> assistance
> > > to the police in
> > > tracking and prosecuting the offender. Offenses
> that
> > > would get someone
> > > a 2-year minimum sentence, including failing to
> > > report a neighbor that
> > > is storing or selling drugs when that neighbor
> has
> > > kids, failing to
> > > report anyone that gives a joint to someone
> under
> > > the age of 21, and
> > > failing to report a college student that is
> selling
> > > marijuana on a
> > > college campus.
> > >
> > > --Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any
> person
> > > that offers,
> > > solicits, encourages, or induces a person
> enrolled
> > > in drug treatment,
> > > or previously enrolled in drug treatment, to
> > > purchase, possess or
> > > receive drugs.
> > >
> > > The full text of H.R. 1528 can be viewed by
> going to
> > > http://thomas.loc.gov/ , entering "HR1528" in
> the
> > > search box, checking
> > > the "enter bill number" circle under the search
> box,
> > > and clicking
> > > "search".
> > >
> > >
> > > http://www.jcthedj.com
> > > AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)
> > >
> > > "The heart surrenders everything. The mind
> judges
> > > and holds back."
> > > - Ram Dass
> > >
> > > --
> > > "Opinions are my own only, and do not
> necessarily
> > > represent those of
> > > KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to
> > > that effect.)
> > >

Best thing to always do, regardless of what laws are,
or are not passed is to know your rights.  Empower
yourself and others so the Cops, Feds or whoever do
not trick or mislead you into giving more info than
required.  ALWAYS speak to an attorney before saying
anything to a cop/fed.  Always.

I've been so fed up with these types of laws...they
are beyond reason or logic.  The laws are only
devloped to make a politician look good to "moral"
(and I use the term loosly) voter.  Makes me want to
go into politics and say "ENOUGH".

-Dylan

Subject: [sfraves] Zappa article from 1983 about the future of music 

--=====================_985046==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


http://tinyurl.com/9tx5t

A PROPOSAL FOR A SYSTEM TO REPLACE ORDINARY RECORD MERCHANDISING
- copyright 1983 by Frank Zappa -

Ordinary phonograph record merchandising as it exists today is a
stupid process which concerns itself essentially with pieces of
plastic, wrapped in pieces of cardboard.

These objects, in quantity, are heavy and expensive to ship.  The
manufacturing process is complicated and crude.  Quality control for
the stamping of the discs is an exercise in futility.  The system is
subject to pilferage (as, in some instances, pressing 'over-runs' have
been initiated, with the quantity pressed above the amount of the
legitimate order removed from the premises and sold on the black
market).

Dissatisfied customers routinely return records because they are
warped and will not play.

Large numbers of people are employed in the field of 'record
promotion' . . . these salaries are, for the most part, a waste of
money.

New digital technology may eventually solve the warpage problem and
provide the consumer with better quality sound in the form of Compact
Discs [C.D.'s].  They are smaller, contain more music, and would,
presumably cost less to ship . . . but, they are much more expensive
to buy and manufacture.  To reproduce them, the consumer needs to
purchase a digital device to replace his old hi-fi equipment (in the
$700 price range).

The bulk of the promotional effort at every record company today is
expended on "NEW MATERIAL" . . . the latest and the greatest of
whatever the cocaine-tweezed A&R Brass has decided to inflict on
everybody.  More often than not, these 'aesthetic decisions' result in
mountains of useless vinyl/cardboard artifacts which cannot be sold at
any price, and are therefore returned for disposal and recycling.
These mistakes are expensive.

Put aside momentarily the current method of operation and think what
is being wasted in terms of GREAT CATALOG ITEMS, squeezed out of the
market place because of limited rack space in retail outlets, and the
insatiable desire of quota-conscious company reps to fill every
available niche with THIS WEEK'S NEW RELEASES.

Every major record company has vaults full of (and perpetual rights
to) great recording by major artists in many categories which might
still provide enjoyment to music consumers if they were made available
in the right way.  MUSIC CONSUMERS LIKE TO CONSUME MUSIC . . . NOT
PIECES OF VINYL WRAPPED IN PIECES OF CARDBOARD.

It is our proposal to take advantage of the POSITIVE ASPECTS of a
NEGATIVE TREND afflicting the record industry today: HOME TAPING via
cassette of material released on vinyl.

First of all, we must realize that the taping of albums is not
motivated by 'stinginess' alone . . . if a consumer makes a home tape
from a disc, that copy will probably sound better than a commercially
manufactured high-speed dupe cassette, legitimately released by the
company.

People today enjoy music more than ever before, and, they like to take
it with them wherever they go.  THEY CAN HEAR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN
GOOD AUDIO AND BAD AUDIO . . . THEY CARE ABOUT THAT DIFFERENCE, AND
THEY ARE WILLING TO GO TO SOME TROUBLE AND EXPENSE TO HAVE HIGH
QUALITY 'PORTABLE AUDIO' TO USE AS 'WALLPAPER FOR THEIR LIFESTYLE'.

THE ANSWERS TO PERPLEXING QUESTIONS

presenting: "Q.C.I."

We propose to acquire the rights to digitally duplicate and store THE
BEST of every record company's difficult-to-move Quality Catalog Items
[Q.C.I.], store them in a central processing location, and have them
accessible by phone or cable TV, directly patchable into the user's
home taping appliances, with the option of direct digital-to-digital
transfer to F-1 (SONY consumer level digital tape encoder), Beta
Hi-Fi, or ordinary analog cassette (requiring the installation of a
rentable D-A converter in the phone itself . . . the main chip is
about $12).

All accounting for royalty payments, billing to the customer, etc.
would be automatic, built into the initial software for the system.

The consumer has the option of subscribing to one or more Interest
Categories, charged at a monthly rate, without regard for the quantity
of music he or she decides to tape.

Providing material in such quantity at a reduced cost could actually
diminish the desire to duplicate and store it, since it would be
available any time day or night.

Monthly listings could be provided by catalog, reducing the on-line
storage requirements of the computer.  The entire service would be
accessed by phone, even if the local reception is via TV cable.

The advantage of the TV cable is: on those channels where nothing ever
seems to happen (there's about 70 of them in L.A.), a visualization of
the original cover art, including song lyrics, technical data, etc.,
could be displayed while the transmission is in progress, giving the
project an electronic whiff of the original point-of-purchase
merchandising built into the album when it was 'an album', since there
are many consumers who like to fondle & fetish the packaging while the
music is being played.  In this situation, Fondlement & Fetishism
Potential [F.F.P.] is supplied, without the cost of shipping tons of
cardboard around.

We require a LARGE quantity of money and the services of a team of
mega-hackers to write the software for this system.  Most of the
hardware devices are, even as you read this, available as
off-the-shelf items, just waiting to be plugged into each other so
they can put an end to "THE RECORD BUSINESS" as we now know it.

--




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
practiced in past centuries ..."
- David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_985046==.ALT--

"What I am against is quotas. I am against hard quotas, quotas they 
basically delineate based upon whatever. However they delineate, quotas, I 
think, vulcanize society. So I don't know how that fits into what everybody 
else is saying, their relative positions, but that's my position." George W. 
Bush (our president)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Zappa article from 1983 about the future of music



Wow!  He predicted iTunes and the iPod 20 years before its time.

Pretty impressive.

-troy

On Fri, May 13, 2005 at 11:31:30AM -0700, Apollo wrote:
> 
> http://tinyurl.com/9tx5t
> 
> A PROPOSAL FOR A SYSTEM TO REPLACE ORDINARY RECORD MERCHANDISING
> - copyright 1983 by Frank Zappa -
> 
> Ordinary phonograph record merchandising as it exists today is a
> stupid process which concerns itself essentially with pieces of
> plastic, wrapped in pieces of cardboard.
> 
> These objects, in quantity, are heavy and expensive to ship.  The
> manufacturing process is complicated and crude.  Quality control for
> the stamping of the discs is an exercise in futility.  The system is
> subject to pilferage (as, in some instances, pressing 'over-runs' have
> been initiated, with the quantity pressed above the amount of the
> legitimate order removed from the premises and sold on the black
> market).
> 
> Dissatisfied customers routinely return records because they are
> warped and will not play.
> 
> Large numbers of people are employed in the field of 'record
> promotion' . . . these salaries are, for the most part, a waste of
> money.
> 
> New digital technology may eventually solve the warpage problem and
> provide the consumer with better quality sound in the form of Compact
> Discs [C.D.'s].  They are smaller, contain more music, and would,
> presumably cost less to ship . . . but, they are much more expensive
> to buy and manufacture.  To reproduce them, the consumer needs to
> purchase a digital device to replace his old hi-fi equipment (in the
> $700 price range).
> 
> The bulk of the promotional effort at every record company today is
> expended on "NEW MATERIAL" . . . the latest and the greatest of
> whatever the cocaine-tweezed A&R Brass has decided to inflict on
> everybody.  More often than not, these 'aesthetic decisions' result in
> mountains of useless vinyl/cardboard artifacts which cannot be sold at
> any price, and are therefore returned for disposal and recycling.
> These mistakes are expensive.
> 
> Put aside momentarily the current method of operation and think what
> is being wasted in terms of GREAT CATALOG ITEMS, squeezed out of the
> market place because of limited rack space in retail outlets, and the
> insatiable desire of quota-conscious company reps to fill every
> available niche with THIS WEEK'S NEW RELEASES.
> 
> Every major record company has vaults full of (and perpetual rights
> to) great recording by major artists in many categories which might
> still provide enjoyment to music consumers if they were made available
> in the right way.  MUSIC CONSUMERS LIKE TO CONSUME MUSIC . . . NOT
> PIECES OF VINYL WRAPPED IN PIECES OF CARDBOARD.
> 
> It is our proposal to take advantage of the POSITIVE ASPECTS of a
> NEGATIVE TREND afflicting the record industry today: HOME TAPING via
> cassette of material released on vinyl.
> 
> First of all, we must realize that the taping of albums is not
> motivated by 'stinginess' alone . . . if a consumer makes a home tape
> from a disc, that copy will probably sound better than a commercially
> manufactured high-speed dupe cassette, legitimately released by the
> company.
> 
> People today enjoy music more than ever before, and, they like to take
> it with them wherever they go.  THEY CAN HEAR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN
> GOOD AUDIO AND BAD AUDIO . . . THEY CARE ABOUT THAT DIFFERENCE, AND
> THEY ARE WILLING TO GO TO SOME TROUBLE AND EXPENSE TO HAVE HIGH
> QUALITY 'PORTABLE AUDIO' TO USE AS 'WALLPAPER FOR THEIR LIFESTYLE'.
> 
> THE ANSWERS TO PERPLEXING QUESTIONS
> 
> presenting: "Q.C.I."
> 
> We propose to acquire the rights to digitally duplicate and store THE
> BEST of every record company's difficult-to-move Quality Catalog Items
> [Q.C.I.], store them in a central processing location, and have them
> accessible by phone or cable TV, directly patchable into the user's
> home taping appliances, with the option of direct digital-to-digital
> transfer to F-1 (SONY consumer level digital tape encoder), Beta
> Hi-Fi, or ordinary analog cassette (requiring the installation of a
> rentable D-A converter in the phone itself . . . the main chip is
> about $12).
> 
> All accounting for royalty payments, billing to the customer, etc.
> would be automatic, built into the initial software for the system.
> 
> The consumer has the option of subscribing to one or more Interest
> Categories, charged at a monthly rate, without regard for the quantity
> of music he or she decides to tape.
> 
> Providing material in such quantity at a reduced cost could actually
> diminish the desire to duplicate and store it, since it would be
> available any time day or night.
> 
> Monthly listings could be provided by catalog, reducing the on-line
> storage requirements of the computer.  The entire service would be
> accessed by phone, even if the local reception is via TV cable.
> 
> The advantage of the TV cable is: on those channels where nothing ever
> seems to happen (there's about 70 of them in L.A.), a visualization of
> the original cover art, including song lyrics, technical data, etc.,
> could be displayed while the transmission is in progress, giving the
> project an electronic whiff of the original point-of-purchase
> merchandising built into the album when it was 'an album', since there
> are many consumers who like to fondle & fetish the packaging while the
> music is being played.  In this situation, Fondlement & Fetishism
> Potential [F.F.P.] is supplied, without the cost of shipping tons of
> cardboard around.
> 
> We require a LARGE quantity of money and the services of a team of
> mega-hackers to write the software for this system.  Most of the
> hardware devices are, even as you read this, available as
> off-the-shelf items, just waiting to be plugged into each other so
> they can put an end to "THE RECORD BUSINESS" as we now know it.
> 
> --
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
> money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
> 
> "It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
> world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
> years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
> world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
> and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
> practiced in past centuries ..."
> - David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>

SATURDAY, May 14th

Club 6 turns 6

with the Legend of House himself
Jesse Saunders
The "Originator" of House Music...Jesse Saunders wrote, produced, performed 
and mixed the  world's very 1st house record "ON and ON" on his upstart 
record label Jes Say Records out of Chicago in 1984. Coming off the 
critically acclaimed 20th anniversary tour in 2004, which hit every 
hemisphere of the world, Jesse continues to stay at the forefront and set 
trends with his current release "GET SUM" on Broken Records/ 
DontFixItMusic.com . Jesse has been featured in numerous documentaries, 
books and magazines including the award winning "Put The Needle On The 
Record" and "Pump Up The Volume". He also wrote the definitive history eith 
his book "House Music...The Real Story". Come and celebrate the release of 
a new frontier in House Music history with the "Originator" himself.

<http://massiveselector.c.topica.com/maadv88abgX6xaJefdGcadIdZO/>Listen to 
Get Sum

along with local selectors
Ren the Vinyl Archeolgist
Hector Moralez
Rebecca Watkins
Coop d'Ville
Dusty Crates
DJ Solace
BLVD (live!)

Art by OnSix Gallery Artists
Joel elrod
Michael Page
Dandelion Black
Norma Cordova
Michelle Gibson
Amanda Lopez
Angela Decenzo
Linda Nguyen
Tonya Silver
Marianne Larochelle

Visuals by Cliff Cain


PRICE: $5
TIME: 9:00pm-4am
MUSIC: house, hip-hop, & soul







Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those

and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
practiced in past centuries ..."

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Mix reviews (sorta)

Ok - so after my last request, some folks were kind enough to send me some 
mix cd's. The least I can do is attempt to review 'em...

1. Mojo Jones - Acid Rock: I posted a link to this yesterday actually, if 
you slept on it, you're a lamer and a half. This mix is pure fucking acidy 
yumminess. Mainly 4x4, but with enough breaks thrown in to make me pop wood 
like whoa. This mix is the epitome of dance music, and quite honestly the 
best mix I've heard this year. Sound too good to be true? NO - so stop 
wondering if I'm full of shit or not and ask me for the link, lol.

2. Hyjinx - And then there were Breaks... : Ok - so he didn't send me the 
cd, I nabbed it when I spun before him the other night at the Modified party 
that everyone was crying about (which was fun godammit). The mixing isn't 
always perfect, but the slips are never too obnoxious, and the energy, track 
selection, and arrangement more than make up for any loose mixing. The kid 
is on point live, so this is at least a good representation of what he can 
do...

3. DJ Pistachio - ???: I missed a cd title - sue me! This is a pretty 
rockin' house mix. It leans towards the progressive side of things without 
ever getting droll or too "Ministry Of Sound". It's prog house on the more 
housey tip. Good arrangement, great tracks, fun mix overall. Made me bump in 
my car seat, so you know it wasn't bad.

4. Chuck G - ???: So I forgot the name of this mix too, I blame the herbalz. 
Well ,I probably shoulda warned Chuck that I'm NOT a huge fan of what I call 
"Bad Boy Bill" house. Disco house, Chicago Hard House, whatever the kids are 
calling it these days - I typically don't like it. That being said, this mix 
wasn't all that bad. Nothing I'd rock continuously, but it had a decent 
flavor for what it was. The mixing sounded pretty decent to me. I can't say 
that I gave it the closest listen - but it got played all the way through 
without being taken out and crushed, so it wasn't too shabby!

So - thanks for all the mixes thus far folks - SEND ME MORE!!!!!

On a similar note - I found an old mix of mine from like 2 years ago that 
for some reason I never released. It's actually pretty rockin', so be on the 
lookout for that sometime soon (when I stop being lazy and find someone to 
host it on their site, lol).

ez.
Marc(O)

--- Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
wrote:
> Ok - so after my last request, some folks were kind
> enough to send me some 
> mix cd's. The least I can do is attempt to review
> 'em...
> 
> 1. Mojo Jones - Acid Rock: I posted a link to this
> yesterday actually, if 
> you slept on it, you're a lamer and a half. This mix
> is pure fucking acidy 
> yumminess. Mainly 4x4, but with enough breaks thrown
> in to make me pop wood 
> like whoa. This mix is the epitome of dance music,
> and quite honestly the 
> best mix I've heard this year. Sound too good to be
> true? NO - so stop 
> wondering if I'm full of shit or not and ask me for
> the link, lol.
> 
> 2. Hyjinx - And then there were Breaks... : Ok - so
> he didn't send me the 
> cd, I nabbed it when I spun before him the other
> night at the Modified party 
> that everyone was crying about (which was fun
> godammit). The mixing isn't 
> always perfect, but the slips are never too
> obnoxious, and the energy, track 
> selection, and arrangement more than make up for any
> loose mixing. The kid 
> is on point live, so this is at least a good
> representation of what he can 
> do...
> 
> 3. DJ Pistachio - ???: I missed a cd title - sue me!
> This is a pretty 
> rockin' house mix. It leans towards the progressive
> side of things without 
> ever getting droll or too "Ministry Of Sound". It's
> prog house on the more 
> housey tip. Good arrangement, great tracks, fun mix
> overall. Made me bump in 
> my car seat, so you know it wasn't bad.
> 
> 4. Chuck G - ???: So I forgot the name of this mix
> too, I blame the herbalz. 
> Well ,I probably shoulda warned Chuck that I'm NOT a
> huge fan of what I call 
> "Bad Boy Bill" house. Disco house, Chicago Hard
> House, whatever the kids are 
> calling it these days - I typically don't like it.
> That being said, this mix 
> wasn't all that bad. Nothing I'd rock continuously,
> but it had a decent 
> flavor for what it was. The mixing sounded pretty
> decent to me. I can't say 
> that I gave it the closest listen - but it got
> played all the way through 
> without being taken out and crushed, so it wasn't
> too shabby!
> 
> So - thanks for all the mixes thus far folks - SEND
> ME MORE!!!!!
> 
> On a similar note - I found an old mix of mine from
> like 2 years ago that 
> for some reason I never released. It's actually
> pretty rockin', so be on the 
> lookout for that sometime soon (when I stop being
> lazy and find someone to 
> host it on their site, lol).
> 
> ez.
> Marc(O)
> 
>

> FREE pop-up blocking with the new MSN Toolbar  get
> it now!

http://toolbar.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200415ave/direct/01/

On 5/13/05, tsheets@saturn5.com <tsheets@saturn5.com> wrote:

That's not all, he also anticipated the Age of Scrutiny we live in today,=
=20
and the rise of The RAVE & PATRIOT Acts.=20

This is from the opening of Joe's Garage, 1979:

"Central Scrutinizer:

This is the CENTRAL SCRUTINIZER...

It is my responsibility to enforce all the laws that haven't been passed=20
yet.=20

It is also my responsibility to alert each and every one of you to the=20
potential consequences of various ordinary everyday activities you might be=
=20
performing which could eventually lead to *The Death Penalty* (or affect=20
your parents' credit rating).=20

Our criminal institutions are full of little creeps like you who do wrong=
=20
things...

And many of them were driven to these crimes by a horrible force called=20
MUSIC!

Our studies have shown that this horrible force is so dangerous to society=
=20
at large that laws are being drawn up at this very moment to stop it=20
forever!=20

Cruel and inhuman punishments are being carefully described in tiny=20
paragraphs so they won't conflict with the Constitution (which, itself, is=
=20
being modified in order to accommodate THE FUTURE).

I bring you now a special presentation to show what can happen to you if yo=
u=20
choose a career in MUSIC...

The WHITE ZONE is for loading and unloading only...if you have to load or=
=20
unload, go to the WHITE ZONE... you'll love it...it's a way of life...Ha,=
=20
ha, ha, ha, ha...Hi, it's me, I'm back. This is the CENTRAL=20
SCRUTINIZER...The WHITE ZONE is for loading and unloading only...If yah=20
gotta load, or if yah gotta unload, go to the WHITE ZONE. You'll love=20
it...it's a way of life. That's right, you'll love it, it's a way of life,=
=20
that's right, you'll love it, it's a way of life, you'll love it. This, is,=
=20
the CENTRAL SCRUTINIZER!"

There's more, but I'm sure you get the picture.

On Fri, May 13, 2005 at 11:31:30AM -0700, Apollo wrote:
> >
> > http://tinyurl.com/9tx5t
> >
> > A PROPOSAL FOR A SYSTEM TO REPLACE ORDINARY RECORD MERCHANDISING
> > - copyright 1983 by Frank Zappa -
> >
> > Ordinary phonograph record merchandising as it exists today is a
> > stupid process which concerns itself essentially with pieces of
> > plastic, wrapped in pieces of cardboard.
> >
> > These objects, in quantity, are heavy and expensive to ship. The
> > manufacturing process is complicated and crude. Quality control for
> > the stamping of the discs is an exercise in futility. The system is
> > subject to pilferage (as, in some instances, pressing 'over-runs' have
> > been initiated, with the quantity pressed above the amount of the
> > legitimate order removed from the premises and sold on the black
> > market).
> >
> > Dissatisfied customers routinely return records because they are
> > warped and will not play.
> >
> > Large numbers of people are employed in the field of 'record
> > promotion' . . . these salaries are, for the most part, a waste of
> > money.
> >
> > New digital technology may eventually solve the warpage problem and
> > provide the consumer with better quality sound in the form of Compact
> > Discs [C.D.'s]. They are smaller, contain more music, and would,
> > presumably cost less to ship . . . but, they are much more expensive
> > to buy and manufacture. To reproduce them, the consumer needs to
> > purchase a digital device to replace his old hi-fi equipment (in the
> > $700 price range).
> >
> > The bulk of the promotional effort at every record company today is
> > expended on "NEW MATERIAL" . . . the latest and the greatest of
> > whatever the cocaine-tweezed A&R Brass has decided to inflict on
> > everybody. More often than not, these 'aesthetic decisions' result in
> > mountains of useless vinyl/cardboard artifacts which cannot be sold at
> > any price, and are therefore returned for disposal and recycling.
> > These mistakes are expensive.
> >
> > Put aside momentarily the current method of operation and think what
> > is being wasted in terms of GREAT CATALOG ITEMS, squeezed out of the
> > market place because of limited rack space in retail outlets, and the
> > insatiable desire of quota-conscious company reps to fill every
> > available niche with THIS WEEK'S NEW RELEASES.
> >
> > Every major record company has vaults full of (and perpetual rights
> > to) great recording by major artists in many categories which might
> > still provide enjoyment to music consumers if they were made available
> > in the right way. MUSIC CONSUMERS LIKE TO CONSUME MUSIC . . . NOT
> > PIECES OF VINYL WRAPPED IN PIECES OF CARDBOARD.
> >
> > It is our proposal to take advantage of the POSITIVE ASPECTS of a
> > NEGATIVE TREND afflicting the record industry today: HOME TAPING via
> > cassette of material released on vinyl.
> >
> > First of all, we must realize that the taping of albums is not
> > motivated by 'stinginess' alone . . . if a consumer makes a home tape
> > from a disc, that copy will probably sound better than a commercially
> > manufactured high-speed dupe cassette, legitimately released by the
> > company.
> >
> > People today enjoy music more than ever before, and, they like to take
> > it with them wherever they go. THEY CAN HEAR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN
> > GOOD AUDIO AND BAD AUDIO . . . THEY CARE ABOUT THAT DIFFERENCE, AND
> > THEY ARE WILLING TO GO TO SOME TROUBLE AND EXPENSE TO HAVE HIGH
> > QUALITY 'PORTABLE AUDIO' TO USE AS 'WALLPAPER FOR THEIR LIFESTYLE'.
> >
> > THE ANSWERS TO PERPLEXING QUESTIONS
> >
> > presenting: "Q.C.I."
> >
> > We propose to acquire the rights to digitally duplicate and store THE
> > BEST of every record company's difficult-to-move Quality Catalog Items
> > [Q.C.I.], store them in a central processing location, and have them
> > accessible by phone or cable TV, directly patchable into the user's
> > home taping appliances, with the option of direct digital-to-digital
> > transfer to F-1 (SONY consumer level digital tape encoder), Beta
> > Hi-Fi, or ordinary analog cassette (requiring the installation of a
> > rentable D-A converter in the phone itself . . . the main chip is
> > about $12).
> >
> > All accounting for royalty payments, billing to the customer, etc.
> > would be automatic, built into the initial software for the system.
> >
> > The consumer has the option of subscribing to one or more Interest
> > Categories, charged at a monthly rate, without regard for the quantity
> > of music he or she decides to tape.
> >
> > Providing material in such quantity at a reduced cost could actually
> > diminish the desire to duplicate and store it, since it would be
> > available any time day or night.
> >
> > Monthly listings could be provided by catalog, reducing the on-line
> > storage requirements of the computer. The entire service would be
> > accessed by phone, even if the local reception is via TV cable.
> >
> > The advantage of the TV cable is: on those channels where nothing ever
> > seems to happen (there's about 70 of them in L.A.), a visualization of
> > the original cover art, including song lyrics, technical data, etc.,
> > could be displayed while the transmission is in progress, giving the
> > project an electronic whiff of the original point-of-purchase
> > merchandising built into the album when it was 'an album', since there
> > are many consumers who like to fondle & fetish the packaging while the
> > music is being played. In this situation, Fondlement & Fetishism
> > Potential [F.F.P.] is supplied, without the cost of shipping tons of
> > cardboard around.
> >
> > We require a LARGE quantity of money and the services of a team of
> > mega-hackers to write the software for this system. Most of the
> > hardware devices are, even as you read this, available as
> > off-the-shelf items, just waiting to be plugged into each other so
> > they can put an end to "THE RECORD BUSINESS" as we now know it.
> >
> > --
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.org <http://www.mokshatribe.org>
> >
> > House Music 101: http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >
> >
> > The US is: "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> > money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in=
=20
> the
> > world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> > -Hunter S. Thompson
> >
> > "It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the
> > world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those
> > years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march=20
> towards a
> > world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elit=
e
> > and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodeterminatio=
n
> > practiced in past centuries ..."
> > - David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991
> >
> > "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of th=
e
> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually=20
> become
> > visible."
> > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> >
> >
>=20
> --
>=20

>SATURDAY, May 14th
>
>Club 6 turns 6
>
>with the Legend of House himself
>Jesse Saunders
>The "Originator" of House Music...Jesse Saunders wrote, produced, performed 
>and mixed the  world's very 1st house record "ON and ON" on his upstart 
>record label Jes Say Records out of Chicago in 1984. Coming off the 
>critically acclaimed 20th anniversary tour in 2004, which hit every 
>hemisphere of the world, Jesse continues to stay at the forefront and set 
>trends with his current release "GET SUM" on Broken Records/ 
>DontFixItMusic.com . Jesse has been featured in numerous documentaries, 
>books and magazines including the award winning "Put The Needle On The 
>Record" and "Pump Up The Volume". He also wrote the definitive history eith 
>his book "House Music...The Real Story". Come and celebrate the release of 
>a new frontier in House Music history with the "Originator" himself.
>
><http://massiveselector.c.topica.com/maadv88abgX6xaJefdGcadIdZO/>Listen to

>"It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for the 
>world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those 
>years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march towards a 
>world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual elite 
>and world bankers is surely preferable to the national autodetermination 
>practiced in past centuries ..."
>- David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
J

Subject: [sfraves] New Mix - When you look at me!

It's mainly freeform, a lil d&b and some uk hardcore. Its a little 
different than what I normally play. Just something I tossed together 
out of boredom.

http://clev.netdojo.com/sideshow_dj/mixes/When_you_look_at_me.mp3

Burn and Shiver - Tazz vs Digital Anarchy
Beyond Control - Scampy and Mayhem
Closer - John B vs NIN
Sounds Legit - Brisk and Ham
Dreamskies - Euphoria
Lost our minds - Frisky and Hujib
Standing Still - Sunrize
Ear Popper - Robbie Long and A.M.S
Taste The Rainbow - Brisk and Ham
Adrenalin Rush - Stormtrooper
Happy Generation - The Bandits

Hope you like it

--

Subject: [sfraves] New Weekly Prog House / Trance in SF

Hey Everybody,

What's up?  Just wanted to inform ppl...there's a new weekly Progressive
House / Trance event in SF called "Crush".  It happens every Wednesday
night at Underground SF, 9am till 2am.  There's no cover, they have a
great sound system, and the DJs are pretty good.  I went there last week
and had a blast.  You guys should check it out!  Here's the flyer someone
sent me:

http://www.djturbine.com/flyer.html

Cya around.

>That's not all, he also anticipated the Age of Scrutiny we live in today,
>and the rise of The RAVE & PATRIOT Acts.
>
>This is from the opening of Joe's Garage, 1979:
>
>"Central Scrutinizer:
>
>This is the CENTRAL SCRUTINIZER...
>
>It is my responsibility to enforce all the laws that haven't been passed
>yet.
>
>It is also my responsibility to alert each and every one of you to the
>potential consequences of various ordinary everyday activities you might be
>performing which could eventually lead to *The Death Penalty* (or affect
>your parents' credit rating).
>
>Our criminal institutions are full of little creeps like you who do wrong
>things...
>
>And many of them were driven to these crimes by a horrible force called
>MUSIC!
>
>Our studies have shown that this horrible force is so dangerous to society
>at large that laws are being drawn up at this very moment to stop it
>forever!
>
>Cruel and inhuman punishments are being carefully described in tiny
>paragraphs so they won't conflict with the Constitution (which, itself, is
>being modified in order to accommodate THE FUTURE).
>
>I bring you now a special presentation to show what can happen to you if 
>you
>choose a career in MUSIC...
>
>The WHITE ZONE is for loading and unloading only...if you have to load or
>unload, go to the WHITE ZONE... you'll love it...it's a way of life...Ha,
>ha, ha, ha, ha...Hi, it's me, I'm back. This is the CENTRAL
>SCRUTINIZER...The WHITE ZONE is for loading and unloading only...If yah
>gotta load, or if yah gotta unload, go to the WHITE ZONE. You'll love
>it...it's a way of life. That's right, you'll love it, it's a way of life,
>that's right, you'll love it, it's a way of life, you'll love it. This, is,
>the CENTRAL SCRUTINIZER!"
>
>There's more, but I'm sure you get the picture.
>
>On Fri, May 13, 2005 at 11:31:30AM -0700, Apollo wrote:
> > >
> > > http://tinyurl.com/9tx5t
> > >
> > > A PROPOSAL FOR A SYSTEM TO REPLACE ORDINARY RECORD MERCHANDISING
> > > - copyright 1983 by Frank Zappa -
> > >
> > > Ordinary phonograph record merchandising as it exists today is a
> > > stupid process which concerns itself essentially with pieces of
> > > plastic, wrapped in pieces of cardboard.
> > >
> > > These objects, in quantity, are heavy and expensive to ship. The
> > > manufacturing process is complicated and crude. Quality control for
> > > the stamping of the discs is an exercise in futility. The system is
> > > subject to pilferage (as, in some instances, pressing 'over-runs' have
> > > been initiated, with the quantity pressed above the amount of the
> > > legitimate order removed from the premises and sold on the black
> > > market).
> > >
> > > Dissatisfied customers routinely return records because they are
> > > warped and will not play.
> > >
> > > Large numbers of people are employed in the field of 'record
> > > promotion' . . . these salaries are, for the most part, a waste of
> > > money.
> > >
> > > New digital technology may eventually solve the warpage problem and
> > > provide the consumer with better quality sound in the form of Compact
> > > Discs [C.D.'s]. They are smaller, contain more music, and would,
> > > presumably cost less to ship . . . but, they are much more expensive
> > > to buy and manufacture. To reproduce them, the consumer needs to
> > > purchase a digital device to replace his old hi-fi equipment (in the
> > > $700 price range).
> > >
> > > The bulk of the promotional effort at every record company today is
> > > expended on "NEW MATERIAL" . . . the latest and the greatest of
> > > whatever the cocaine-tweezed A&R Brass has decided to inflict on
> > > everybody. More often than not, these 'aesthetic decisions' result in
> > > mountains of useless vinyl/cardboard artifacts which cannot be sold at
> > > any price, and are therefore returned for disposal and recycling.
> > > These mistakes are expensive.
> > >
> > > Put aside momentarily the current method of operation and think what
> > > is being wasted in terms of GREAT CATALOG ITEMS, squeezed out of the
> > > market place because of limited rack space in retail outlets, and the
> > > insatiable desire of quota-conscious company reps to fill every
> > > available niche with THIS WEEK'S NEW RELEASES.
> > >
> > > Every major record company has vaults full of (and perpetual rights
> > > to) great recording by major artists in many categories which might
> > > still provide enjoyment to music consumers if they were made available
> > > in the right way. MUSIC CONSUMERS LIKE TO CONSUME MUSIC . . . NOT
> > > PIECES OF VINYL WRAPPED IN PIECES OF CARDBOARD.
> > >
> > > It is our proposal to take advantage of the POSITIVE ASPECTS of a
> > > NEGATIVE TREND afflicting the record industry today: HOME TAPING via
> > > cassette of material released on vinyl.
> > >
> > > First of all, we must realize that the taping of albums is not
> > > motivated by 'stinginess' alone . . . if a consumer makes a home tape
> > > from a disc, that copy will probably sound better than a commercially
> > > manufactured high-speed dupe cassette, legitimately released by the
> > > company.
> > >
> > > People today enjoy music more than ever before, and, they like to take
> > > it with them wherever they go. THEY CAN HEAR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN
> > > GOOD AUDIO AND BAD AUDIO . . . THEY CARE ABOUT THAT DIFFERENCE, AND
> > > THEY ARE WILLING TO GO TO SOME TROUBLE AND EXPENSE TO HAVE HIGH
> > > QUALITY 'PORTABLE AUDIO' TO USE AS 'WALLPAPER FOR THEIR LIFESTYLE'.
> > >
> > > THE ANSWERS TO PERPLEXING QUESTIONS
> > >
> > > presenting: "Q.C.I."
> > >
> > > We propose to acquire the rights to digitally duplicate and store THE
> > > BEST of every record company's difficult-to-move Quality Catalog Items
> > > [Q.C.I.], store them in a central processing location, and have them
> > > accessible by phone or cable TV, directly patchable into the user's
> > > home taping appliances, with the option of direct digital-to-digital
> > > transfer to F-1 (SONY consumer level digital tape encoder), Beta
> > > Hi-Fi, or ordinary analog cassette (requiring the installation of a
> > > rentable D-A converter in the phone itself . . . the main chip is
> > > about $12).
> > >
> > > All accounting for royalty payments, billing to the customer, etc.
> > > would be automatic, built into the initial software for the system.
> > >
> > > The consumer has the option of subscribing to one or more Interest
> > > Categories, charged at a monthly rate, without regard for the quantity
> > > of music he or she decides to tape.
> > >
> > > Providing material in such quantity at a reduced cost could actually
> > > diminish the desire to duplicate and store it, since it would be
> > > available any time day or night.
> > >
> > > Monthly listings could be provided by catalog, reducing the on-line
> > > storage requirements of the computer. The entire service would be
> > > accessed by phone, even if the local reception is via TV cable.
> > >
> > > The advantage of the TV cable is: on those channels where nothing ever
> > > seems to happen (there's about 70 of them in L.A.), a visualization of
> > > the original cover art, including song lyrics, technical data, etc.,
> > > could be displayed while the transmission is in progress, giving the
> > > project an electronic whiff of the original point-of-purchase
> > > merchandising built into the album when it was 'an album', since there
> > > are many consumers who like to fondle & fetish the packaging while the
> > > music is being played. In this situation, Fondlement & Fetishism
> > > Potential [F.F.P.] is supplied, without the cost of shipping tons of
> > > cardboard around.
> > >
> > > We require a LARGE quantity of money and the services of a team of
> > > mega-hackers to write the software for this system. Most of the
> > > hardware devices are, even as you read this, available as
> > > off-the-shelf items, just waiting to be plugged into each other so
> > > they can put an end to "THE RECORD BUSINESS" as we now know it.
> > >
> > > --
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.org <http://www.mokshatribe.org>
> > >
> > > House Music 101: 
>http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> > >
> > >
> > > The US is: "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> > > money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in
> > the
> > > world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> > > -Hunter S. Thompson
> > >
> > > "It would have been quite impossible for us to develop our plan for 
>the
> > > world if we had been subjected to the lights of publicity during those
> > > years. But, the world is more sophisticated and prepared to march
> > towards a
> > > world government. The supranational sovereignty of an intellectual 
>elite
> > > and world bankers is surely preferable to the national 
>autodetermination
> > > practiced in past centuries ..."
> > > - David Rockefeller, Bilderberg club permanent member, 1991
> > >
> > > "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
>the
> > > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
> > become
> > > visible."
> > > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> > >
> > >
> >
> > --

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Mon)

what is life like when you've got 10,000 windows open, a couple of them
work related, one of them sort of permanently attached to your webmail,
one of them fine tuning your amazon wish list, back to webmail, check your
wells fargo real quick, add some stuff up, maybe do a little CD shopping
while you're at it?

would that be a description of me, or a description of about 3/4 of the
list, slowly widdling a little bit of their life away to some company, 8
or 10 hours at a time?

remember, your skills are on your side.  time is not.  use them both
wisely and to your advantage!

But at my back I always hear Time's winged chariot hurrying near.

- Andrew Marvell

From sfraves-return-121329-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon May 16 21:53:15 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121329-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
