Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Senate Examines Patriot Act Expansion Bill

--0-996409981-1116982125=:29283
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

http://www.aclu.org/SafeandFree/SafeandFree.cfm?ID=3D18313&c=3D206
"...
Senate Examines Patriot Act Expansion Bill
The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence met to consider legislation=20
that would reauthorize and expand the Patriot Act. The ACLU denounced=20
attempts to expand controversial provisions set to expire this year.

Senate Intelligence Committee Examines Controversial Patriot Act Expansion=
=20
Bill; Closed Door Vote to Be Held This Week

May 24, 2005

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
Contact: Media@dcaclu.org

WASHINGTON - The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence met today to=20
consider legislation that would reauthorize - and expand - the Patriot=20
Act. The American Civil Liberties Union denounced attempts to expand,=20
rather than critically review and reform, the controversial provisions set=
=20
to expire at the end of the year. A proposal to make the law=92s most=20
controversial provisions permanent, and to expand it by allowing FBI=20
agents issue their own search orders with no advance court approval, will=
=20
likely be voted on in secret Thursday.

"Now is the time to bring the Patriot Act in line with the Constitution -=
=20
not expand it," said Lisa Graves, ACLU Senior Counsel for Legislative=20
Strategy. "Concerned citizens from across the political spectrum have=20
spoken out against the Patriot Act=92s secrecy: many provisions are=20
implemented secretly, and the government has kept secret key information=20
on how these extraordinary powers are being used. Now, some lawmakers are=
=20
trying to keep debate and votes on legislation to reauthorize and expand=20
the Patriot Act secret as well."

The bill would grant so-called "administrative subpoena" authority to the=
=20
FBI, letting the bureau write and approve its own search orders for any=20
tangible thing it deems relevant to an intelligence investigation without=
=20
approval. This power would let agents seize personal records from medical=
=20
facilities, libraries, hotels, gun dealers, banks and any other business,=
=20
without having to appear before a judge, and without any evidence that the=
=20
people whose records are swept in are involved in any criminal activity.

The proposal would also give the FBI broad new powers to track people=92s=
=20
mail in intelligence inquiries. It would force postal workers to disclose=
=20
the name, address and other information appearing on envelopes delivered=20
to or from people designated by the FBI, without any meaningful=20
protections.

The bill would permit secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act=20
searches and surveillance for the sole purpose of criminal prosecution for=
=20
certain crimes, such as terrorism and espionage, allowing searches to=20
proceed without following the requirements of the Fourth Amendment to the=
=20
Constitution. FISA searches were designed to be used a tool in=20
intelligence gathering investigations, so they are held to lower=20
evidentiary standards than criminal investigations.

Without limits on how the powers can be used, the proposed legislation=20
creates the very real possibility that FISA will now be used to conduct=20
searches and seizures in criminal investigations without probable cause=20
that a crime has been committed, the ACLU said. In other words, it will=20
let law enforcement do an end run around the Constitution.

The ACLU also noted that the proposed legislation would remove the one=20
safeguard in place against using FISA warrants recklessly. Currently, FISA=
=20
warrants cannot be issued against Americans when the investigation is=20
"conducted solely upon the basis of activities protected by the first=20
amendment to the Constitution." The proposed legislation would amend that=
=20
limited protection so that FISA records searches can be conducted solely=20
based on First Amendment activities so long as the investigation as a=20
whole is not based solely on constitutionally protected activity.

"Protecting America also means protecting our Constitution," Graves said.=
=20
"If adopted, these broad new powers would sidestep time-honored checks and=
=20
balances. Lawmakers should hold an open process, and reject this reckless=
=20
disregard for the Fourth Amendment, which protects the liberty and privacy=
=20
of all Americans."

For more on the ACLU=92s concerns with the proposed legislation:
http://www.aclu.org/SafeandFree/SafeandFree.cfm?ID=3D18298&c=3D206

=2E.."

 =09 --=20

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Sly and Lazy Slave on An Epiphany Of Sound tomorrow

Tomorrow I'll have two san francisco djs bringing different takes on sub
fueled electronica and rhythmics.

So get ready for an illin' back-to-back versus battle that will leave
you in a total manic state. Be sure to take plenty of beta-stoppers, cuz
LAZY SLAVE will be spinning an all-school reunion of breaks that'll
leave you comin' up short on your next pop quiz.

Just when you thought it was safe to go back in, SLY will rock ya
two-time with some dubby electrical-shock house that'll totally
short-circuit what little you had left for a brain. Be prepared with
sturdy rubber shoes!

They've promised to bring me rosicrucian pool party polkas : illektro,
chunk-house, fonk, and porntempo (and, no, I'm not trying to compete
with Howard Stern.)  I'll be holding them to their promise (if it's at
all possible!)  So you must listen in: 90.1 FM over the air and
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu online from 9a-Noon pacific time.

Ram ram!



http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] DIRTY w/ Reid Speed

LOLOLOLOLOLOLOMAO   Oh my goodness man... Hello 2Day... it was
sooooooooooo much fun last Saturday & ya know.. i really didn't feel bad
about any of the other events that I mised out on that night 'vcause it
was all about getting DIRTY on Sat night!!!

Opening set w/ Mista Bam & Jauncy was sick... I'd probably describe their
tag set as just a sown home funky SF breaks set that blew me away... Aaron
Jae (now known as Poppa Jae since they got Mama Jamaica hangin' on the
wall every event) & MOD spun this Dope Dope Dope Future Breaks set that
made me feel like a Britney Soears dancer graduated 2 a Janet Jackson
Dancer while I grabbed floor... Ms. Audio Angel graced the set w/ her
Awesome Singing.. YUM!!!  Reid Speed was Sick.. this weas the 1st time i
ever heard her spin Breaks like in the whole 4 years i've known her.... it
was fun catchin up & talkin' 2 her about eeeeeeverything!@!!  WowWW!!!!

Donna Matrix was sick as always w/ her set... she spun alot wait.. I'm
conufzed... OK.. these was a nice yummy set of Acid Breaks but it was
wither during like Reid's sset, Ms Mtraix's set... or Ripple's set... buyt
yeah... Donna spun alota wicked, Evil, DiRtY tracks.. LOVED IT!!!  Love U
Donna!!!

OK.. this was the set I been waiting 4 the whole night.. 'cause like
Ripple & I have well.. there's a thread 4 this on Groundscore about
this... but like i was sayin'g how Reid Speed spins 2 Step (& I didn't
really hear any in her set that night) so Ripple said that he'd bring some
new 2Step records he just got 7 I'm like sooooooooo mondo hello 2Day happy
2 Say that a good portion of the 2nd part of his set was 2 Step & I
LOOOOOOOOOOOOVED IT!!!  OOH YEAH!!!

Then closing out the night was Influence & Sheztek... WOW!!!  Like they
got totally funky.. infact.. i heard this 1 track that Sheztek put in a
demo like 2-3 years ago & I fuckin' LOVED it!!!

It was Groovy.. the vibe was Sick as usual w/ the following the the Evil
Break following has!!!  It was a Dope night & hoestly... I can say 1 of
the mondo highlights of this night was hanignin out w/ Ranger again/...
Dude... I hella missed ya man 7 u did get taller U fucker!!!  Lol :P  Love
U Ranger!!  Oh yeah.. Samira was hella looking 4 when she popped up BTW...

OK... I'M HERE @  school right now tryin'2 attempt 2 do my homework since
i don't have a computer @ my home currently (mm motherboard decided 2 go
kaput on me) & after a few more thingies online.. I shuld be good... so la
la la la.. but yeah.. ui just wanted 2 let U  know how it was last
Saturday & how things were...

Love U all!

Osby {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: <<<STILLDREAM>>> 5 Year Anniversary Campout - June 17, 18 & 19th, 2005

[[[[[[ *~STILLDREAM~* ]]]]]]
--5 Year Anniversary Campout--
June 17, 18 and 19th of the year 2005

The Stilldream Collective is ready to celebrate their 5 Year Anniversary of
amazing music under the stars.  They have been working hard for the last 6
months to ensure this is going to be the best Stilldream Event of ALL time.
We want you to be there, come be part of the Stilldream Experience!

100% Confirmed Line-Up!!!

The Attack People, LIVE!
www.abiotic.net / Mankind - Minneapolis, MN
It's our pleasure to welcome for the first time At a Stilldream Event, one
of the best and fastest growing acts in the United States. Thick driving
bass meets aggressive percussion. Lush analog sounds creating moody
atmospheres. The music is heavy yet groovy. Contrasting from one extreme to
the other with ease. This is The Attack People. They are the Sound of the
Future!

Dig-Dug
USC Events, Seattle
For over 7 years, DJ Dig-Dug has been a resident DJ for the Northwests
largest electronic music event production company, USC Events. his
underlying themes of warped basslines and intelligent drum loops bring a
sense of unity to his signature sound.   DJ Dig-Dug has developed a
following based on skillsnot hype.   Get Ready!

Treavor
www.Moontribe.org, Sound of Mind - SF
While most DJs are focused on one type of electronica, Treavor is known to
make the barriers between Techno, Trance, House and Breaks seem non-existent
often fusing them into one set. This keeps Treavor one step ahead and allows
him to be able to play any time of the night at any event.  Be Prepared for
the Treavor Experience!

Mystre (www.djmystre.com, Reverb Records - SF)

Subject: [sfraves] San Francisco LIVE set from skylab2000 this friday


Hi all,

Japan was wicked! Was very cool to play there, and people were great to 
us!  Still catching up cos we decided to stay an extra week for more fun.

We used to play in San Francisco pretty often - even played a few massive 
raves back in the day- but it's been quite a while, so I'm excited to be 
going back this weekend..

Please come check it out.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 


LIVE WIRE FRIDAY MAY 27TH, 2005 (SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA)

Friday, May 27, 2005 @ Blue Cube
34 Mason St. (off Market) - San Francisco - Map
10 PM - 3 AM :: 18+ w/ valid ID :: $15 @ the door
http://www.livewiresf.com :: infoline - 415.820.3230

Join us in kicking off the Memorial Day weekend! Friday, May 27, 2005, 
Allover Twist is proud to present an electric night of thunderous bass and 
hard, driving beats otherwise known as LiveWire. LiveWire is about 
connecting unique individuals and diverse groups to each other to build a 
stronger electronic dance culture and it's also about body rocking, booty 
shaking, supa-fucking rhythms.

It all goes down at the Blue Cube, located at 34 Mason St. in San 
Francisco. Polo's Blue Cube houses the first twenty channel digital 
surround sound system on the continent with twenty state-of-the-art KV2 
loudspeakers. The Blue Cube features cutting edge art, hand made fusion 
food, 8 tapped kegs and killer drinks that creates an environment that 
loosens the animal inside. So come and get connected @ LiveWire.

Main Floor - Breaks and Techno
skylab2000- Live P.A. Brainforest Productions, LA skylab2000.com
SwitchFocus - Live P.A. Coldtrax, SF/Van. BC
Felix the Dog - Hektik, SF
and sfbreaks.org's own: Aaron Jae - Evil Breaks , SF aaronejae.com

Upstairs Lounge - House
Jonathan Neil - Friction, Godskitchen, Spundae LA/SF
DJ Elz - LNE, Femme DJs, Bay Raves, SF
Bass Reinforcement provided by RevolutionaryAudio

Buy your limited $12 pre-sale tickets here: Groovetickets.com
For $5 admission before 11 PM for 21+ e-mail: vip@livewiresf.com

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 


There are still some summer dates open for skylab2000, so if you do a club 
or event, please contact us. Easy to have skylab2000 play at your event!


   |_e_/~  Dennis Barton <db@skylab2000.com>
     )     skylab2000
   ~\/\    Brainforest Productions, Los Angeles

Otherworld, Coil, & Radiant Atmospheres
proudly present
++++ DEPTH CHARGE ++++
Saturday, June 4, 2005
more info 510 287 5917

UNLEASH YOUR INNER KRAKEN

When they've had enough rum, the old-timers sing
the tale of the last voyage of the Jiggletech,
a noble submarine. Weighing anchor, she drifted from
port and set out in search of the Other World, an
undersea grotto of kinky pyramids and giant pearls.

  Dj Jeno (Wicked)
  http://www.djjeno.com/

  Sutekh (Force Inc. / Mille Plateaux / Context)
  http://www.context.fm/artists_sutekh.html

  Dragnfly vs. Amber
  (lovetribe / sister sf / iamthedj.com)
  http://www.djdragnfly.com
  http://www.iamthedj.com/music.html

  Ethan vs. Donna Matrix (FnF / newsBREAKZ)
  http://www.bass-station.com/ethan/audio
  http://www.newsbreakz.org

  Reid Oda (Aranji / Looq Records)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Dom (FnF)

Fearing the pleasures this might unleash, a squadron
of black helicopters intercepted the vessel at the
horizon's edge. The good ship dove for the ocean floor
as depth charges rained down from the sky! Relentless
sonic pressures pounded her hull with each detonation,
discharging waves of unending acoustical force.
Her hatches battened, her bulkheads sealed,
the Jiggletech drifted deeper.

  Azeem live hip hop
  (Future Primitive / Wide Hive / Oaklyn Records)
  http://www.widehive.com/azeem.html

  Mark Stretch (Foreign Legion / Look Records)
  http://www.lookrecords.com/marcstretch

  Barefoot (Aranji)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Mozaic (13moontribe / djmozaic.net)
  http://www.djmozaic.net

  Origami vs. Cubik (newstylesound.com / Moksha Tribe)
  http://newstylesound.com

Beyond the reach of sunlight, the Jiggletech
found herself embraced by the coiling tentacles
of a radiant squid. Gently, this leviathan
deposited its catch on the sandy sea bottom.

  Tom Thump (Throwdown / Milk / Kinkysweet Records)
  http://www.tomthump.com

  Joe Rice (Justice League / FnF)
  http://www.justiceleague.com/agents/joe.html

  Monty Luke (DHP / FnF)
  http://www.justiceleague.com/tsm/blog

  drjd (SLA, Koinonea)
  http://i5tribe.org/dr.jd

  Redstickman (Ambient Mafia / Moksha Tribe)
  http://redstickman.homestead.com/redstickman.html

  Mr. Band live

Having jaws but no gills, the submarine's divers
ventured curiously out through the hatch, snorkles
in hand, masks and tanks at the ready. What they
found was no inky abyss; all around them were
Nereids, Neptunes and shape-shifting sea-nymphs --
a deep water garden of coral and bubbles,
beautifully lit by the phosphorescence of the
benevolent squid.

  BRAIN-BENDING SUPER-COLOSSAL LIGHTING
  by Coil & Radiant Atmospheres
  with special guest Mang on the Diskovision

  PRECISION PRESSURES
  by Know:Audio, Gateway Systems & Thick Sound

  ALTARED REALITIES by the Minx

  AQUATIC INSTALLATIONS by Marin

Scuttling her butt in this clamshell of love,
the Jiggletech never returned.

  DEPTH CHARGE 06.04.05
  more info 510 287 5917
  http://www.otherworld.ws
  http://www.redolent.org

  $12 @ the door  
  *West Oakland location 
  (call day of event for directions)

Protect your right to party. Do not post this
invitation on other lists.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

this is not a crack on this event nor the fans of this event, but...

i always found it odd that people would want to heard eurotrance at a
small, weekly event.  to me, the sound doesn't translate well to that
kind of venue.  trance to me always seemed more fit for a bigger
sound.  progressive house....yes, that works for a small, weekly
event.  eurotrance?  not so sure that's a good fit.  but then i'mm not
a big fan of eurotrance so i really don't know what i'm talking about.

and yes, folks.  there is good trance.  let's say it together.  "there
is good trance."

-b

ps.  $10 says chris jackson is going to respond to this thread.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

Tiesto - there was a remix of Flight 643 that i kinda liked, but it
was breaky.  and his remix of Innocente was nice and pretty and
proggy.

Ferry Corsten - a little too foo foo for me.  and then he went all
breaky with Punk and then electroey with Rock your Body

Markus Schulz - i think of progressive house and not so much trance

Armin Van Buren - trance

but i'll still ask the same question again:  do people want to hear
trance at a small, weekly, 21+ venue?

-b

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Crush tonight?



>and yes, folks.  there is good trance.  let's say it together.  "there
is good trance."<

Well, yes, there IS good trance.  It was made over 10 years ago before it
was dubbed "trance" and just happened to be a derivative of early techno and
house.  The first half of Cowboy Records catalogue...some  early stuff on
Warp like RAC, Rhythm Invention and the like.  A record from the early 90's
called "Transient Truth".  The artists name is slipping my memory right now.
Damn that shit was good!  I used to play a shit ton of it...and consider
some of the tracks to be some of my all time favs.  Makes the foo-foo crap
balls people call trance now-a-days look like...well...foo-foo crap balls.
I liked it better when it was all just underground dance music.


>ps.  $10 says chris jackson is going to respond to this thread<

Sooooo.  Anybody take the bet and lose some cash to B??


hehehe,

chris

or more specific

> catalogue...some  early stuff on
> Warp like RAC, Rhythm Invention and the like.  A
> record from the early 90's
> called "Transient Truth".  The artists name is
> slipping my memory right now.
> Damn that shit was good!  I used to play a shit ton
> of it...and consider
> some of the tracks to be some of my all time favs. 
> Makes the foo-foo crap
> balls people call trance now-a-days look
> like...well...foo-foo crap balls.
> I liked it better when it was all just underground
> dance music.
> 
> 
> >ps.  $10 says chris jackson is going to respond to
> this thread<
> 
> Sooooo.  Anybody take the bet and lose some cash to
> B??
> 
> 
> hehehe,
> 
> chris
>

The early platipus records were really good.

i like the german "trance" that Sandra Collins used to play. (prolly still
does)

i like progressive that some people call trance that doesn't have any
hoovers or drum build ups or girls singing remakes of songs that were
terrible in the first place.

Am I the only one that started crying when I read the words Euro-trance in
relation to what used to be The Top?  Tonight used to be teh best of the
house muzak for years running there.  If there's one good thing I think
that's been happening out here, it's that crap big room "trance" is dying
a slow death, it's not getting nearly the support it once was, and the psy
scene, amongst others, seems to be on the up.

Subject: [sfraves] JULY 30!!!! IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE!!!!!!!!

Reliable people have been telling me it's true since last week. But it 
really only sunk in this morning, when the song came up randomly on my 
iPod. Ever since it's been damn near impossible to keep this big silly 
shit-eating grin off my face. I keep breaking out in laughter, and 
people keep wondering why,

I've already broken out my beads and bought fifteen yards of elastic.



Imagine there's no heaven
It's easy if you try
No hell below us
Above us only sky

Imagine all the people
Living for today

Imagine there's no country
It isn't hard to do
Nothing to kill or die for
And no religion too

Imagine all the people
Living life in peace

You may say I'm a dreamer
But I'm not the only one
I hope someday you will join us
And the world will live as one

Imagine no possessions
I wonder if you can
No need for greed or hunger
A brotherhood of man

Imagine all the people
Sharing all the world

You may say I'm a dreamer
But I'm not the only one
I hope someday you will join us
And the world will live as one

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

I know i might get a lil flamed for this one...but i'll say it anyway.
 As far as trance goes, i definatly like the old trance, from the
early 90's.  It was still very danceable and very moving, with out
being all foo foo and lame.

I used to hate trance because it all sounded the same and didnt really
make me wanna dance or move or take me to another place (which is what
i thought something called trance should do) it should put you in a
trance of some sort and i just never felt that way with all the crap i
was hearing.

This is where the flames will begin, but i'll say it anyway.  Keoki's
old mixes, were what got me to realise that there was good
trance....at one point in time.  If you havent checked em out yet you
really should.  His Journey's By Dj mix is awesome.

1.OMYCRON - Whaler
2.POWER CIRCLES - Garden of peace
3.MOMENTUM - Technoriental
4.LAZONBY - Sacred Cycles
5.SHI-TAKE - Don't look back in anger
6.TRANSONIC - Sonic
7.MIKE INK - Vinyl countdown
8.E-RECTION - Colonisation of space
9.THE MIGHTY DUB CATS - Keep on truckin
10.THE SPIRIT - The Spirit
11.COOL JACK - Try the feeling
12.DIGGER - Soweto
13.BEATMISTRESS WITH XPANDO - Jazz 303
14.THE SHERMANIANS - All the way live
15.VAN BASTEN - Magnetic King

That is what i feel trance should be like.  It's very listenable, and
makes you wanna dance, and it takes your mind on a journey, with out
being all foo foo.

Some people would probably call it progressive house, but progressive
house used to be a totally differant beast in of itself.  Not this
lame crap like they have now.  Good Progressive house to me would best
be displayed on CD's like

The Stress Compilation 1 and 2 (http://www.discogs.com/release/111176
and http://www.discogs.com/release/261224)

The first one was mixed by (and some of you will proabably say some
shit about it, but they're fuckin spot on awesome mixes and tracks)
Sasha and Dave Seaman.  The 2nd one was mixed by Kimball Collins and
Steve Loria (I dont think the Steve Loria mixes are all that great but
the tracks are awesome) If you havent heard those mixes i suggest you
check them out as well, that's what progressive house should be, not
the crap that gets produced now a days, cause it's definatly more
trance then it is house.  Stress Records put out some of the best
progressive house to date.  My old roommate nick had tons of Stress
records, they're a bit harder to mix, cause they change up a lot more
and don't follow the same basic boring format as most dance music
today, you actually had to be a skilled DJ in order to mix this stuff
flawlessly, had to know that some things went on the 16 beat, and some
on the 8 rather then the standard 32 count like most all other
records.  In any case though it is some of the best driving, pumping
dancing music ever, and it's too bad it all had to evolve into what it
is now.  They just don't make tracks like that anymore.


--=20
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

> >and yes, folks.  there is good trance.  let's say it together.  "there
> is good trance."<

> Well, yes, there IS good trance.  It was made over 10 years ago before it
> was dubbed "trance" and just happened to be a derivative of early techno =
and
> house.  The first half of Cowboy Records catalogue...some  early stuff on
> Warp like RAC, Rhythm Invention and the like.  A record from the early 90=
's
> called "Transient Truth".  The artists name is slipping my memory right n=
ow.
> Damn that shit was good!  I used to play a shit ton of it...and consider
> some of the tracks to be some of my all time favs.  Makes the foo-foo cra=
p
> balls people call trance now-a-days look like...well...foo-foo crap balls=
.
> I liked it better when it was all just underground dance music.
>=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

As much as it pains me to say it nowadays, I've always been a fan of the 
Sasha & Digweed "Northern Exposure" series (especially the East Coast 
edition). That to me was "trance" that took you somewhere. Yea - some of it 
was fluffy, but it wasn't as lofty and cheesey as anything post '99 (IMHO). 
It was more relaxed and vibey. In fact, I find it has more in common with 
downtempo/ambient than it does anything else. And of course, for some reason 
lots of people call Underworld "trance", and I love them.

So it seems most of us actually LIKE the older trance...maybe I ought to dig 
out my old trance vinyl and make a cd. I'm partial to the breaky stuff (a la 
Miro "Paradise" {Creeping Farmatronic mix}) - so it would be stuff of that 
ilk.


*scratches chin*

> > is good trance."<

> > Well, yes, there IS good trance.  It was made over 10 years ago before 
>it
> > was dubbed "trance" and just happened to be a derivative of early techno 
>and
> > house.  The first half of Cowboy Records catalogue...some  early stuff 
>on
> > Warp like RAC, Rhythm Invention and the like.  A record from the early 
>90's
> > called "Transient Truth".  The artists name is slipping my memory right 
>now.
> > Damn that shit was good!  I used to play a shit ton of it...and consider
> > some of the tracks to be some of my all time favs.  Makes the foo-foo 
>crap
> > balls people call trance now-a-days look like...well...foo-foo crap 
>balls.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] JULY 30!!!! IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE IT'S TRUE!!!!!!!!

Skills and UNITY will be throwing a party on July 30th called "Imagine 2000=
."

Jason and Tom did the booking for the lineup and Duckie from Unity
will be doing most of the creative work (from what i was told).

I think it'll be a fun party.  Yes, dog on the candy scene but the
fact of the matter is that UNITY parties went way fucking off.  Some
of the happiest crowds and balls out energetic raves I've been to.

My only issue with the party is that the lineup is completely
trance/nrg.  And the way I remember the UNITY parties being was a mix
of genres from trance to house to breaks to happy hardcore.  To me, a
party with all trance/nrg doesn't reflect the spirit of UNITY in a
musical sense.  But I talked to Duckie about it and it's all gravy
baby.

Yes, I might be going to this party.  And I honestly think some of you
old folks might be able to appreciate the fact that the crowd at this
party will be bouncing, smiling and being genuinely friendly towards
one another.  And that's a good thing.

--- Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
wrote:

> As much as it pains me to say it nowadays, I've
> always been a fan of the 
> Sasha & Digweed "Northern Exposure" series
> (especially the East Coast 
> edition). That to me was "trance" that took you
> somewhere. Yea - some of it 
> was fluffy, but it wasn't as lofty and cheesey as
> anything post '99 (IMHO). 
> It was more relaxed and vibey. In fact, I find it
> has more in common with 
> downtempo/ambient than it does anything else. And of
> course, for some reason 
> lots of people call Underworld "trance", and I love
> them.
> 
> So it seems most of us actually LIKE the older
> trance...maybe I ought to dig 
> out my old trance vinyl and make a cd. I'm partial
> to the breaky stuff (a la 
> Miro "Paradise" {Creeping Farmatronic mix}) - so it
> would be stuff of that 
> ilk.
> 
> 
> *scratches chin*
> 
> >From: Chester Copperpot
> <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
> >Reply-To: Chester Copperpot
> <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
> >To: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
> >CC: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>, georgeC | origami
> <newstylesound@yahoo.com>, SF 
> >Trance Fan <trancefan01@yahoo.com>,
> sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?
> >Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 07:52:50 -0700
> >
> >I know i might get a lil flamed for this one...but
> i'll say it anyway.
> >  As far as trance goes, i definatly like the old
> trance, from the
> >early 90's.  It was still very danceable and very
> moving, with out
> >being all foo foo and lame.
> >
> >I used to hate trance because it all sounded the
> same and didnt really
> >make me wanna dance or move or take me to another
> place (which is what
> >i thought something called trance should do) it
> should put you in a
> >trance of some sort and i just never felt that way
> with all the crap i
> >was hearing.
> >
> >This is where the flames will begin, but i'll say
> it anyway.  Keoki's
> >old mixes, were what got me to realise that there
> was good
> >trance....at one point in time.  If you havent
> checked em out yet you
> >really should.  His Journey's By Dj mix is awesome.
> >
> >1.OMYCRON - Whaler
> >2.POWER CIRCLES - Garden of peace
> >3.MOMENTUM - Technoriental
> >4.LAZONBY - Sacred Cycles
> >5.SHI-TAKE - Don't look back in anger
> >6.TRANSONIC - Sonic
> >7.MIKE INK - Vinyl countdown
> >8.E-RECTION - Colonisation of space
> >9.THE MIGHTY DUB CATS - Keep on truckin
> >10.THE SPIRIT - The Spirit
> >11.COOL JACK - Try the feeling
> >12.DIGGER - Soweto
> >13.BEATMISTRESS WITH XPANDO - Jazz 303
> >14.THE SHERMANIANS - All the way live
> >15.VAN BASTEN - Magnetic King
> >
> >That is what i feel trance should be like.  It's
> very listenable, and
> >makes you wanna dance, and it takes your mind on a
> journey, with out
> >being all foo foo.
> >
> >Some people would probably call it progressive
> house, but progressive
> >house used to be a totally differant beast in of
> itself.  Not this
> >lame crap like they have now.  Good Progressive
> house to me would best
> >be displayed on CD's like
> >
> >The Stress Compilation 1 and 2
> (http://www.discogs.com/release/111176
> >and http://www.discogs.com/release/261224)
> >
> >The first one was mixed by (and some of you will
> proabably say some
> >shit about it, but they're fuckin spot on awesome
> mixes and tracks)
> >Sasha and Dave Seaman.  The 2nd one was mixed by
> Kimball Collins and
> >Steve Loria (I dont think the Steve Loria mixes are
> all that great but
> >the tracks are awesome) If you havent heard those
> mixes i suggest you
> >check them out as well, that's what progressive
> house should be, not
> >the crap that gets produced now a days, cause it's
> definatly more
> >trance then it is house.  Stress Records put out
> some of the best
> >progressive house to date.  My old roommate nick
> had tons of Stress
> >records, they're a bit harder to mix, cause they
> change up a lot more
> >and don't follow the same basic boring format as
> most dance music
> >today, you actually had to be a skilled DJ in order
> to mix this stuff
> >flawlessly, had to know that some things went on
> the 16 beat, and some
> >on the 8 rather then the standard 32 count like
> most all other
> >records.  In any case though it is some of the best
> driving, pumping
> >dancing music ever, and it's too bad it all had to
> evolve into what it
> >is now.  They just don't make tracks like that
> anymore.
> >
> >
> >--
> >Chester Copperpot

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

Alot of complainers on this list....

I realize not everyone is into trance, especially in the US.  Hundreds of thousands
of ppl in Europe still love it though and follow it closely, so I think it deserves
some merit.  ("But Europeans are idiots" ...)

I don't notice any rise in psytrance.  I think breaks and deep house are on the rise
though.

What's wrong with adding some musical diversity to this city?

"My taste in music is the standard for good music."  Please stop sucking your own
cock.  Thank you.

-Ted

John is referring, I believe, to the "Imagine"=20
parties that were given by a not-for profit=20
collective. Wonderful, magical events for=20
massive-sized parties.  I always had a memorable=20
time at them:  awesome vibe and beautiful people.

Aside from Moksha Tribe, the Imagine people were=20
the only not-for profit party givers in the=20
community:  all their profits went to local youth=20
charities.  IMHO this affects the vibe.  Those=20
who are in it for the love and the other create=20
the genuine TAZ experience.

So if there is to be another Imagine I highly recommend it.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?

There is still a lot of good prog house being produced. Granted I have not 
bought any records in about a year but im pretty sure that there are still 
good producers making good chit mang!

examples: Bill Hamel Good prog house, Chris fortier Deeper but ok prog 
house. Listen to his Bedrock 3 album and tell me that is "Trance" it is 
straight up deep house.. mixed with some progressive stuff.
Funny that you mention the defunct stress records and how prog house sucks. 
Cause one of the guys that either started the label or use to record alot of 
tracks on it,and  is a prog house producer that I happen to like. His name 
is escaping me right now but he did Mindwarp 1 and II on stress. I have to 
check the records when I get home for his name.

But then there are alot of producers that make "Prog house" that tend to be 
on the trancy side at times example: Austin leeds, Markus Schultz the guys 
over at lost language label etc..

Just depends on who you listen to in each genre..

PS: I can do a mix of nothing but techno loops and drum fills that would put 
you in a "Trance" so to speak but I would not consider it trance music.. it 
is hard banging loopy techno.

So the lesson for the day... Just because it puts you in a trance DOES NOT 
make it trance music

so im a smart ass :-)

Macadio



>From: Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
>Reply-To: Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
>To: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
>CC: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>, SF 
>Trance Fan <trancefan01@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Crush tonight?
>Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 07:52:50 -0700
>
>I know i might get a lil flamed for this one...but i'll say it anyway.
>  As far as trance goes, i definatly like the old trance, from the
>early 90's.  It was still very danceable and very moving, with out
>being all foo foo and lame.
>
>I used to hate trance because it all sounded the same and didnt really
>make me wanna dance or move or take me to another place (which is what
>i thought something called trance should do) it should put you in a
>trance of some sort and i just never felt that way with all the crap i
>was hearing.
>
>This is where the flames will begin, but i'll say it anyway.  Keoki's
>old mixes, were what got me to realise that there was good
>trance....at one point in time.  If you havent checked em out yet you
>really should.  His Journey's By Dj mix is awesome.
>
>1.OMYCRON - Whaler
>2.POWER CIRCLES - Garden of peace
>3.MOMENTUM - Technoriental
>4.LAZONBY - Sacred Cycles
>5.SHI-TAKE - Don't look back in anger
>6.TRANSONIC - Sonic
>7.MIKE INK - Vinyl countdown
>8.E-RECTION - Colonisation of space
>9.THE MIGHTY DUB CATS - Keep on truckin
>10.THE SPIRIT - The Spirit
>11.COOL JACK - Try the feeling
>12.DIGGER - Soweto
>13.BEATMISTRESS WITH XPANDO - Jazz 303
>14.THE SHERMANIANS - All the way live
>15.VAN BASTEN - Magnetic King
>
>That is what i feel trance should be like.  It's very listenable, and
>makes you wanna dance, and it takes your mind on a journey, with out
>being all foo foo.
>
>Some people would probably call it progressive house, but progressive
>house used to be a totally differant beast in of itself.  Not this
>lame crap like they have now.  Good Progressive house to me would best
>be displayed on CD's like
>
>The Stress Compilation 1 and 2 (http://www.discogs.com/release/111176
>and http://www.discogs.com/release/261224)
>
>The first one was mixed by (and some of you will proabably say some
>shit about it, but they're fuckin spot on awesome mixes and tracks)
>Sasha and Dave Seaman.  The 2nd one was mixed by Kimball Collins and
>Steve Loria (I dont think the Steve Loria mixes are all that great but
>the tracks are awesome) If you havent heard those mixes i suggest you
>check them out as well, that's what progressive house should be, not
>the crap that gets produced now a days, cause it's definatly more
>trance then it is house.  Stress Records put out some of the best
>progressive house to date.  My old roommate nick had tons of Stress
>records, they're a bit harder to mix, cause they change up a lot more
>and don't follow the same basic boring format as most dance music
>today, you actually had to be a skilled DJ in order to mix this stuff
>flawlessly, had to know that some things went on the 16 beat, and some
>on the 8 rather then the standard 32 count like most all other
>records.  In any case though it is some of the best driving, pumping
>dancing music ever, and it's too bad it all had to evolve into what it
>is now.  They just don't make tracks like that anymore.
>
>

Saturday, June 11
10pm-10am
2 rooms of psytrance and breaks
all night long

Starring:

DJ Bam - evil breaks
Manx - oceanmanx
Michael Liu - illumination records
Mr. Rogers - the droameyfossilloti
Teleomorph - nyc
The Zapper - i am the zapper

and

Bertzerker
Kevin
Pikasso
Skedache
Vax

$5 Donation
Free fruit and water

Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="============_-1094979451==_ma============"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Tell Congress To Oppose Sensenbrenner's HR 1528

--============_-1094979451==_ma============
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

Tell Congress To Oppose Sensenbrenner's HR 1528

H.R. 1528, Defending America's Most Vulnerable: Safe Access to Drug 
Treatment and Child Protection Act of 2005, is one of the worst drug 
war bills that Congress has ever considered.

Among other things, HR 1528:

--Virtually eliminates the ability of federal judges to give 
sentences below the minimum sentence recommended by federal 
sentencing guidelines, essentially creating a mandatory minimum 
sentence for every federal offense (including both drug and non-drug 
offenses).

--Expands the federal "three strikes and you're out" law to include 
new offenses, including mandating life imprisonment (with no 
possibility of parole) for anyone convicted a third time under the 
RAVE Act.

--Mandates a 10-year minimum sentence for anyone 21 or older that 
gives marijuana or others drugs to someone under 18 (i.e. a 21 year 
old college students gives a joint to his 17-year old brother). A 
second offense would be life in prison.

--Expands what is considered to be a "drug-free" school zone to 
include almost any place in an urban area, and increases penalties 
for selling or distributing drugs in that area. (The result will be 
enhanced penalties for people in inner cities, while people in rural 
and suburban areas get less time for the same offense).

--Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that commits a 
drug trafficking offense near the presence of a person under 18 or in 
a place where such person resides for any period of time. The 
sentence is 10 years if they are parent. (I.e. a mother that sells 
her neighbor a joint will get a 10-year minimum sentence, even if her 
kids were at school at the time).

--Creates a new offense for persons who witness or learn about 
certain drug offenses that fail to report the drug offender to the 
police within 24 hours or fail to provide full assistance to the 
police in tracking and prosecuting the offender. Offenses that would 
get someone a 2-year minimum sentence, including failing to report a 
neighbor that is storing or selling drugs when that neighbor has 
kids, failing to report anyone that gives a joint to someone under 
the age of 21, and failing to report a college student that is 
selling marijuana on a college campus.

--Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that offers, 
solicits, encourages, or induces a person enrolled in drug treatment, 
or previously enrolled in drug treatment, to purchase, possess or 
receive drugs.

--Makes it a federal crime to provide "drug paraphernalia" to anyone. 
While the goal is to make it a crime - punishable by up to three 
years in prison - to give someone a bong as a birthday present, it 
would also make it a federal crime to provide someone with sterile 
syringes (except where it is explicitly authorized by local or state 
law). If enacted, it would essentially criminalize many needle 
exchange programs.

The full text of H.R. 1528 can be viewed by going to 
http://thomas.loc.gov/ , entering "HR1528" in the search box, 
checking the "enter bill number" circle under the search box, and 
clicking "search".

Take Action Now.

http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/


-- 


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into 
experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to 
the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are 
alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

On 5/26/05, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> Tell Congress To Oppose Sensenbrenner's HR 1528
>=20
> H.R. 1528, Defending America's Most Vulnerable: Safe Access to Drug
> Treatment and Child Protection Act of 2005, is one of the worst drug
> war bills that Congress has ever considered.
>=20
> Among other things, HR 1528:
>=20
> --Virtually eliminates the ability of federal judges to give
> sentences below the minimum sentence recommended by federal
> sentencing guidelines, essentially creating a mandatory minimum
> sentence for every federal offense (including both drug and non-drug
> offenses).
>=20
> --Expands the federal "three strikes and you're out" law to include
> new offenses, including mandating life imprisonment (with no
> possibility of parole) for anyone convicted a third time under the
> RAVE Act.
>=20
> --Mandates a 10-year minimum sentence for anyone 21 or older that
> gives marijuana or others drugs to someone under 18 (i.e. a 21 year
> old college students gives a joint to his 17-year old brother). A
> second offense would be life in prison.
>=20
> --Expands what is considered to be a "drug-free" school zone to
> include almost any place in an urban area, and increases penalties
> for selling or distributing drugs in that area. (The result will be
> enhanced penalties for people in inner cities, while people in rural
> and suburban areas get less time for the same offense).
>=20
> --Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that commits a
> drug trafficking offense near the presence of a person under 18 or in
> a place where such person resides for any period of time. The
> sentence is 10 years if they are parent. (I.e. a mother that sells
> her neighbor a joint will get a 10-year minimum sentence, even if her
> kids were at school at the time).
>=20
> --Creates a new offense for persons who witness or learn about
> certain drug offenses that fail to report the drug offender to the
> police within 24 hours or fail to provide full assistance to the
> police in tracking and prosecuting the offender. Offenses that would
> get someone a 2-year minimum sentence, including failing to report a
> neighbor that is storing or selling drugs when that neighbor has
> kids, failing to report anyone that gives a joint to someone under
> the age of 21, and failing to report a college student that is
> selling marijuana on a college campus.
>=20
> --Mandates a 5-year minimum sentence for any person that offers,
> solicits, encourages, or induces a person enrolled in drug treatment,
> or previously enrolled in drug treatment, to purchase, possess or
> receive drugs.
>=20
> --Makes it a federal crime to provide "drug paraphernalia" to anyone.
> While the goal is to make it a crime - punishable by up to three
> years in prison - to give someone a bong as a birthday present, it
> would also make it a federal crime to provide someone with sterile
> syringes (except where it is explicitly authorized by local or state
> law). If enacted, it would essentially criminalize many needle
> exchange programs.
>=20
> The full text of H.R. 1528 can be viewed by going to
> http://thomas.loc.gov/ , entering "HR1528" in the search box,
> checking the "enter bill number" circle under the search box, and
> clicking "search".
>=20
> Take Action Now.
>=20
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/
>=20
>=20
> --
>=20
>=20
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>=20
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>=20
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all
> the money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody
> else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
>=20
> "Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into
> experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to
> the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are
> alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
> -Kabir
>=20
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>=20
>=20


--=20

Message-ID: <20050526233320.33616.qmail@web32811.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

From: Carlos S <mathsound101@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-251856406-1117150400=:32166"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Trance

--0-251856406-1117150400=:32166
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I remember when I first heard the term "trance," it referred more to a style of mixing. The tracks in a trance mix were really all progressive house. Eventually, labels  started producing tracks that were trance inducing by themselves. Platipus and TIP are two labels that definitely produced "trance" tracks. At some point, the term "trance" came to represent a very distinct high enery sound. Tracks that today are called "trance" usually don't put me in a trance at all, and the way is which they are usually mixed in not trance inducing at all. It seems like the term/genre has really mutated. 
 
I know the style I played in the mid to late nineties was called trance, but I always just thought of it as high energy. I feel the style I play these days is much closer to what was originally called "trance."
 
thoughts and comments, please...

		
---------------------------------
Discover Yahoo!
 Use Yahoo! to plan a weekend, have fun online & more.  Check it out!
--0-251856406-1117150400=:32166--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Trance

I agree with you on that point carlos it is true.. Epic or melodic trance of 
this day and age exactly as you state does not put you in a trance. It 
sounds more like a movie soundtrack to me. Hell half of the big "Trance" 
anthems are from movies. (I.E Titanic,Never ending story,Star wars, Imagine  
etc)

Trance to me are guys like: Chris Liebing.. He encompasses a true producer 
this guy has made so many solid tracks in so many different genre's it's not 
funny. 777 alpha wave, old Sven Vath and some of the harthouse catalogue. 
But guys like that really blur the lines so you can't really put it in a 
category ya dig!

Mac

listen to my record. but hey, wtf, why not. she'll probably appreciate
it more than this list seems to! jesus. what I can't believe is that

I could smash buildings with my penis. I mean doesn't that seem kind
of odd? my dick versus a skyscraper and the skyscraper goes down?
"Godzilla" was actually a movie about my cock? that didn't provoke any
kind of reaction at all? I can say my scrotum gives new meaning to the
term "wrecking ball" and nobody gives a shit, but I say Reid Speed is
hot, which is OBVIOUSLY TRUE, and it's this big deal?

I wonder about you people...

From sfraves-return-121617-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri May 27 01:13:25 2005

Received: (qmail 30055 invoked by uid 1101); 27 May 2005 01:13:25 -0000
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 18:13:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20050526181305.O28252@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Hyperreal<-_->http: //www.hyperreal.org/ SFRaves<-_->http://www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] A History of Hyperreal and the Beginning of SFRaves

a cobbled-together history of hyperreal
written by mike brown in december 2000
originally for publication in iron feather journal and on hyperreal.org. 
contact hyperreal for permission to reproduce elsewhere.

brian behlendorf is a southern california native who fell into the los 
angeles rave scene during his high school years. at the time, the only 
raves in the usa were in l.a., san francisco, and new york.

in 1991 he started college at u.c. berkeley and gained access to their 
computing facilities. in march of 1992, he started an online mailing list 
for the san francisco rave community: sfraves. it was a huge success. says 
brian,

     "When I moved, the only parties I could easily find up here were in 
over-21 clubs. Yet I had heard about ToonTown and Wicked and other crews, 
so out of desperation thought that starting an Internet mailing list would 
be a way to find other people who knew. Turns out that was a good idea - 
SFRaves started March 6th 1992, and that weekend I went to a party I found 
out about through the list, called the Woopy Ball. Later that year, 
August, the SFRaves list itself threw a party called "Connection" on a 
beach in Santa Cruz - that led to more parties and more use of email to 
find other ravers and coordinate underground parties."

i have to explain something here. in 1992 the only rave mailing list 
besides sfraves was ne-raves, which was hosted at m.i.t. ...someone had 
already created the alt.rave usenet newsgroup, and the uk-dance mailing 
list existed as well but wasn't focused on a rave scene. so these were 
about the only places online where people could get information about the 
scene.

longtime hyperreal contributor dan "danFREELove" philpott adds:

     "In '92 there were at least three rave lists on the east coast. UMD 
Raves (University of Maryland) was active due to the scene blowing up in 
DC. The list was really just a way to find out about parties and organize 
road trips. It went under quickly after DC Raves started up and absorbed 
most of the conversation. So DC, UMD and NE Raves were operating but only 
DC and NE survived.

     "As for LA, SF and NY having a lock on rave in the US at that time. DC 
actually was the first place on the east coast with raves. DC's 
Catastrophic parties predated (and influenced) the Storm parties in NY. 
The Storm parties are what inspired NERaves into exis-dance. NY always had 
a wikked club scene but from what I remember the rave scene hit LA first, 
then DC, then NY."

the majority of people with internet access back then were college 
students involved in computer-oriented studies, employees of well-funded 
technology companies like at&t, and a smattering of u.s. government and 
military agencies. consumer-oriented services like compuserve, genie, 
prodigy and aol, as well as most dialup bbs 'networks' were not on the 
internet, or had very limited gateways for mail and news that no one knew 
about. there was no spam, and since you weren't interacting with a true 
cross-section of the general public, the entire net had a different 
character than it does today, socially.

to be a part of the internet at that time was a big deal, because 
everybody who could contribute something to it was able to do so and be 
heard, and their contributions were more often than not of significant 
value. it was easy to concentrate and filter information into very 
valuable outlets like mailing lists, newsgroups, and ftp-accessible 
repositories.

and at the same time, it wasn't a big deal, because no one foresaw that it 
would become what it is today. we were just into it because we had access 
to it, usually on someone else's tab, and it allowed us to connect and 
exchange ideas with people whose interaction and ideas we valued. there 
was a lot of signal in a very small number of places, and hardly any noise 
except what we generated ourselves. definitely a different internet than 
today.

so as the rave scene started to blow up nationwide, we'd tell each other 
online about the flyers we found and the records we bought and the parties 
we went to. you'd have people in the midwest who were driving 9-12 hours 
to get to raves in new york and d.c., and to hang out with the friends we 
made through these online forums. the same thing was going on in 
california and all over the northeast. a lot of information sharing was 
going on in this subculture's subculture. 'netravers' or 'cybertribe' is 
what we called ourselves.

at the same time that brian started the sfraves mailing list, he was able 
to make available an anonymous ftp space where would put various files 
related to the scene. this was at soda.berkeley.edu and later 
haas.berkeley.edu. it contained the sfraves list archives, gifs of various 
people on the list, drug information, flyers, and other interesting text 
files about raving. he (i think it was him) also set up gary grossman's 
telnet-based 'unix-cb' chat server, and dubbed it 'vrave' -- the virtual 
rave.

this was the beginning of hyperreal. early-mid 1992.

in one sense it was this tangible, static thing, a deliberately assembled 
collection of information about raves, music and drugs. there were very 
few places online where this kind of subject matter could be found, so it 
was very important. in another sense, especially through the mailing list, 
it was something less tangible; it was active service for a certain small 
segment of a relatively small community of people. it was simultaneously 
providing services for and more importantly, helping build and strengthen 
that community. it was a conduit, a filter, and a magnet for information 
centered around certain memes.

in 1993, berkeley wanted their machines back, so everything moved to 
sfraves.stanford.edu, aka techno.stanford.edu, thanks to someone at 
stanford who was into the scene and donated the facilities. it was there 
that brian was able to give out accounts to some friends and add more 
non-sfraves specific content like audio files (30 second .au-format 
clips), discographies, etc.

among the new contributors were people who improved the vrave code, 
including brian's new long-distance girlfriend, laura la gassa, one of the 
ne-ravers whose hoboken, nj apartment had hosted more than a few pre- and 
post- rave netraver gatherings. laura and brian met on vrave in april 
1993. laura moved to san francisco in 1994 and they eventually wed in 
september 1995.

also getting an account was lamont granquist, a university of washington 
student who was building up a collection of faqs and informative posts 
that were coming across the alt.drugs newsgroup at the time. this was 
before there was a rec.drugs hierarchy. lamont started a massive archive 
of recreational drug information, much of it anecdotal but with some 
scholarly references too. this part of hyperreal was and continues to be 
very popular.

brian gave me an account, too. i was on about a dozen mailing lists (you 
could do that back then; there wasn't that much traffic) and i read every 
post on the newsgroups. i wanted to archive as much information as i 
could, especially discographies and music reviews that people would post, 
and i wanted to reorganize what brian had already collected. i focused on 
the music but helped with everything. aside from the music related files i 
also had an archive of image & audio conversion and eye candy software.

there were a handful of others helping with other rave, drug and music 
related sections. we had archives for several regional rave lists, and 
there were accounts associated with those. the idm mailing list started in 
1994 on techno.stanford. rob campanell was producing a techno video show 
for the u network (a syndicated college tv network), and he had various 
files up related to that. there were sections on nootropics and smart 
drinks. and there were some e-zines that people had put together that we 
were archiving.

brian set up a gopher server on techno.stanford. this opened up a whole 
new world of possibilities. gopher is dead now, but at the time, it was a 
great interface. rather than just opening up a filesystem and letting 
people wander around and having to view README and 00-INDEX.TXT files to 
see what they were looking at, one could selectively index the filesystem, 
causing nice navigable menus to appear in people's gopher clients. as i 
got more familiar with the server's capabilities, we started adding text 
around the menus, and when i got a hold of mosaic, i found out that the 
gopher server we were using (john franks' gn) also had http service. if 
you gauge hyperreal's entry onto the 'web' as being the day the archive 
started http service, then it was sometime in 1993.

this archive didn't really have a name. it was just 'the ftp server at 
soda.berkeley.edu' or 'brian behlendorf's techno/rave archive' for the 
longest time. when i got into configuring the gopher server and setting up 
all the indexes, i registered the site in some central directory as 'the 
techno and rave resources at techno.stanford.edu'.

in the fall of 1993, while still attending berkeley, brian started working 
at wired magazine, where he set up www.wired.com, with articles from back 
issues of the magazine and other fun stuff. that was one of the first 
non-academic/research web sites online. a quote he gave me when he was at 
wired: "the people who run this company know a lot about magazines and 
nothing about about the internet."

in 1994 things really started taking off with the web. isps were starting 
to offer affordable internet access to the general public en masse. the 
consumer networks got connected to the net. it was disconcerting in some 
ways but it was my first inkling that something bigger was going on. i was 
still downplaying it, content to just help take care of the archives, but 
brian was all over it, co-leading the apache web server project, 
predicting (accurately) things to come, evangelizing, prophesizing, 
espousing terms like community building and collaborative filtering.

in july of 1994, brian bought his own pc so he could move all the content 
off of the stanford site and have more control over the servers. it was 
also simultaneously a home for a new project he was involved in: a set of 
patches for the ncsa http server ('a patchy web server' ...get it?)

the pc, a pentium 90, went under his desk at wired, was hooked up to their 
lan and was given a public ip address. he chose a domain name for it in 
honor one of his favorite techno tracks at the time: 'hyperreal' by the 
shamen. (specifically, the jack dangers remix of that song). the machine 
name, taz, was a reference to hakim bey's entry on every cyberpunk's 
essential reading list: 'T.A.Z. - the Temporary Autonomous Zone, 
Ontological Anarchy, Poetic Terrorism'.

brian wanted hyperreal to be a place where all the people who were 
contributing could have free reign over their projects, and for it to be a 
home for these projects that people couldn't put elsewhere. the subject 
matter had to meet with his approval, of course, but that just meant that 
it had to have something to do with raves, electronic music, and altered 
states of consciousness. another rule was that there could not be any 
banner ads or commercial activity on the site. this was partly due to the 
fact that wired didn't want other people using its network for commercial 
activity, but also because we just didn't want it. netscape had turned the 
web browser into a billboard, and for all the ways that was good in 
fueling the growth of the web, it was also obviously not something that we 
wanted hyperreal to be dependent upon.

said brian for a yahoo! internet life article,

     "What I was always into building was platforms - places where people 
can get together and build web sites about anything that they typically 
wouldn't be able to, and not have to worry as much about the boring tech 
side of things. Now, these days, anyone can set up a web page at Geocities 
or a mailing list at OneList, but Hyperreal continues to be a big 'group 
publishing experiment'. The purpose has evolved, but it's still about 
giving people a platform to speak from, to show off, to organize, and to 
inform, without having to worry about banner ads or other forms of 
corporate infiltration. We'll stay true to our roots until we're forced 
off the air.

     [...]

     People don't really need free web space or free lists anymore, so 
actually it's been easier to focus on supporting the really unique content 
or ideas that people want to sponsor. Just as it was in '94, the mission 
continues to be to create a reference site for this community, and I think 
we're doing that pretty well."

this volunteer-based approach has of course had its downside. projects are 
often started and then abandoned in a half-finished state. content gets 
stale because people have personal lives to get on with. it's not so much 
a community as it is a loosely organized carnival of sorts, a bunch of 
side shows competing for attention. brian and i and various graphic 
designers have made a number of attempts over the years to reign in the 
content as all being 'part of hyperreal', creating centralized indexes to 
lead visitors to the individual projects, but we've gone about as far as 
we can with this approach. the nature of the web is changing. everybody 
has their own domain name. there is no need to distinguish between 
resources just based on where they are hosted. hyperreal is not supposed 
to be about hording information. it's hard, though, because people want to 
go to 'hyperreal the web site' and can't really handle finding 'hyperreal 
the arbitrary collection of commonly-themed volunteer-run projects'. and 
it is becoming ever more arbitrary all the time.

back to the story. brian set up hotwired.com in the fall of 1994. it was 
the first ad-supported web site, and also the first user-based web site. 
around this time he dropped out of college. he went on to cofound the web 
presence / e-marketing provider organic online in san francisco, 
eventually settling in as cto of that company until leaving to start 
o'reilly's collab.net in 1998. all along, he was involved in the apache 
project, mainly as a facilitator and as a sysadmin for the project's home 
server, which was, as i mentioned, actually taz.hyperreal.org.

although hyperreal appears very stagnant, people and their projects 
quietly come and go all the time. the indexes to the web-accessible 
content are sporadically updated projects, themselves. lamont abandoned 
the drug archives after a couple years of inactivity and allowed its 
content to be merged into the erowid.org site, which we had been quietly 
hosting all along. some projects like they eye candy were retired 
semi-permanently, others like the music reviews and automated rave 
calendar are just on ice for a while. vrave had to be taken down due to 
abuse in 1998, but it might come back again someday. new projects are 
getting off the ground and others are collecting dust. everything is in 
motion, and there's always something new. it just isn't highly polished 
and could still stand to be better organized. says brian,

     "Very few other sites are as volunteer-focused as ours; most rely on 
some form of revenue, even if it's just ad banners. But even ad banners 
can really get in the way of trying to make a message. I think the most 
important thing is that we don't really care about being the #1 site for 
this or that - we just want to put out the truth, as we see it.

     Hyperreal, all told, is pretty big, as archives go, though it could 
certainly be formatted much more nicely, we admit. It's a lot like a city 
- some central planning, but most of the character comes from serendipity, 
finding the cool stuff amidst the mass of just so-so stuff. And hey, if 
you don't like a certain section, and want to help, just speak up!"

i would add that lots of people speak up, but there's not a lot of 
follow-through :) i should also mention that in addition to brian and 
myself and all the other volunteers, helping behind the scenes have been 
several people like andrew bennett and eric mccormick, whose contributions 
have been invaluable.

the rest of hyperreal's history from 1994 to the present has been pretty 
much the same story. brian contributes the hardware, the bandwidth, the 
vision, the mission, and he executes & delegates the primary sysadmin 
duties. other volunteers bring in their own projects -- web sites, mailing 
lists or whatever -- and some occasionally make donations, at their 
expense, toward hardware upgrades. hyperreal is currently a pair of boxes 
sitting in a rack space at a major backbone provider in san jose. who 
knows what it will be, physically, or virtually, next year. there is very 
little expense involved with running hyperreal, other than time, and no 
financial income associated with it.

in the mean time, the internet has gone mainstream, raves have gone 
mainstream, we're all working i.t. jobs or have started our own technology 
and design companies, and we've somehow become 'old school' in more ways 
than one. through it all, we are, each of the volunteers individually, 
dedicated to certain ideas and ideals that are compatible with each other 
to some degree, and this compatible commitment and enthusiasm manifest as 
the projects that are collectively known as hyperreal. hyperreal, or 
something like it, is the natural result of human interaction, and it will 
continue to exist in some form or another for quite some time to come.
This document last updated Friday, 10-Aug-2001 08:22:56 PDT


From: http://www.hyperreal.org/info/history.html

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="============_-1094956488==_ma============"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Technical English

--============_-1094956488==_ma============
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

Technical English

Hold on there, kids! Here's a handy idiot's guide to help you 
navigate the niggling nuances of electronic music lingo


Everyone knows that electronic music jargon is blatantly ridiculous 
and impossible to understand. Admit it, we all have to pretend to 
know what the next big thing is talking about when we hear, "I 
thought that knarzy rockno was the deepest shit when I heard it last 
November, but now it sounds just like IDM from '99 played at 120 
BPMs."

What's that shit really mean, you ask? Well, here's the translation: 
"That German stuff that sounded so good last year now sounds like old 
progressive rock played too fast."

Part of the reason for this glossary is to demystify and clarify some 
of the insidery language of electronica. A few definitions are 
obvious and quite literal, while others are, well, totally fucked up. 
But that's part of the fun. Remember, this is a "music culture" meant 
to be experienced and not necessarily understood. So chill and enjoy 
this alphabetized glossary that any beat-soused musical tourist or 
burb-dwelling, beer-slurping sports fan can use. Just clip out and 
save.


Abstract: Music that contains layers of sounds and beats so erratic 
that shaking ass cheeks to it might be impossible. But you can try. 
This is an umbrella term under which a number of different styles 
(see "ambient," "broken beat" and "IDM" below) can be contained.

Acid: A complex word that's rooted in layers of slang. In terms of 
dance culture, it began not with LSD research studies in the 1950s 
and Timothy Learyisms of the 1960s, but with a way that club-dazed 
Brits needed to define the far-out sounds of Chicago in the mid-'80s. 
In short: Acid was the sound of suburban American rave culture in the 
early 1990s.

Ambient:Music with no beats or minimal beats. Gigantic whooshes of 
sound or practically no sound at all. Perfect music as a backdrop for 
thinking, feeling, schtupping, spliffing, reading or doing nothing.

Bass: In Detroit, bass historically refers to the music created by 
'80s Miami-based stars like 2 Live Crew, who provided the 
woofer-destroying building blocks (and, you'll note, fetching 
derriere imagery) for Detroit's street-friendly dance scene. People 
new to the sonic energy of electronic dance music are often put off 
by the crunchiness and distortion of the bass. Either you wrap your 
mind and your ass around it, or you don't.

Booty: Also known as ghetto-tech or ghetto-funk. A Detroit invention 
that combines elements of house, techno, bass, hip hop and electro 
with glorious strip club inelegance. A musical genre keen-eyed on 
asses of Detroit women. Pure, politically incorrect joy that the 
Dutch, French and Germans have a better intuition for than most 
uptight Americans.

Broken beat: It's simple: Imagine hip-hop beats falling down stairs. 
It's been the sound of Detroit's Woodbridge neighborhood for the last 
five years.

BPM: Beats Per Minute. Also: how fast your heart races when you're 
slamming on the dance floor.

DEMF: Detroit Electronic Music Festival, 2000-2002. The name of the 
festival for the first three years under the direction of Carol 
Marvin and (for the first two years) artistic director Carl Craig. 
The third year, though mired in scene drama, was planned by a strong 
committee of longtime Detroit producers and DJs.

Disco: When you hear this often-maligned genre during the festival, 
it won't be the Bee Gees. It'll more likely be a track like "You Make 
Me Feel (Mighty Real)" from the late black transvestite vocalist 
Sylvester, or extended jams by Motown's Ashford and Simpson. It's 
stuff that really made the "disco sucks" rock fascists nervous.

DJ: The disc jockey as selector, the person who chooses what record 
comes next, and sets the emotional temperature of the club space. DJs 
are, for better or for worse, the kings and queens of the scene.

Downtempo: Slowing the music down to normal breathing levels. Sexier 
than dancing to head-hammering techno. Chilling it down without 
getting all ambient.

Drum 'n' bass:Like the sound of a roaring freight train, often with 
what appears to be chaotic snare and bass drum programming and 
sampled or live vocals. Fans of D 'n' B are devoted, and spread out 
all over the planet. Large scenes still flourish in parts of the 
United States and Europe.

East Grand: As in The Boulevard. Home to the world's most famed 
techno emporium, Submerge Records.

East Side: Roughly, Detroit east of Woodward Avenue. Home of the 
rave-converted Packard Plant and seemingly every other abandoned 
factory in Detroit. Musically, the East Side is considered to be the 
home of electro lovers (see below). No, we're not talking Clinton 
Township or Lakeside Mall here.

Electro: The itchy, twitchy electrical outlet of dance music, filled 
with sounds pioneered in the early '80s by such groups as Kraftwerk 
and Cybotron. A versatile style: Depeche Mode, the Pet Shop Boys and 
the Human League are electro; so are Detroit's Adult., Ectomorph and 
booty DJs like Assault and Godfather.

Fuse-In: Part metaphor, part contractual obligation, the name merely 
extends the six-year melodrama more commonly known as "The Festival."

Hip hop: At the beginning of Detroit's techno culture in the early 
'80s, hip hop was just one sound among many (electro, progressive, 
funk, disco, new wave) that could be used to turn a party out. Twenty 
years later, the difference in the various speeds of the styles and 
differences of culture may seem too significant to overcome. But just 
watch the Fuse-In crowd find common ground when Mos Def hits the 
stage.

House: The sound of Chicago, the heartbeat of New York, the call of 
the urban diva: a clear influence on Detroit techno and variations on 
electronic dance music developed in Europe. House is an outgrowth of 
disco; you can hear the syncopated beats and gorgeous melodic 
structures nurtured in the 1970s in almost every track. And its 
variation, deep house: House music built on smoother, rounder melodic 
tones and a less frenetic pace than its source.

IDM: Intelligent Dance Music. Rarely on the beat and less pop than 
the sounds your refrigerator makes, IDM is the elitist cousin of 
techno that makes for difficult dancing but far easier chin 
scratching.

Ital-Disco: A combination of acid house, techno and electro developed 
in Italy 25 years ago, and for years a part of DJ sets by Derrick 
May, Carl Craig and Stacey Pullen.

Jefferson Avenue: The street to bang on in the summer on the way to 
Belle Isle. The corner of East Grand Boulevard and Jefferson was the 
site of the, er, fuse that lit the 1943 riots, but now is home to a 
Starbucks financed by Magic Johnson. Mythologized by DJ Assault as 
the nasty-ass strip where you go to see "ass 'n' titties" bounce.

Knarz: Crazy, Germanized techno that improbably combines elements of 
rock music and the baroque. The sound is dark and druggy, and works 
best in the basement of a factory between 4 a.m. and sunrise. Best 
practitioner scheduled for Fuse-In: Berliner Peter Grummich (who also 
records for Ann Arbor's Spectral Sounds).

Minimal: Stripping dance music down to bare essentials. It could be 
house or techno played fast or slow, intended for the club or for 
listening on headphones. See UK-based Web site ubercoolische.com for 
a cheeky soap opera starring main practitioners Richie Hawtin, Magda 
and Ricardo Villalobos.

Movement: The name of the festival for years four and five, run by 
Derrick May and his Transmat record label. Though powerful and 
exciting at times, the most lasting image is of May tooling around in 
a golf cart with a bucket begging for money.

MusicoLogical: The name of Kevin Saunderson's new production company. 
He says it's a combination of reason and sound. We say, as we're sure 
you do, "Huh?"

Producer: Another name for an artist who makes music, producing 
tracks with analog equipment or digitally with computer software. Not 
all producers of electronic music are DJs and many DJs are not 
producers. Both producers and DJs rarely play "live" (that is, create 
new music as they're performing) thereby making many of Fuse-In's 
live acts special enough not to be missed.

Rockno: A combo style that fuses rock, techno, electro and other 
influences. Who does it? See Pan/Tone, who is not on the festival 
lineup but will play one of the many afterparties (see afterparty 
rundown, online only at www.metrotimes.com).

Tha D: Detroit, Big D, Motown, The Motor City, Techno City, 
Technopolis. Got it?

The shit: An ear-bending musical experience so unimpeachable that 
true descriptive words escape you.

Techno: Beats played in 4/4 time. Melodies that sound like they were 
created in outer space. The music can come in wildly different 
variations, and be remixed into infinity. The sound that the entire 
world associates with Detroit.

Trance: The sound most reviled and snubbed by Detroit techno purists. 
It's considered too commercial and far too stylized for many hardcore 
technophiles. But the sound is creeping into European techno and 
house records, and goddamn if it doesn't sound good when used for 
escapist purposes. The Brits and Germans are calling this development 
acid-trance or neo-trance.

West side: Detroit's neighborhoods west of Woodward. Home of Buy-Rite 
records and all of those boojie blacks who "invented" techno. Not 
Canton Township or Novi. No way, mister.

http://www.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=7730

-- 


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                  
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all 
the money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody 
else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into 
experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to 
the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are 
alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

--============_-1094956488==_ma============--

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves BBQ 

Who here is interested in planning a BBQ for SFRaves ?

BBQS are easy to organize, cheap on the funds/cost, can be hosted in a park or 
in someone's Backyard, can be all ages, and can have music.

This is an opportunity for us to join together in person and get to know one 
another.

Any takers?

<3 Karina

--

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws;
        s=beta; d=gmail.com;
